"Just Cause 3," developed by Avalanche Studios, throws players into a massive open-world sandbox where chaos reigns supreme. As Rico Rodriguez, players embark on a whirlwind adventure filled with explosive action, breathtaking stunts, and liberating an entire fictional Mediterranean island from a ruthless dictator. It's definitely a game worth every dollar in my opinion.

Pros:

Expansive Open World: The island of Medici is a sprawling playground, teeming with diverse landscapes, from sun-drenched beaches to snow-capped mountains and bustling cities. The sheer scale of the world encourages exploration and discovery, with hidden secrets and challenges waiting around every corner.

Unbridled Freedom: "Just Cause 3" embraces the ethos of freedom with open arms, allowing players to tackle missions and objectives however they see fit. Whether you prefer to traverse the landscape by land, sea, or air, the game offers a vast array of vehicles and traversal options, from sports cars and fighter jets to wingsuits and grappling hooks.

Spectacular Action and Destruction: The game's signature feature is its over-the-top action and destruction, with players able to wreak havoc on the environment using a variety of weapons, explosives, and vehicles. From toppling statues and blowing up bridges to engaging in epic aerial dogfights, the chaos knows no bounds.

Fluid Movement and Combat: Rico's traversal abilities, including the iconic grappling hook and parachute combination, provide fluid and exhilarating movement options both in and out of combat. The controls are intuitive and responsive, allowing for seamless transitions between traversal and combat encounters.

Stunning Visuals and Audio: "Just Cause 3" impresses with its stunning visuals and immersive audio design. The vibrant colors, detailed environments, and breathtaking vistas make for a visually striking experience, while the dynamic soundtrack and sound effects enhance the adrenaline-fueled action and intensity.

Cons:

Repetitive Mission Structure: Despite its expansive open world, the mission structure in "Just Cause 3" can feel repetitive and formulaic. Many missions boil down to a familiar pattern of liberating settlements, destroying enemy infrastructure, and engaging in repetitive objectives, leading to a sense of monotony over time.

Technical Issues: The game's launch was marred by technical issues, including performance optimization problems, bugs, and glitches. While many of these issues have been addressed through patches and updates, some players may still encounter occasional frame rate drops, texture pop-ins, or other technical hiccups.

Thin Story and Characters: While "Just Cause 3" excels in its action and gameplay, the story and characters are relatively thin and forgettable. The narrative takes a backseat to the chaotic gameplay, with shallow character motivations and minimal development hindering emotional investment in the overarching plot.

Limited Enemy Variety: The game suffers from a lack of enemy variety, with players facing off against the same generic soldiers and vehicles throughout the majority of the game. A greater variety of enemy types and encounters could add depth and challenge to the combat experience.

Lack of Meaningful Progression: Despite its emphasis on chaos and destruction, "Just Cause 3" lacks meaningful progression systems to incentivize players to continue playing beyond the initial thrill of causing mayhem. The absence of character progression or meaningful rewards for completing objectives may lead to a lack of long-term engagement for some players.

Conclusion:

"Just Cause 3" delivers an adrenaline-fueled thrill ride through its expansive open world, offering players the freedom to unleash chaos and destruction on an epic scale. While it has its flaws, including repetitive missions and technical issues, its strengths in action-packed gameplay, fluid traversal mechanics, and stunning visuals make it a standout title in the open-world action genre. Whether you're soaring through the skies in a wingsuit, liberating settlements from oppression, or causing massive explosions, "Just Cause 3" delivers an exhilarating and unforgettable experience that is sure to leave players craving more chaos.

This game is a top notch endeavor of free-roaming destruction. The various means of destruction are quite enjoyable and quite intense. For instance, calling in an air strike from above, or using a 'rocket launcher' that shoots 5 rockets at once; or another type that shoots a single rocket that breaks off into 8 smaller rockets, of which each home into your previously locked on targets (up to 8, obviously).

The core gameplay loop is "liberate settlements and military bases/outposts," and do "missions." It is quite fun, and it doesn't get boring at all, because the variety of destruction is substantial. In addition to the aforementioned means of destruction, one may obtain an 'Apache' style helicopter and rain destruction from above; jet fighters are also available. Or if assaulting via the waters is more your style, you can obtain a gun-boat of which has two miniguns and two rocket launchers of which shoots a massive barrage of seeking rockets (this is DLC, admittedly). This is only a brief mentioning of what there is.k

To conclude, this game is absurd, but in the absolutely best way possible!

Just Cause 3 - A Explosive Sandbox Extravaganza

Rating: ★★★★☆

Just Cause 3, developed by Avalanche Studios, catapults players into a Mediterranean playground of chaos and destruction, offering a whirlwind experience of action-packed stunts, massive explosions, and liberating an entire island nation. While the narrative may falter, the game's emphasis on unrestrained fun and an expansive open world makes it a thrilling adventure for fans of explosive action.

The standout feature of Just Cause 3 is its vast and visually stunning open world of Medici. The sheer scale of the environment, from picturesque coastal towns to towering mountains, provides players with a playground for adrenaline-fueled antics. The inclusion of a wingsuit and a grappling hook, both seamlessly integrated into the protagonist's arsenal, amplifies the sense of freedom and verticality in exploration.

The grappling hook, in particular, becomes a versatile tool for creative mayhem. From tethering enemies to explosive barrels, creating makeshift slingshots, or enabling daring mid-air stunts, the grappling hook adds an extra layer of creativity to the chaos. The destructible environments further enhance the joy of wreaking havoc on an epic scale.

The game's emphasis on vehicular mayhem, including a diverse array of cars, motorcycles, helicopters, and fighter jets, adds variety to the gameplay. The ability to hijack any vehicle on the fly and seamlessly transition between land, sea, and air contributes to the game's sense of fluidity.

Just Cause 3 boasts a visually appealing and vibrant aesthetic. The sun-soaked landscapes, detailed environments, and explosive pyrotechnics create a visually stunning backdrop for the game's action. The occasional technical hiccups and frame rate drops, while present, do little to dampen the overall spectacle.

However, Just Cause 3 falls short in terms of its narrative depth. The story, revolving around protagonist Rico Rodriguez's quest to liberate Medici from a tyrannical dictator, is predictable and serves as a backdrop rather than a driving force. The characters lack significant development, and the overall plot feels like a mere justification for the game's chaotic gameplay.

The game's progression system, based on liberating territories and completing challenges, may become repetitive for some players. While the explosive action remains entertaining, the lack of meaningful character progression or narrative rewards may leave some longing for more depth in their experience.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 delivers an explosive and entertaining sandbox experience that revels in chaotic creativity. The game's open-world freedom, stunning visuals, and adrenaline-pumping stunts make it a must-play for fans of over-the-top action. While the narrative may be forgettable, the sheer joy of causing havoc in the beautifully crafted Mediterranean playground more than makes up for any shortcomings.

Just Cause 3 is a monument to excess. It boasts some great improvements over the previous game of the series and evolve the formula in a significant way. I love playing with its systems, It’s a really good game if you just want to destroy stuff, overall it’s like a GTA game but just with more freedom. I don’t like the driving mechanics but other than that it’s a good game, I highly recommend this if you are a open world game enthusiast. Just Cause 3 is the peak of the series imo.

The game forces an "Online log-in" for a single-player game. This is annoying by itself, but this login fails consistently, and there is no way to "enable offline mode" even though such an option is present when the login attempt fails. When clicking "Enable offline mode" the game works fine, until you open a menu, e.g. the map (which you use all the time), and then it freezes all gameplay while trying to log in again. Rinse and repeat.

This becomes so frustrating, that I often give up on playing this game.
It should be noted, that I have NO issues in other games, and have low latency and high down-/upload speeds. I play CS2 and Warthunder just fine, with zero lag. The issue must be with Square Enix's servers.

The ultimate comfort food game.

Features a dumb "good guy" vs "bad guy" story that you don't have to think too much about. No moral ambiguity or whatever. Might be a negative for some, but I appreciate it's innocence and simplicity nowadays.

Super fun gameplay that's accessible and and easy to get into, but with enough mechanics to allow for plenty of freedom and self-expression, which keeps it engaging and helps mitigate repetition. Just have fun with it, and don't always pick the most effective, optimized and boring way to do something when you have so many other options at your disposal.

Good game to play when you're going through some hard times.

Buy only on a sale and have fun. By far the best in the series with amazing destruction, graphics, weapons and vehicles. The only negative is the lack of diversity in weapon, many weapons feel like they repeat and are useless like the mag grenade launcher, outperformed by the grenade shotgun. It is the same for rockets and snipers. There is no reason to switch explosives assault rifles and sidearms from revolver, tactical assault rifle and the 5 burst rocket launcher. The DLCs do not fix the problem. Gunplay is good until the drones and juggernauts appear, the juggernauts are just uninteresting and slow bullet sponges, drones cannot be harmed unless from a explosive or tether to the ground. Another problem would be the sky fortress dlc which gives you a permanent upgrade to the wingsuit that also only creates probles, dodging missles from drones or stationary turrets is impossible, get stun locked and repeatedly locked on unless getting out of the wingsuit which negates all the wepons that it comes with.

[h1]Take Back Medici From An Evil Dictator[/h1]
Set six years after its predecessor, Just Cause 3 follows series protagonist, Rico Rodriguez as he returns to his homeland of Medici, a fictional Mediterranean island country under the control of dictator General Sebastiano Di Ravello. The game is played from a third-person perspective and allows players to explore the tropical island of Medici in an open world environment.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Graphics are really gorgeous. The tropical environment is really well done here. The cities are well designed, the water is beautiful, and the attention to detail is pretty good for the time this game was made. The car and character models look pretty decent as well. Now the destruction effects are impressive, even by today's standards. One tip I recommend is to make sure you don’t use SMAA 2x, just use SMAA since that looks much sharper (for some reason). Overall the graphics are really good, and have had zero issues with them. A truly stunning game, and world.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay is the main course here. Being able to wingsuit around the map is such a unique method to travel around. You also get a grapple tool as well, making interactions with the enemy and environments much more engaging. You can also be really creative on how to deal with targets with the grapple tool. The destruction is some of the best destruction in an open world game, Being able to destroy bridges, towers, walls, etc. It’s so fun just to cause havoc. Now the destruction isn't 100% perfect since you can’t destroy most buildings, but overall it’s really well done. You have tons of cool vehicles and weapons in this game. The better thing is that you have a tool called the “Rebel Drop”. These rebel drops allow you to create your own care package of 1 vehicle and some weapons of your choosing. The more vehicles you store in your garage, the more vehicles you can choose from in your Rebel Drop. There are TONS of vehicles in this game. This includes cars, bikes, boats, planes, helicopters, and military vehicles. Gear mods are also a cool feature. These are basically like perks for your character, vehicles, wingsuit, etc. The stupid thing about these gear mods, is that you can only get them from challenge missions. And I have to say that these challenge missions get old really fast, and are so frustrating at times. Why not just give me gear mods from natural progression? That would have been a better option. I do have gripes with this game. The gunplay feels stale and so boring. Gunfights are just a snoozefest here. The driving is stiff and not fun at all. The AI are brain dead at best. Also the controls are annoying at times. Keyboard controls feel like an afterthought, because some keybinds are just horrible. So I recommend a controller if you want a good time here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story is pretty lame in my opinion. It’s uninteresting, boring, and just cliche. Basically take control of the island and kill the bad dictator. It was so stale and lame. I was basically just dragging my feet to beat the story. Now the island control (taking territories) felt pretty cool and gave me a sense of progression. Taking outposts can be fun since you have so much freedom on how to take them. Wanna grab a tank and destroy everything you can, Wanna crash a plane into the outpost, you can as well. You don’t have many restrictions here. I mean the gameplay and taking outposts just overshadows the story in every way! Now I’m sure Just Cause was never really known for its good story, but it doesn’t mean they can get away with a generic lame story. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]Playtime is around 50+ hours if you plan on getting everything done. You do have good replayability since you have many collectables, challenges, and good overall progression. Also the overall gameplay is really fun here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]I love the sound design. The explosions sound really incredible. Also the weapons sound really good. They are punchy and have an echo/reverb effect since you are around many mountains. The voice acting is okay. Some cringy and annoying lines, but overall pretty good.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]AI pathing is pretty bad at times. I saw them get stuck on rocks, houses, etc. Physics can be a little odd. A little jump can make you go flying after landing. Also the timer will skip seconds. This is frustrating when you do challenge missions.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Performance is pretty inconsistent. Now my PC specs are way above the recommended specs and I still got a lot of stutters and lag at times. I even got a low memory warning with 16GB ram (I never had this issue with any other game). I had many odd framedrops (would go back to 60 after a few seconds), stutters when using wingsuit, and some other minor hiccups. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Solid sound design
[*]Beautiful open world map
[*]Grapple mechanics are fun
[*]Superb destruction physics
[*]Really fun gameplay mechanics
[*]Good replayability (progression stats, collectables, etc)
[*]Able to use many types of vehicles (both air, land, and sea)
[*]Gear mods grant amazing abilities and upgrades to your gear
[*]Rebel drops allow you to spawn in many types of weapon and vehicles
[*]Taking enemy outposts and claiming parts of the island gave a sense of progression
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Gunplay is stale
[*]Terrible keybinds
[*]Story feels rushed
[*]Driving physics feel stiff
[*]Challenge missions are terrible
[*]Performance is pretty bad at times
[*]Locking gear mods behind challenges
[*]No health bar (not essential, but would have been nice to have)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]6/10
Buy this on sale for 50% (if you are gonna buy the XXL Edition).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Just Cause 3 has a pretty fun gameplay loop. With tons of destruction and a huge map to explore, you can get lost in the island of Medici. Now it may not be indepth, and can have some annoying problems like performance and some odd design choices, but overall it can be a fun game. I don’t like how some things are done here, but I’m sure others prefer how it was designed. I just wish they change how you can achieve gear mods, and made the story at least somewhat interesting. The game is okay, not amazing or bad, but a joy to mess around in. Don’t come in here expecting something incredible. You will have stale driving, gunplay, and a story. In trade off, you will have a huge map with tons of vehicles and great destruction, and some cool gameplay mechanics. I’d say give this game a try. It may or may not be for you. If you are conflicted on this, than wait for a sale.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

This is the first and so far only review I have left for a steam game and I think that alone should say something.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. If you are looking for GTA with more explosions and none of the "realistic" crap (trading stocks, playing sports, having to buy ammo and parachutes and etc.) then this this is the game for you. While it does get a little repetitive with the town liberation after a while, the explosions truly never get old (especially the spherical gas tanks or the mining machines). 

Nothing compares to busting into an enemy base with a tank and leveling the entire place, or taking out an ENTIRE outpost with a SINGLE shot from the nuclear rocket launcher.

The DLC's are all totally worth it to. They add some story missions but also add some really nice gear including a jetpack to attach to the wing-suite (you'll never need a helicopter again), a "lightening gun", and the fastest boat you will ever drive!

10/10

Oh Just Cause 3, you're a beautiful game.

Not because of your storyline or your combat system, but because of your absolutely gorgeous visual design.
I can't say how many times I've been running, driving and gliding across the islands and wishing that it was a real place I could visit. The bright colour scheme used in towns, nature and different weathers is marvelous.

This totally makes up for the terrible writing. Seriously, it's worse than the Fast & Furious movies. Plot armour there, plot armour here, unnatural conversations and some very predictable plot points.
It's... really bad.

The combat system on keyboard is doable and with all the gadgets Rico has you can still try new things 20 hours in. On controller it's an absolute nightmare (at least for me) and I only use the controller for driving or flying. Yes, you can switch back an forth like that.

Other mechanics in the game are all quite easy to get used to and the challenges spread across the islands will keep you busy for a while.

The DLCs are nice additions, mainly because of the new vehicles, gadgets and challenges. The storyline is... just as bad.

Still, I like Just Cause 3 and I do recommend it.
Just maybe watch some gameplay footage first and see if it's really your type of game before buying it.

Before I get into explaining why this game is bad let me tell you that mechanically this game is great. All of the improvements we needed in the first two games have come to fruition here and if you turn your brain off and just focus on the gameplay loop of destruction you can enjoy this game as i am doing so now.
Where this game turns into a disappointing massacre of the franchise however is the writing and composition, or rather lack thereof. While the past two games presented a great dark humor about the CIA interventions and double crossings in any given banana republic, where there are truly no good guys and rooting for anyone is a grave mistake, this game throws all that away and paints a poetic picture of revolution and liberation where there is a clear side to be taken. Worse yet, our beloved Rico Rodriguez who used to be a MexAmerican covert operative is now fighting for his home nation of Medici (I guess Italy?) further forging a bond between one side of the equation and the player. Added to this are the unbearable quips and clown-like comedic characters and dialogues that throw the whole dark humor aspect of the franchise into garbage for the benefit of a lazily written story that lacks any depth, creativity, or brilliance. Furthermore, the story is downright preposterous. While the old games followed a sensible story such as narcoterrorism and oil dictatorship, this game for some reason is written with the intention of chasing an imaginary substance called Bavarium in the hands of a dictator whose arsenal of helicopters and troops is greater than the US and who probably wouldn't need the substance in the first place. To add insult to injury we can collect diary tapes of this dictator where he narrates a story of his rise to power in the most black-n-white way possible, justifying why the bad guy is bad to the player. Instead of all these the game could easily create a cynical dictator who has nuclear weapons or biological ones or heck even one who does human testing or something tangible. But alas the writers seem to have conceptualized the story while still in middle school, where gray areas of life are still unknown and subtlety is nonexistent.
Add to all these the horrific ludonarrative dissonance this game suffers from, where Rico (our Mexican native of Italy) is called a savior by the NPCs at the same time that he steals their cars to add to his collection, murders them without consequence, and bombards their homes in fits of unpunished war crimes. If anything, here we should assume that the supposed bad guys are the true heroes for going after Rico as soon as he hurts civilians all the while our revered rebels stand to the side and talk about how they worship him.
But the crown jewel of annoyances in this game is the constant online login messages you get in the middle of play. Started a mission but your internet was unstable? Forced pause to ask if you want to keep playing offline. Quickly trying to check the map? Forced pause telling you the game is logging you in online. Opening the main menu for whatever reason? Logging in again. This will happen way more often than you'd think and despite having a stable connection for some reason it keeps happening to me and many others on the internet. I guess you can't play a terribly composed game without added annoyance these days.
Finally, the liberation activities of the game do not match with the questline. You may liberate a whole island and have no enemy presence in there but the story would still be behind you and its missions would still show opposition control of the areas you have already taken. This could have been easily fixed by gating the areas behind story missions as do many other open world games. But I guess the makers were just too careless to do that.
All in all this is a missed opportunity and wasted mechanical perfection.

It's probably not as good as Just Cause 2, but it's still a fun time. It has less content and variety overall but it has a way better movement system with the addition of the wingsuit and more polished controls. Other than that though, I feel like it's a bit of a step back from the previous game in pretty much every way. Not to say it's bad, it's still fun for the most part but it suffers from the same problems most open world games do - it just gets repetitive after a while. It's the perfect kinda game to throw on a podcast or youtube in the background and zone out to while you destroy some settlements and blow things up to.

I would recommend this if you enjoy Just Cause 2 or if you can't handle the older graphics because it's basically the same game, just a little less good in my opinion

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Just Cause 3 is a game that I can only describe as 'fun' but that descriptor might be a tad too bold for some.

Firstly, I am a huge fan of the second game, which has a spectacular map, a fun B-movie like story and a cast of quirky characters like dear old Bolo Santosi.

Compared to it, the third game is a lot less about fun and more about repetition, and not in a nice way.

But there is still something under that shiny surface which saves the game from being bad to me, which is the gameplay (much improved grappling hook) and the gliding suit (especially with the DLC upgrade). Together with that the island of Medici is simply staggering, and those who have been to a Mediterranean location could attest to how true to life the map can be.

I also appreciate the amount of hidden details in this game, seems like the devs have poured a lot of love into the world.

Now with the positives out of the way, what is so bad about the game?

From the gameplay perspective, the challenges are horrible. Why are game altering mechanics such as car nitros, glide-to-ground, and hook-to-kick stuck behind repetitive missions that have to be done in a specific way in order to receive the highest amount of gears just to unlock one ability? Furthermore, who designed some of these? I swear, it's like most of the challenges have not been properly tested since you can fail them just because the game glitches out or you unintentionally strain the physics some way. 

Furthermore, the car and especially the bike physics are just asinine, the worst. No car in the real world behaves like those at all and this would not be such a problem had the cars not been the focus of several missions including escort ones. Likewise, helicopter/plane/boat nitros? Really?

Some challenges like the gliding ones can be cool, or maybe the shooting galleries, while simple, can be nice as well. But the rest, like the destruction challenges are just horrible to do.

And is it just me or does Rico die too easily while the NPCs are bullet sponges? Sure, you get a respawn next to the location where you died, but it is still annoying since the enemies have laser-like sight and a tendency to spawn right when you are hacking a SAM unit. Quite annoying. Likewise, why are the sprint and the evasion buttons gone? They were great in JC2, without them, Rico is just harder to control and play with.

And while the world is awesome, half of it is empty. Sure, there is a reason for it lore-wise but it makes the last third of territory liberation borderline tedious since there is not a lot of variety in those later locations, compared to the first or the second island.

And while we're on the topic of liberation, the liberation/mission structure makes no sense, like why would Rico liberate a central military outpost when the next mission destroys it anyway, making its liberation worthless in turn?

The storyline as well is just weak, with one particular moment near the end also making absolutely no sense the way it was set up and shown. You'll know it when you play it.

Also, please, let me go into permanent offline mode. The worst thing is how much loading there is with the online service, which I did not even want to use!

So then why am I still recommending this game with such a large amount of negatives?

It's not bad.

I grew to not expect much from the JC series, but what it lacks in depth it makes up for in sheer fun. Liberation and blowing stuff up is still cool, and some of the vehicles you can use to do that make the game have some impressive legs. The Sky Expansion especially was a godsend here since it made the gameplay much better.

It's a 7.5-8 out of 10 for me, but for anyone who just wants to turn off their brain after a terrible day at school/work this might well as be a 10/10.

The unwritten rule for anyone should be 'If a game doesn't take the player seriously and treats you as a dum dum, then the game is automatically a failure'.

Here the full list of issues in the first hour of gameplay.
* AI has different rules applied.
* AI Rebels attack small guard tower. I help and then get treated worse than the AI would have.
* Control scheme is a s bloated as a 2010 game with a lot of overlapping rules for gliding, parachuting and more.
* Control scheme seems hella limited due to dead zone. I did not care to look into the settings past the graphics.
* examples for overlapping: landing with tether grapple only works with some angles. tether does not speed you up unless you somehow learn the bad but skillful system. Collision with gliding is awkward.
* one of the slowest controller control schemes ever.
* game tells you at least 3 times to open up the map and follow instructions which do not even work unless it is pixel perfectly executed.

PS: Sniper Elite Games suffer from the same strange way where player's integrity to find out everything about the objectives without help is no thing. Hitman even shows all ways how to complete a mission. I want Thief, Deus Ex, similar no-hands-approach. So I could not stand the game sadly.

Somehow i missed this Game the last 9-Years, so i started and played this Game in January 2024.

This Game is absolutely Fun!
The Open-World is Huge, the Story is good and the Graphics are still very nice, especially with Downsampling.
Some Physics are great, some others are just strange.
Rico's Tether let you do some creative and destructive Stuff!

If you looking for a Single-Player-Game with a big Open World where you can make Chaos and just have some fun Time; get this Game in Sale.

However, a few weeks ago I decided to complete everything in the game. I discovered the hard way that there is a save file issue and no steam cloud backup. I had gotten to 79% completion when I accidentally dropped my controller on the start screen clicking start new game. The new game deletes your save file. So, I had to start over. But luckily I had backups.

Have not played the other Just Cause games, so this review will not be biased off of past/future JCs in the series and/or opinions of others - but rather, my experience alone, from playing the only Just Cause in the series (so far).

Just Cause 3 brings you the experience of many other traditional open-world games. Outside of missions, you are free to roam and explore the vast world of Medici (where the game takes place). And the map of Medici, is large. By large, I mean very, very large. The environment and map design helps re-imagine a place that reassembles around the Mediterranean sea; forests, mountains, hillsides, countrysides and a large portion of water (lakes and rivers included!) With the tools of a parachute, grapple and wingsuit combined, you will find yourself soaring over the skies and cities often, to get around. While of course, travel by car is also possible.

The main activity you would be doing outside of missions is taking over bases and outposts - mainly by destroying the so called "chaos objects". And of course, with destruction comes explosion, and the game has many, many explosive objects. Alongside this, you have your tether tool to tether multiple objects together, bring them together, or tearing them apart to witness more explosions. This is, what I believe, makes the sandbox experience more immersive. 

There are also many challenges in forms of mini games which you can do to unlock "Gear Mods" - unlocking a more, fun play style to your arsenal of weapons. One thing I do feel inclined to mention about challenges though, is that some of them may seem quite challenging, and by challenging, I mean extremely difficult to the point where you are required to follow exact procedures to unlock all possible gear mods for the challenge (five maximum).

[h2]Lack of "features"[/h2]
[list]
[*]No minimap. Uhm.. just, why? You will find yourself repeatedly having to open the map amidst of all chaos in order to find where the last missing chaos objects are to completely liberate a base, which is very, very annoying.
[*]No sprinting. Apparently the developers believed that it is unnecessary to add a sprint button, since you already have your grapple and parachute to move around easily.
[*]Weapon ADS is an upgrade. I honestly cannot comprehend why something as simple as aiming down sight was locked behind a gear mod upgrade.
[/list]

Overall though, really good game. All the variety of vehicles you have, ranging from cars to boats, to planes, to helicopters, to jets, to military assets, and an arsenal of explosive weapons, this is a truly a sandbox experience, where your creativity also plays a role (making use of your tools to cause different kinds of destruction).

Do you wanna feel like you`re a professional badass, destroyer of cities with a masters on overthrowing dick-tators and a PhD in being cool, than this game`s for you.

[h1]Just Cause 3 - What A Blast! 8/10[/h1]

Estimated 100% Completion time: 40-60 hours.

To put it in one sentence, Just Cause 3 is a Michael Bay simulator in a sandbox environment. Yes, the story isn't particularly compelling, nor are the characters anything complex, but the gameplay is just fantastic. From the flow of the movement mid-air to the incredible levels of demolition that the series is known for, Just Cause 3 somehow made a fairly repetitive gameplay style become ever more entertaining the further into the game I got.

My only complaints are that the vehicle controls aren't particularly great. The driving feels very heavy compared to other titles, and this made using certain vehicles near impossible. This is alongside the fact that this game doesn't run particularly well on occasion, crashing every now and then. However, this only happened to me a few times in my nearly 50 hour playthrough of the main game + all DLC.

The PC version offers a smooth gameplay experience with great graphics. The world is huge, the challenges are engaging, and the gameplay loop is addictive. This entry in the series far exceeds JC4 in terms of fun, although the sequel does have a more varied map. Liberating outposts and wingsuiting around Meddici remains one of the most fun gameplay experiences around, even many years after its launch.

Venturing into the Mediterranean republic of Medici, you'll find yourself entangled in the oppressive regime of General Di Ravello. Assume the role of Rico Rodriguez, determined to dismantle the dictator's grip on power through any means necessary. With an extensive arsenal and complete freedom across 400 square miles, chaos awaits, promising a thrilling but flawed adventure.

Key Features:

Limitless Exploration: Explore the vast Mediterranean island with unprecedented vertical freedom, engaging in skydiving, BASE jumping, and free diving without constraints.

Wingsuit Mayhem: Soar through the skies and maneuver across mountains using the Wingsuit, introducing a fresh perspective for delivering destruction from above.

Grapple and Parachute Mastery: Utilize the Grapple and Parachute to scale buildings, seize vehicles, traverse swiftly, or creatively tether objects for chaotic outcomes.

Destructive Chaos: Unleash widespread destruction in military bases, harbors, prisons, and other facilities to dismantle the dictator's regime.

Explosive Arsenal: Arm yourself with an array of explosive weaponry, from shotguns and missile launchers to tank-busters and air-strikes, ensuring chaotic mayhem.

Vehicle Variety: Choose from an extensive selection of vehicles, including speedboats, jets, helicopters, turbo-fueled sports cars, and super bikes, each offering a unique experience.

Challenge Missions and Collectibles: Embark on dozens of challenge missions and hunt for collectibles, adding an adventurous layer to the quest for chaos.

Online Community Features: Engage with online community features, fostering connectivity and interaction within the chaotic world of Medici.

While the promise of limitless freedom and destructive creativity is enticing, the game suffers from certain drawbacks, making it a somewhat flawed experience.

Third game of the franchise. I played JC2 for the first time 10 years ago and more recently just after I beat up the 3rd so I can provide a very quick comparison.
Both games are huge sandboxes that you will only play if you like destroying things. Both stories can be summarised on a stamp: there is a dictator on an island and you have to help the rebellion to knock him down.
I liked both games but of course since it is quite old, everything seems heavier in JC2 and at the end I had more fun in JC3. Maybe it's also because JC3's DLCs provide big guns and if you unlock them early you can play like in a god mode! Is it a problem? Actually no! I love feeling indestructible and feeling that no enemy has a chance against me. It’s just what theses game should be! JC2 is more old-school with the management of the health and ammos and for this kind of game, it's just not so fun.
From a graphics point of view, JC2 looks definitely old but the environments (tropical, mountains, jungle and dessert) still look pretty. In comparison, JC3 offers a bit less diversity (mountains, countryside, Mediterranean cost) but it looks gorgeous with textures from another dimension compared to JC2.
In the end, if you have not played any JC, just skip JC2 and take JC3 with the DLCs. Also I did not play JC4 so maybe just go for this one since it's apparently a JC3 + tornadoes ;)

[h3] Just Cause 3 - XXL Problems Edition [/h3]

[b] Pros [/b]
- Great visuals, environments, explosions. 
- Great accompanying main menu OST
- Health system has been improved compared to JC2
- Fast travel option available, albeit not at the start
- There's fun to be had, especially for the first few hours
- Cutscenes can be skipped from the main menu. This is vital, considering the crashes and inadequate autosave feature which force you to re-do missions. 

[b] Cons [/b] 
- Main menu loading time is too long! Took 1 min and 13 seconds at one point. This adds insult to injury when desktop/system crashes occur out of the blue. 
- Story is subpar even compared to previous games. Dialogue is atrocious, with above average voice acting. 
- Rico is now upbeat and lighthearted. Far less serious than before. Quite the change in personality from JC2.
- Fatal crash during a sprint challenge. Another right before finishing a mission. Yet another while close to establishing record time while on a rampage. Plenty of others thoughout my time playing. In all instances the game wasn't saved properly! 
- Vehicle controls are as horrific and janky as ever, especially while driving backwards. Moreover, if the camera controls don't give you a headache, it's hard to say what will.
- Such atrocious vehicle controls make challenges a pain to complete.
- Far too much busy work for barely any gain. Liberating cities becomes repetitive. Traveling between places is also an issue that exacerbates this.
- After completing the sniper challenge, the precision aim toggle stays on, requiring a full restart of the game.
- Dialogue lines can overlap, regardless of person. They can even bleed into other, unrelated missions/challenges. 
- Mario's dancing belongs in this section. Ya, really!
- Some cutscenes show game debris flying across the screen at supersonic speeds. Temporarily amusing.

Conclusion: Honestly, due to all the cons and crashes, I initially wanted to give this game a thumbs down. However, for what it's worth I did have fun at the end of the day and I suppose that's what ultimately matters. If you intend to get this, doing so on a sale/in a bundle would be best. 

PS: Tested on PC. Intel 12th gen CPU, Nvidia 30 series GPU, Windows 10. [b] If you've tested this on Linux, leave a comment as I'd like to know how it performs. [/b]

This used to be a great game. Yes, the gameplay was a bit too fast to offer proper tactical gameplay, but you could still have fun AND play tactically with your team (if they actually bothered to cooperate in any way, but that´s the curse of online gaming and the braindead masses). And then the overhaul came. And, i liked the idea. Everything i read about it sounded great. PIP scopes, more tactical cooperation and everything else the game needed to be closer to PR than battlefield. And then the update dropped. And it´s utter ♥♥♥♥. Just.... bad. Terrible performance. PIP scopes are a disgrace to video gaming. (ever heard of SCP secret lab? Free to play game. Got pip scopes too AND THEY WORK. IN A FREE GAME) Adsing causes constant stutters, frame drops and worst off all? Black frames. You try to ads while allready seeing an enemy in front of you? Enjoy a second of blackscreen and gunhandling as if you were in the middle of a 9 on the richter scala earthquake. Scopes literally cut out while you try to ads. They just turn black for a moment. And i haven´t even gotten to the part where your guy takes three days and a vacation to aim in the first place, shakes like he withdrawing from seven different substances at once and suffers from recoil as if he was using a shoulder fired 30 mm anti-air battery. One way to lessen all of these problems, would´ve been something the playerbase has been demanding long before the infantry overhaul. REDUCE MOVEMENT SPEED. Now we have people sprinting by the doorway you´re covering, circling you two times and then just spray you without ads while you TRY to get your gun into their aproximate direction. Instead of fixing the game by actually fixing the damn game, the devs rather waste hundreds if not thousands of hours of development work on things the playerbase has not asked for.
Oh and now to why this game will be dead soon anyway. Tencent. Now owi is trying to push skins, in an effort to "finance further development". Funny. Right after being bought by a mega corp, microtransactions appear. Hm, where did i see that allready. Oh yeah, all of those dead studios and games. One example, Insurgency Sandstorm! First they added micro-crap with the reasoning of financing development. Then all the devs magically were fired and their positions outsourced for cheap. And then ALL OF A SUDDEN there wasn´t enough money to pay for development, while the investors were marking record profits, and THE WHOLE STUDIO WAS LAID OFF. But nah, couldn´t be EXACTLY WHAT´S HAPPENING HERE

Just Cause 3 - Unleashing Chaotic Liberation

Just Cause 3, available on Steam, is a whirlwind of explosive action and unbridled mayhem that solidifies its place as an adrenaline-pumping open-world experience. Developed by Avalanche Studios, this third installment in the series takes the concept of sandbox chaos to new heights.

Visually, the game is a feast for the eyes. The Mediterranean archipelago of Medici is a stunning and diverse backdrop, featuring lush landscapes, picturesque coastlines, and towering mountains. The attention to detail, combined with vibrant graphics, creates a visually captivating playground for the chaos that ensues.

At the core of Just Cause 3's appeal is the freedom it offers. The protagonist, Rico Rodriguez, equipped with his iconic grappling hook, parachute, and wingsuit, becomes a one-man wrecking crew. The seamless transitions between these tools empower players to traverse the expansive world with unparalleled freedom, turning every mission into a canvas for creative destruction.

The game's arsenal of weapons and vehicles amplifies the chaos. From high-speed chases to explosive shootouts, the action is relentless and over-the-top. The destructive capabilities, coupled with the expansive map, provide players with countless opportunities to engineer chaos in their unique style.

While the story takes a backseat to the gameplay, offering a somewhat predictable narrative, the focus on fun and spectacle compensates for any storytelling shortcomings. Some players might encounter occasional performance issues, with frame rate drops during intense moments, but these drawbacks don't significantly hinder the overall experience.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 on Steam is a must-play for fans of open-world mayhem. Its breathtaking visuals, seamless traversal mechanics, and explosive gameplay make it a standout title in the genre. If you're ready to unleash chaos on a grand scale, Just Cause 3 invites you to tether, glide, and explode your way through the vibrant chaos of Medici.

A fun game that doesn't take itself too seriously. I almost got JC4 Reloaded, but reviews really favored 3 as best in the series and so far I've not been disappointed. I bought the game and all the DLCs for under $10 USD and its definitely been worth it. 

I'm still going through the campaign, but I'll say this, I really enjoy being able to just play the game without feeling stuck to the storyline and or having to complete missions/objectives in any specific order. The DLC really makes the game even more fun with the jet suit and mech. I've yet to even do the Sea Heist DLC yet. The controls feel a little janky at first such as using the grappling hook and wing suit, but with a little practice its a lot of fun getting around the map. Most of the time you won't even be using vehicles (helis, planes, ships, cars etc). 

There is a ton of stuff to blow up and quite a bit of weapons at your disposal. Completing challenges as side objectives opens up gear mods which provide extra abilities based on what the challenge is so that opens up even more of what you can do in the game. 

I put this game on my wishlist and the next day it went on sale, so I got lucky! Definitely worth playing and it'll eat up quite a few hours liberating towns within its huge map!

Gameplay - 9/10
Blowing up enemy bases is fun but does get a bit repetitive especially if you go for 100% completion (which I did and fully recommend doing so that you can get the most out of your experience)

Sound - 10/10
No sound compression as far as I could tell and the explosion sound effects are great.

Story - 3/10
Don't play this game for the story as it is pretty 'meh' but still better than Just Cause 4's and I only played the story missions to get 100% completion.

DLC - 8/10
Again, Don't play the DLCs for their stories, but the weapons you get from them however, are great. The wing suit that you get from the Sky Fortress DLC is really fun and can rinse a small base in a few well placed rockets. The ship from Bavariam Sea Heist DLC can beat all the sea races with almost no difficulty. The Eden Spark that you also get from the Bavarium Sea Heist is so fun as you literally summon lightning down on your enemies. The mech that you get from the Mechland Assault DLC can one shot the final boss (Just use the rebel drops to drop it in and chuck Di Ravello into the lava) and is also pretty much needed to get a boat that is stuck in a lake that you need to transport to a garage to chop (You can do it with a helicopter but it is like 10x easier with the mech.

Price
The XXL edition, which includes the base game and all of its DLC, is the one I recommend and is I think £55 but usually goes on sale for about £3 (that's how much i bought the XXL edition for)

[h1]Just Cause 3 - Unleashing Chaotic Liberation[/h1]

Graphics: ★★★★☆
Just Cause 3 delivers a visually stunning open-world environment filled with lush landscapes, vibrant colors, and expansive vistas. The Mediterranean-inspired setting provides a diverse backdrop for chaos, and the level of detail in explosions and environmental destruction is impressive. However, occasional frame rate drops on some platforms can be a minor drawback.

Gameplay: ★★★★★
Just Cause 3 excels in providing a sandbox of destruction and creativity. The grappling hook and parachute mechanics, combined with an expansive arsenal of weapons and vehicles, empower players to create chaos in countless ways. The freedom to approach missions and challenges creatively adds a layer of replayability that few open-world games can match.

Story: ★★★☆☆
While the narrative is serviceable, Just Cause 3 places a stronger emphasis on over-the-top action and mayhem rather than a deep, engaging story. The characters and plot are somewhat forgettable, serving as a backdrop for the game's true focus – providing a playground for chaotic and explosive gameplay.

Soundtrack: ★★★☆☆
The soundtrack complements the game's high-octane action with energetic and fitting tunes. The use of licensed music during intense moments enhances the overall experience. However, the soundtrack may not be particularly memorable outside of the game's context.

Level Design: ★★★☆☆
The world of Medici is vast and filled with diverse regions, each offering a unique backdrop for destruction. The level design accommodates the game's chaotic nature, with numerous settlements, military bases, and challenges to conquer. However, some areas may feel repetitive, and the lack of truly distinct landmarks can make navigation challenging.

Replayability: ★★★★☆
Just Cause 3's replay value is substantial, thanks to the sheer variety of ways players can approach challenges and wreak havoc. The liberation of settlements, completion of challenges, and experimentation with different weapons and vehicles provide ample reasons to return to the chaos of Medici.

Overall: ★★★★☆
Just Cause 3 is a playground of destruction and mayhem that delivers on its promise of explosive action in a vast open world. While it may not offer a deep narrative experience, its strengths lie in providing players with unparalleled freedom to create their own brand of chaos. For those who value pure, unbridled fun in a video game, Just Cause 3 is a wild and exhilarating ride.

Happy 8th anniversary Just Cause 3! It's fitting I complete this game for the first time on it's explosive birthday. JC3 is one of those games in the open world genre that can be boiled down to "shoot red thing." Sounds simple right? Well that's because it is. Blow up military bases, liberate provinces under siege, and blast through 3 massive islands in a near 16 hour romp that never gets old because of the limitless experimentation granted by the numerous weapons and the abuse of a silly physics system... and that's not even half of it. 
The other bits are a little hit or miss though, I like the activity system, rewarding you with new ways to play as you go through them (i.e wingsuit challenges or mayhem a la Saints Row). The game is actually surprisingly restraint on collectibles, as nobody wants to collect a hundred useless artifacts, instead opting for lore dumps and vintage weapon/vehicle parts. 
Now the most meh thing about this game would be its main story, it only takes up 4-5 hours of runtime, but because Avalanche couldn't come up with mission ideas past "escort this" or "follow pipes" it feels so much longer. Couple that with a very paper thin plot and a LAME ending, and yeah you'll be glad you never have to play it again after completion. At least the characters were fun to be around otherwise it would just be flat out bad.
Ignoring a weak story (which is not hard to do), Just Cause 3 is one of the best "blow up thing move on" open world games since Crackdown 1.

After having 100% this game just a few minutes prior to writing this review, I can only recommend this game. It's has been incredibly fun and the moment to moment gameplay is one of the best found in any game. But not just the moment to moment gameplay feels great, also the progression system plays perfectly into the setting and premise of the game.
Yes sometimes I hated the game for ragdolling Rico all over the place, yes sometimes I hated the game for missing a challenge by like .10 seconds, but completing them just feels so much more accomplishing after that. I could write a lot more here, but just try it out. On sale its just a few bucks and it can give you like a hundred hours of fun time. (Yes my time is way shorter, but I played alot in offline mode to avoid Square Enix' servers - the only real bad thing)

Purely on a dollar-per-hour basis, this would be worth buying but much of this game is simply a bloated sandbox where you repeat much of the same 'liberation' and side missions ad nauseam. The main variations are in the story missions and even there, a few of the missions are simply 'battles' where rebel and DRM influence are measured but the DRM (occupying faction) cannot increase theirs. The final boss fight was also a massive disappointment as you simply fly to a remote island and fight a single advanced helicopter that you have fought a few times before now, with ease. I only needed my rocket launcher and its 6 shots. It was also very demanding on my computer and glitched a few times where it either killed me by getting me stuck in the ground/walls or simply broke while loading a cutscene. I enjoyed JC2 much more, especially due to have 3 different factions that you worked with instead of just 1.

[h1] JUST CAUSE 3 REVIEW - War and Peace (Light Spoilers) [/h1]
[i] I only get my political education from the best media out there. [/i]

Having picked up Avalanche's cult classic, Just Cause 3, after playing the recent The Legend of Zelda games, I realized just how damn ahead of its time this game was.
While it is in certain ways a mechanical downgrade from Just Cause 2, the game explodes (ha) the quality and quantity of the Hollywood action spectacle to epic proportions. The store page really does not lie when it promises an entire mediterranean island state for you to explore and blow up its fascist regime, one base after another.

The game definitely lacks variety concerning enemies, NPCs, mission objectives, and even much of the open world is littered with very obviously copy-pasted structures, but it doesn't really matter.
The best open world games are, in my opinion, those that don't give a damn about exploration and are all about your direct and immediate interactions with the world, so that any ordinary land- or cityscape can serve as a setting for a whole array of different activities. Just Cause 3, like Insomniac's Spider-Man, the Batman Arkham trilogy and Zelda Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom, excels at the moment-based gameplay.

Graphically, this 2015 game is eye candy.
The lighting, textures, particle effects and oversaturated colors all work in harmony to paint the fictional mediterranean nation of Medici as a wonderful panorama.
Only real graphical complaints are the low-res debris from explosions, as well as the characters’ stiff faces.
Performance on Steam Deck is extremely stable, with only occasional technical jank or crashes. The game also experiences no slow-downs whatsoever when there is a lot of action on screen, a far cry from its disastrous launch in 2015 and yet more proof that western soft- and hardware should just always be bought at least two years after launch.

The gameplay is a constant thrillride.
You get exactly what's on the box, if not way more. Rico Rodriguez' insanity cannot be contained by a box art.
Even if seeing the same copy-pasted structures, enemies and vehicles gets visually boring, the action never does.
It takes time to learn the mechanics and physics system, and I've had plenty of frustrations as a result, but if you focus, you'll keep on improving until you turn from an action hero to an unstoppable force of primal destruction.
Also, don't skip the challenges when you unlock them. They're a bit boring, compared to the 1-on-50 gunfights, but they're your only source of 'Gears', the currency used to unlock upgrades to all your moves, weapons and vehicles.

This game also knows how to pace itself well.
Especially in areas you've liberated, the peaceful atmosphere provides a stark, but wonderful contrast to the insanity of war. Not only is it legitimately relaxing to drive, fly, swim, climb and wingsuit across these beautiful landscapes and search for collectibles, but it also reminds you what the war that the game's story centers around, is about.
This is massively helped by the incredible soundtrack by the masterful Henry Jackman, who knows precisely how to make you melancholic when at peace, and how to get and keep you hyped when fighting the dictator's forces.
And I swear, the soundtrack is mixed adaptively by the game, according to your gameplay…

The story reminds me of old Bond films, but with a slightly more down-to-earth and also personal touch.
The previous game didn't take itself seriously at all and was very obviously satire.
In it, a younger CIA Special Agent Rico Rodriguez tore down the government of the fictional eastern country of P A N A U, simply because the local dictator turned his foreign policy against the US after murdering the previous guy. You also infiltrated the organizations of extremely stereotypical mafia-like criminals.
In a massive tonal shift, Just Cause 3 balances the political satire with the personal story of Rico Rodriguez and sees him fight the enigmatic, if generic, fascist dictator General Di Ravello, in order to finally free his home country from decades of the man's brutal oppression.
A few characters, specifically Mario Frigo and Annika, may be extremely annoying, but it hardly detracts from the overall experience.
I also love the little detail of David Tennant getting kidnapped at the start and being forced to narrate the General's radio propaganda and progressively losing more of his mind as the story goes on.

There are also audio tapes that Di Ravello hid across the country over the years, which serve as one of the primary optional collectibles. While they really only please lore junkies like myself, they are very interesting to listen to, both regarding the relationship between Rico Rodriguez and General Di Ravello, as well as the worldbuilding of the country of Medici.
The General may be a 2D character, but he does serve as a baseline example of fascism.
I was only half joking when I opened this with "I only get my political education from the best media out there", as especially the tapes are a legitimately educational documentation of the never-changing method that political psychopaths use to convert free countries into fascist collectives. It's food for thought, and especially important to me, a Gen Z German who's studied his country's past.

[i] A wonderful package of an exhilarating open-world action-fantasy marathon with substance, creative gameplay, beautiful graphics that bring out a beautiful world and a thrilling soundtrack. [/i]

[b] 9.5/10 [/b]

"When Just Cause was heading in a positive direction, I made one last attempt today to give Just Cause 3 a chance. To be honest, it's just not working for me. The AI, gunplay, lack of precision in aiming, and overall control issues are quite frustrating. Additionally, the way AI seems to materialize behind you like specters is perplexing. Over the years, my preference has shifted towards other open-world games that offer more refined shooting mechanics and superior driving controls. Take CyberPunk, for example. The driving in that game was initially too rigid, and many players didn't like it. However, the developers revisited and improved it. Therefore, as time goes on, Just Cause should consider reevaluating its approach and reimagining a more polished gameplay experience."

Just Cause 3 is actually really good, probably the best of the Just Cause series. I love the setting of the game - that Mediterranean vibe in aesthetics really looks beautiful to explore. The game remains as fun as other titles with the parachute/grapple gun stunt mechanics, and the collection of vehicles provides enough choice for getting around the world.

I do like the side activities in the game - some of them are challenging - as well as the ability to reset any liberated location post-game. The story was a good one to see play out, and its missions are not too difficult to play through. I recommend getting the DLC for this game to expand the fun; I also recommend using a controller, as its more fun using one to play the game with.

I don't know if it is that I played Horizon Zero Dawn and Far Crys.  But this game I always meant to get to and just did and it's repetitive.  The play control is decently responsive but you keep getting trapped when grappling to almost going up but not quite.  The play overall is fun for an hour or two and then, more of the same.  I feel the same way about a more modern game like Far Cry 6.  It's just a lot of the same over and over and over.  You blow up stuff, fun.  Stuff never really seems to change or get that different.  So really it gets boring pretty quick as your upgrades are not really vastly new things just extensions of the same.

I don't know, maybe if I put in more than 4 hours it would start to get better but it just was feeling like more work then fun to play this in 2023.

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Just Cause 3 is a wild, action-packed rollercoaster that takes you on a breathtaking adventure through the fictional Mediterranean island of Medici. With 27.8 hours of gameplay, I've had ample time to experience the game's unique blend of open-world mayhem and unbridled freedom.

The game's central premise revolves around your role as Rico Rodriguez, a one-man wrecking crew tasked with liberating Medici from the tyrannical grip of General Di Ravello. From the moment you hit the ground (or the air), it's clear that Just Cause 3 is all about creating chaos. The game's open world is your playground, and your destructive arsenal includes an impressive array of weaponry, vehicles, and, of course, the iconic grappling hook and wingsuit combo.

The real star of Just Cause 3 is the grappling hook, and it's not your typical grappling tool. It allows for boundless creativity and destruction. You can tether objects together, pull them apart, create makeshift zip lines, or even use them to slingshot vehicles into the air. The grappling hook, combined with the wingsuit, grants you a sense of freedom and mobility that few games can match. Soaring through the skies and gliding over lush landscapes is a truly exhilarating experience.

The world of Medici is vast and diverse, featuring scenic coastlines, towering mountains, dense forests, and bustling cities. The visual design is stunning, capturing the essence of a Mediterranean paradise corrupted by dictatorship. The variety of environments encourages exploration and experimentation.

Despite the freedom and mayhem, the main story missions can feel somewhat formulaic, often involving liberating bases, destroying infrastructure, and taking on General Di Ravello's forces. However, the real fun in Just Cause 3 lies in the sandbox nature of the game. Side activities, like challenges and stunts, are where the game truly shines. Racing jets, wingsuit courses, and engaging in creative chaos is where you'll find the most fun.

The game's chaotic nature, while thrilling, can sometimes lead to a lack of focus. Storytelling takes a backseat to the action, and the characters, including Rico himself, are not particularly well-developed. But for players looking for a pure adrenaline rush, this may not be a significant drawback.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 is a love letter to explosive, high-octane action and the exhilaration of unfettered freedom. With 27.8 hours of gameplay, you've likely experienced countless explosions, death-defying stunts, and a fair share of laughter at the sheer absurdity of it all. While the story and character development might not match the intensity of the gameplay, Just Cause 3 delivers unapologetic and chaotic fun that will keep you hooked as you explore the bounds of your creativity and the limits of the game's explosive potential. It's a beautiful symphony of destruction and freedom that's sure to leave a lasting impression.

In Just Cause 3 Rico Rodriguez returns home to Medici, the island he once called home. This is the place he grew up, the place where he left his friends after his parents were brutally murdered and a place ruled by dictator Sebastiano Di Ravello.

I was surprised to see that Just Case 3 is almost a copy of just Cause 2. It seems as if the developers simply moved the story from the tropical South-east Asian island Panau to the Mediterranean. Other than that, the addition of a wingsuit and improved graphics it's almost the same game.

But since Just Cause 2 was a huge success and lots of fun, creating a copy was probably not the worse thing to do. Just Cause 3 is a huge open world playground with tons of things to do and a blast to play. The game offers...

- 22 story missions
Scripted and too childish in my opinion. If you only concentrate on the story you'll miss the best of the game. In my opinion the story is the weakest part of the game. It's rather boring, too easy and silly.

- 3 DLCs
Just Cause 3 comes with three major story add-ons: Bavarium Sea Heist, Mech Land Assault, and Sky Fortress.
Story-wise the DLCs are not much better than the main story but add some great new equipment to the game.

Bavarium Sea Heist adds the Loochador, an armoured jet-powered boat, armed with missiles and mini-guns. Besides being a lot of fun to operate, the Loochador helps a lot when it comes to collecting a few specific achievements.

The Mech Land Assault adds two new mini-games to the game where you have to defend two different military bases from waves of incoming invaders with a mech. While the mech doesn't really feel like you would expect a mech to feel, it's still a lot of fun to defend the bases. These mini-games are great add-ons!

Sky Fortress enhances your wingsuit dramatically by adding a Bavarium-powered booster, homing rockets and a machine gun. The DLC also adds the 'Bavarium Splitter' an extremely powerful assault rifle that you don't want to miss.

- Free Medici
Besides completing the story you have to free Medici. This means you have to free villages, small outposts and military bases - some of them huge - from the oppressor. In order to do so you have to destroy chaos objects such as fuel depots, pipelines, gas pumps, radars, communications masts, satellite dishes, wind turbines, generators, transformer, police stations etc. Although repetitive, this is a lot of fun. Causing chaos while igniting explosions all over the place with a huge arsenal of weapons never grows old.

- Challenges
In order to upgrade you gear you can complete the following challenges:

Destruction Frenzy Challenges: Destroy as many Chaos objects as possible with a specified weapons / vehicle

Crash Bomb Challenges: Drive a super-charged vehicle towards a target without losing too much speed, then bail out and watch the fireworks.

Shooting Gallery Challenges: Complete various weapons training courses to increase your proficiency with different types of armaments.

Scrapyard Scramble Challenges: Collect and deliver caches of Bavarium using a specially designed magnet attached to a vehicle.

Wingsuit Course Challenges: Fly through the markers to complete the course - the closer to the center of each marker you get, the higher your score will be.

Land Race Challenges: Race a land vehicle (car, truck, tank, etc.) through a series of checkpoints. The faster your time, the faster your score.

Air Race Challenges: Pilot an aircraft through a series of checkpoints while racing against the clock.

Sea Race Challenges: Drive a boat through a series of checkpoints while racing against the clock for a high score.

- Collectables
There are tons of collectibles in Medici. Scattered all over the island you can collect the following items:

DiRavello Audio Tapes - tapes recorded by your enemy DiRavello that add additional story content to the game when found

Rebel Shrines - small, blue shrines with candles that need to be light to access quick travel

Vintage Parts - Dig them up to unlock additional nostalgic weapons

Daredevil Jumps - Jump of ramps with cars as fast and far as you can

Ancient Tombs - Old graves you can only find on the last island you visit.

- Achievements
Some very cool achievements like collecting all vehicles including all planes and boats. This was a lot of fun!

Pros:
- beautiful graphics
- excessive explosions
- brilliant sound effects, cars sound better than in many racing games, insects, birds, waves
- parachute and wingsuit
- insane stunts
- driving cars in Medici is wonderful
- and all cars feel very different and individual
- boats, planes, helicopters, tanks, jets
- huge arsenal of weapons
- good music
- fantastic start screen
- peaceful sceneries
- wild action

Cons:
- rather childish and boring main story
- repetitive gameplay, but lots of fun if you like it
- requires a potent rig
- rather long loading times
- very poor German voice acting, except from DiRavellos speaker who did an outstanding good job
- some challenges seem impossible to beat with highest rating

[h1] Just Cause 3 [/h1]

[h2] Review Date: [/h2]
October 13, 2023

[h2] Reviewer Name: [/h2]
Schqrk Reviews

[h2] Overall Rating: [/h2]
9/10 ⭐

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

As I revisit the sun-soaked Mediterranean archipelago of Medici in Just Cause 3 in 2023, I'm overwhelmed by nostalgia. This isn't just a game; it's a time machine that takes me back to my childhood. From the countless hours spent on my PlayStation 4 to the epic adventures on my PC, Just Cause 3 has transformed into an all-time favorite, etching indelible memories of chaos and creativity. In this review, I aim to delve even deeper into this cherished game, showcasing its brilliance and why it remains a beloved childhood classic.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Explosive action: The graphics in Just Cause 3 are a testament to the game's ability to deliver explosive action that continues to captivate. Vibrant explosions, chaotic firefights, and dynamic destruction remain as exhilarating as ever, etching memories of daring escapades that are impossible to forget.
[✔️] 🖼️ A picturesque paradise: Medici isn't just a backdrop for destruction; it's a scenic masterpiece. The diverse landscapes, from lush forests to sun-drenched beaches and tranquil towns, are akin to postcards from paradise, each concealing secrets waiting to be uncovered. Just Cause 3's attention to detail transforms every inch of Medici into a mesmerizing sight that will forever remain in my memory.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Controls and responsiveness: The intuitive controls of Just Cause 3 have been etched into my gaming soul. The fluidity of movement, whether it's soaring through the skies with a wingsuit, gracefully grappling from rooftop to rooftop, or commandeering military hardware, adds to the nostalgia. These controls are more than just a mechanic; they're the thread weaving countless memories of creative chaos and destruction.
[✔️] ⚙️ Explosive mechanics: Just Cause 3's mechanics are the heart and soul of the game. The extensive array of weapons, gadgets, and vehicles provides a playground for creativity and mayhem that's unrivaled. The wingsuit-grappling hook combo is more than just an in-game feature; it's a symbol of exhilarating childhood adventures.
[✔️] ⏩ Pacing and balance: Just Cause 3 strikes a balance that transports me back to those thrilling afternoons of my childhood. The mixture of fast-paced action and moments of exploration and relaxation crafts a well-rounded gaming experience that has a permanent place in my heart.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[✔️] 📜 Action-packed storyline: While Just Cause 3 isn't renowned for its narrative depth, it has an engaging premise. The story of liberating your homeland from a ruthless dictator provides the backdrop for countless thrilling missions, each etching memories of daring escapades that keep players engaged. It may not be Shakespeare, but it's the narrative that guides your journey through chaos and creativity.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Audio and Sound [/h2]

[✔️] 🎵 Explosive soundtrack: Just Cause 3's soundtrack resonates in the caverns of nostalgia. The high-energy tunes, with their dramatic flair, sync perfectly with the chaos on the screen. Whether wingsuiting through the skies or igniting fiery explosions, the soundtrack remains a timeless memory of the game's explosive action.
[✔️] 🔊 Voice acting: The voice acting, while not award-winning, is more than just dialogues; it's a collection of character voices etched into my memory. From the eccentric personalities of Medici's denizens to the menacing threats of hostile factions, the voices encapsulate the chaos and creativity of the game's world.
[✔️] 🎼 Ambient sound: The ambient sounds, from the creaking of ruined buildings to the distant roars of mutants, transport me back to those cherished gaming moments. 

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Settings and Customization [/h2]

[✔️] ⚙️ Graphics settings: Just Cause 3's graphics settings personalize the experience for every player, transforming the game into a canvas where every memory is uniquely painted. The range of customisation allows players to find their perfect balance between performance and visuals.
[✔️] ⚙️ Gameplay settings: The customisation gameplay options offer versatile playstyles that cater to every gamer. Whether it's embarking on a hardcore challenge in survival mode or engaging in laid-back exploration, the settings add depth to the nostalgia of chaos and creativity.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[✔️] 🕒 Explosive content: Just Cause 3 boasts a wealth of explosive content, from the extensive main storyline to the thrilling side quests. These moments of daring escapades continue to yield new memories as the game keeps delivering memorable content.
[✔️] 🌐 Modding support: The modding community has added another layer of creativity to Just Cause 3's limitless chaos. While the mod support is somewhat limited compared to other titles, it enhances the game's replayability, offering fresh adventures that continue to captivate.
[✔️] 🎖️ Achievements and challenges: Completing the game's achievements and self-imposed challenges remains an exhilarating memory. The hunt for the next daring stunt or explosive achievement is etched into the very fabric of the game.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[❌] 🚫 Performance bugs: The game's performance is generally stable, but occasional bugs and glitches can disrupt the immersive experience, somewhat tainting the nostalgic journey.
[❌] 🚫 Depth limitations: Just Cause 3, while brimming with creativity, lacks the depth and storytelling found in the best open-world games, which can be a drawback for players seeking more profound narratives.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Pros and Goodness [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Smooth traversal controls: Just Cause 3's traversal controls are a timeless delight. The fluidity of movement, especially the wingsuit and grappling hook combo, ensures that every nostalgic memory of creative chaos and destruction is as memorable as the first.
[✔️] 🌈 Great mobility: Medici's vibrant landscapes come to life through the game's exceptional mobility. The graceful way you traverse mountains and seas adds depth to the memories of discovery and exploration.
[✔️] Numerous options for destructive experimentation: Just Cause 3's options for chaotic experimentation continue to captivate. The vast array of weapons, vehicles, and gadgets fuels the memories of thrilling childhood adventures, each more explosive than the last.
[❌] 🚫 Playful sense of humor: Just Cause 3's playful sense of humor, including its well-timed quips and one-liners, isn't appreciated by all players. Some may find it out of place in the chaotic world of Medici, but for many, it adds a touch of humor to the destruction.

[✔️] 🤔 Would you recommend this game? Just Cause 3 isn't without its storytelling and performance issues, but it remains one of the best games I've played in a while, a masterclass in action-packed open-world gameplay. The game's chaotic and creative spirit is a captivating memory, and it's an all-time favorite that everyone should experience. Just remember, when in doubt, tether an enemy to a fuel tank and let the sparks fly.

[✔️] 💬 Additional comments: Just Cause 3 is a game I'll always remember as a childhood favorite and now, an all-time favorite. The memories of creative chaos and destruction, whether on a PlayStation 4 or a gaming PC, have left an indelible mark. Revisiting Medici in 2023, I was reminded once again of the unparalleled chaos and excitement that Just Cause 3 delivers. 

[hr][/hr]

One of the best games I've ever played. The controls are fluid and work great together with the wingsuit and grapple hook. All the weapons in the game are satisfying to use and aren't unbalanced. The aircraft is a major win, as all of them have great controls and feel like an extension of you, rather than a limitation. Challenges are super fun and varied (except for Laguna Blast). The open world is also pretty well designed and feels rewarding to explore.

However, there are a few reasons why it's not perfect. The game has many, many bugs. They can range from minor physics glitches that mess up Rico's grapple hook, to catastrophic errors that can randomly crash the game, corrupt saves, or just force the game to not start at all. They degrade the quality of the game a lot, it wouldn't be a problem if the game was short as you would be much less likely to encounter them, but since the game is quite long, bugs will inevitably appear as you play.
