Never ever buy this game! Save your money and time. Game is unstable, it has some serious bugs. 

Game sometimes crashes during missions when specific things are not done as game intended forcing you to start mission again. 

At one specific time I was driving a tank on a road and suddenly it just disappeared into thin air. I wasted one beacon on that tank and it just disappeared without even letting me get to my destination. Definitely not what I expected from this game. 

When vehicles or aircraft are left at a specific spot then they risk to disappear for no reason. Sometimes they are still there after you come back from whatever you where doing far away from them and sometimes they just vanish. 

Fell through the map while driving a jet on a bumpy surface. Managed to get back up by using wingsuit and grappling hook but jet fell through. 

Gear upgrade system is stupid. Difficult challenges must be completed to gain gear upgrades but I would enjoy gaining them from progressing the story, completing missions. 

Enemy reinforcements always randomly appear out of sight very close to you and immediately after they are called which is what I hate.  If you are in a slow turning vehicle like tank or helicopter that is easily destructible by rockets then helicopters, tanks and warships who are called as reinforcements can easily destroy it and leave you with nothing but your guns who are useless against them with their limited ammo. 

Just cause 3 has a few fast cars but has no race tracks to test them and enjoy the speed. Instead one is forced to race on the streets where NPC cars are getting in the way resulting in race nearly always ending with crash and car in flames. There are a few air fields but none of them are long enough to test the max speed.

This game has potential, it could be a great game but bugs and unsatisfying game play mechanics are ruining this experience and seems like developers are not doing anything to fix this game. 

Additionally, missions and challenges are designed with intent to annoy the devil out of you. They are insanely hard and player will fail over and over again. If you want destruction and explosions, go play Half life 2 and its custom maps, they won't disappoint you. But if you do decide to buy this game then buy it with dlc together. Dlc has incredibly fun new weapons and vehicles that can make gameplay much smoother and destructive. Mech from dlc will be your best friend.

This is the third time I've written a review for this game. The first two didn't do it justice. 
I'm 16 going on 17 and since I was 5 years old basically all I've done is play video games. I have spent, realistically, something like 12,000-15,000 hours playing video games in my life, which may pale in comparison to some, but is still a LOT of time. 

I may be young, brash, hyperactive and opinionated, but I'll be damned if I don't know who I am, and that person says that Just Cause 3 is probably his favorite game of all time. I've spent about 325 or so hours playing Just Cause 3 and I've beaten it and gotten 100% maybe 6 times now? (Although I only got "100%" once because I never bothered to collect every gear, just enough for all the upgrades.) It is a SUPERB experience. 

I am very sentimental. Things that happened in my past or things that defined any small facet of my life for any small period of time are grasped firmly by my mind and siphoned of all their little hits of painful nostalgia until I can hardly stand to think about them anymore. In this sense, Just Cause 3 is very special to me. But make no mistake: if I picked it up for the first time tomorrow, I'd love it just as much.

The story is pretty weak, and so are a couple of characters, but the gameplay, mechanics, music, collectibles, and graphics are all top notch. The game has astonishing graphics for something that came out in 2015. This game has the same effect as the Rocky Horror Picture Show (American cult classic) or any other movie you boot up once a year, whose lines you have memorized, whose characters you know better than you know some of your family members, whose soundtrack you could turn on and listen to in full without any device but your own brain. I go through the whole story captivated by every explosion, with the massive environment filled with little details and hand-crafted Easter eggs born of devotion and passion, driving around and killing 4-digit numbers of innocent civilians with all the weaponry the game offers.

I don't know how fairly I can really describe the game while my lens is so cloudy with the pervasive gas of nostalgia but I can tell you that after you've liberated the whole country and you just drive or fly around the verdant countryside, industrial roads, and gorgeous forests of Medici, you feel like you're in a different world. That experience alone is what I come back for. And for killing innocent people. 


Confession: I'm a fake fan. I haven't played the first or second game, but I've been meaning to. I didn't finish the fourth game because it's a pile of irreverent garbage not worth buying. 
Speaking of garbage, the DLCs are godawful. They either provide useless/broken vehicles or some scorpion gun, or they provide the BEST WEAPON/MECHS/WINGSUIT ever with the awful cost of having some out-of-place mass take up space in Medici's waters. The DLC stories for land/air/sea are garbage. I recommend buying them for the weapons but I kind of ignore the rest, but you know your boy has to get those thick juicy 100%'s.

I came back to write this review because I'm in a little bit of a depressive rut, grappling with the realization that it's not likely we're ever gonna get a fifth game. But we have Just Cause 3. And that's more than enough for me, and more than any of us deserve. And, if you somehow find this review, I want you to give it a try. And hopefully it can be more than you need too.

I bought this on sale and can say It's a pretty fun game if you're looking for an action only experience. The world is very large and looks quite appealing. Though, as I was playing the game I kept thinking that if Avalanche Studios had invested more attention to detail, making the ingame world a more believable, lived in place, it could've been an amazing game. Beyond liberating settlements and regions, completing challenges to earn upgrade points there's not much else that's a big draw to the game.

All that the ingame world serves for is as a huge sandbox to cause mindless, repetative yet fun mayhem. What I enjoyed most was darting around with the wingsuit, especially what's added through the Sky Fortress DLC. The story for me was boring and bland. They tried to give the characters their own personalities but the story, which lacked impact, prevented me from being interested in the main cast. Again, a little more attention to detail from Avalanche Studios could've elevated the game to something much more. Due to this I often just skipped cut-scenes and story beats.

What I disliked the most is how some vehicles handled. I avoided motorcycles like the plague and just didn't use helicopters and planes. The driving model (programming) for those vehicles are just subpar. Cars are okay. When I unlocked certain upgrades for the wingsuit I just used that as my main means of transportation even if it took me much longer to get from point A to B.

In conclusion: A fun game to play when you just want some mindless fun. The game could've been that much more with more attention from the developers and some extra game mechanics to immerse ourselves more into the game world. The reason why I played as many hours as I did was a drive within me to complete as many activities as possible and complete the entire game.

Definitely a buy on sale with the DLC included.

Game is fun. Now I will complain about it:

- The second game was a cheesy spy action movie. This one is a Mediterranean vacation simulator, Ubisoft style. 
- Rico used to be an undercover spy posing as an anonymous terrorist, and that was cool. Now, every person in the world calls him by name (and talks about how great he is, constantly). It makes no sense, and it's dumb. 
- Rico used to be very Mexican, maybe the only thing that set him apart from other action game protagonists. Now he's basically Nathan Drake crossed with Ezio. Hard to think of a more generic combination. 
- I started skipping the cutscenes, which I never do. The dialogue is kind of annoying. It was always hammy and cliche, which was fine. Now it's also trying to be witty and sentimental, and it doesn't work for me. 
- In the second game, you were rewarded for just causing (^^) general mayhem and destruction, like a good little terrorist. Now, you are conquering outposts by going down a checklist of things to break. The first one is fun, the second is homework. It's also thematically, a weird fit. Feels more like AssCreedFarCry than it should.
- At least so far, the story feels more sanctimonious about Rico's mission. Previously, he was an assassin, mostly in Panau to murder someone, and cause chaos along the way. He spends a lot of time threatening to kill people. Here in the third game, they play it up like he's the new Gandhi or something. I dunno, feels a lot less believable than before, which somehow makes it more scummy. Even if he wasn't employed by a morally bankrupt intelligence agency, this is a guy who sticks detonating rockets to civilians' heads for no reason. (Or that could just be me)
++ On the plus side, this game has a wingsuit, and a mech DLC, and some improvements to the grapple. 
= If you dumped the toys from this game into JC2, I would probably just play that instead.

So. Much. Fun! This is the peak of the Just Cause series and what it is known for, and that is being the perfect video game, doing things you cant do in real life. Just Cause 3 lets you live out a never ending action movie in the most beautiful paradise of your dreams... Do I need to say more? Well I will because I love this game haha. Just cause 3 in my opinion is the best in the series. The world of Medici is absolutely stunning, and has this homely Mediterranean feel that is hard to explain, I think the soundtrack definitely helps with this aswell. Unlike Just Cause 2 which, despite being an amazing game, honestly has an unsettling soundtrack which kind of makes the game feel like a horror game. Just cause 3 in comparison, the music makes the world feel so alive and calming! Which is a great feeling after causing absolute chaos! Its a beautiful juxtaposition that cant be explained or understated. Its odd since Medici doesnt have as many different biomes in the world as the other games however it still somehow has the most beautiful world! The grappling hook, parachute, and wing suit combo also peaked in this game and makes traversing the game world so satisfyingly fluid in a way that must be experienced! Furthermore the game play using all the tools at your disposal is not only super fun but creative! The game encourages you to tackle objectives in any way you see fit and in my opinion encouraging creativity in games is really lacking these days! Overall this game is a masterpiece and a must try, especially after a long, infuriating day at work there is NOTHING like Just cause 3, you can release your anger and relax at the same time!
Slightly tedious but very fun to play around with!

NICE

A lovely tech demo, but where's the game?

As standard, there are something like 21 story missions, few of which have any actual rewards.  The gameplay in each of them is entirely the same as the rest of the game, with the exception that a few of them take place inside structures.

Since your only interaction with your allies is in the cutscenes of these missions, or floating high above them during them, there's no engagement or involvement with them - contrast with Rockstar games. When one ally sacrifices themselves, the response is just "Meh, whatever".

The vast majority of the game time goes into repeating the same limited set of liberation activities over and over and over and over.  Granted, the engine is fine, and the addition of the wingsuit, and (with an expansion) the Bavarium wingsuit, adds even more pleasure to the basic activity of travelling around and raining down death.

But most of the upgrades that you earn through activities only apply to later attempts to complete that activity. Combat never changes much, and you can complete any combat mission at any time. Conversely, some vehicle missions can only be completed once you've finished the story, something that I find particularly frustrating.

There's no real payoff to completion, or to any of the activities, so all we've got here is a basic Skinner box where you chase rewards to get rewards.  It's enjoyable in the moment, but ultimately hollow and frustrating.

While a significant improvement over JC2 in terms of content amount and cadence, JC3 still remains a very janky game that retains a lot of issues going back to even the first game, while adding several of its own.

The traversal using the grapple is janky as ever as you phase through object or get caught and stopped on empty air, the constant respawning enemies are made worse by an addition of large amount of bullet sponges except for times when you have to reach certain "havoc" goals when liberating some settlements and they stop spawning for minutes at a time so you just stand around and wait, the AI is positively rarted - I have seen it crash more helicopters than I shot down and I have shot down 0 jets on my own, yet I have a couple on record because they keep ramming into buildings, they keep shooting their own allies and vehicles, etc.

The writing, the story and characters are somehow even worse than Just Cause 2, which had to take a looot of effort, because JC2 was already absolutely atrocious.

This game is not chaos gamified, it's simply a mess - not in terms of it's technical side, which is not perfect, but not bad either. However, its gameplay is an utter mess. There are games which have chaotic, but ultimately balanced and fun gameplay. This isn't one of them.

The only two redeeming qualities of this game are the beautiful environments which are again an improvement over the already great looks and atmosphere of the previous games, and the again surprisingly competent vehicle sounds which are again a step up from the already pretty good sounds in JC2. This dev team definitely knows how to deliver on the looks and atmosphere of a tropic paradise.

Do you want to play a game or watch a connecting to server screen? If you picked watch a connecting to server screen then hit that purchase button immediately.

But wait I can hear you think, isn't this a single player game? Why would it need to be connected to servers? Well that's for the public leader boards, cause nothing is more important than knowing if you have flown your wing suit longer than any one else in the game. This screen is god damn relentless, game might work fine all day, but then the games leader board servers go wonky and you might as well just shut the thing down and go browse reddit.

Screen pops up and starts trying to reconnect which take 30 seconds to 2 minutes before failing and it gives you another pop up asking if you want to try again or go to offline mode. So screw the lead boards, off line mode it is right? You go back to gaming, but as soon as any thing happens like finishing a challenge, starting a quest..... boom Attempting to Connect to Servers. Then 2 minutes later go off line mode. This is endless, occasionally it will actually connect to servers but that only last a few minutes before it drops you again. IT is insane, just an endless loop of staring at a connecting to servers screen before you get a few minutes of game play just to get dumped right back into the connecting screen.

It seems a decent and fun game, but this is the single stupidest game mechanic I think I've ever seen, If they shut down the servers and just make it offliine I would give it a 5. As is its nothing bust a frustrating pos that isn't worth bothering with.

Just Cause 3: Explosive Fun, with Some Rough Edges

I've had my fair share of adventures in Just Cause 3, both on PS4 and PC, and it's been an enjoyable ride. As someone who owns and has played Just Cause 2, I know this might be a divisive opinion, but I actually prefer this game over its predecessor. The graphics, while not groundbreaking, were decent for the time it was released. However, it's worth noting that there are still quite a few bugs and glitches that I wish had been patched, but we don't always get everything we hope for, and we have to make do with what we've got. :3

I wouldn't say it's worth the full price, though. My recommendation is to wait for a special offer or sale to pick it up.

Overall, I'd give Just Cause 3 a 6/10. It's an explosive and action-packed game, but it can become a bit repetitive and lose its charm after a while. While the graphics are okay, the bugs can be a bit of a downer. That said, there's still something oddly satisfying about kamikaze-ing into a bridge to take down a convoy, and that's a memory I'll cherish.

      This game is amazing. It's packed with explosions, guns, and non-stop action. The story is well-written and incredibly captivating. The range of options for guns, cars, and gadget upgrades available to you is just right. The freedom to roam around an open world and do as you please is liberating. The colors are bright and vivid, and the overall quality is crisp and clean. The game is very mod-friendly. I initially played it on both Xbox and PlayStation, and I had to get it on here. I would say this game is worth the $20, but if it's on sale, it's a no-brainer. It doesn't require a super-intensive PC specification lineup. You won't regret buying this game if you decide to go for it.

The good:
-The movement with the grappling hook/parachute/wingsuit combo is fluid, fast-paced and fun
-The world is large and there's a lot to explore
-Great variety of weapons and vehicles to suit different playstyles
-Performance and optimization improved since release

The bad:
-Gunplay is somewhat mediocre, not great not terrible
-Vehicle handling feels clunky (though more with some vehicles than others)
-A lot of repetitive objectives
-Storyline is similar to 1&2 (as in, unremarkable and somewhat forgettable)

The weird:
-Voice acting is extra cheesy (some will love it, some will hate it)
-The UI has a lot of strange bugs (like waypoints being placed in a different place than your cursor, or incorrect button prompts when using custom keybinds)
-Occasional crashes (not frequent, but still annoying)

Overall fun time exploring and blowing stuff up. Story missions and challenges range from reasonably good to infuriatingly broken.

TL;DR: Domestic Terrorism Simulator + Collateral Damage DLC

Just Cause 3 is (often literally) an absolute blast to play. The goal of the game is simple: Shoot everyone you meet (usually bad people, but the game doesn't penalize you in any way for killing civilians), attach bombs to things, throw bombs at things, hijack innocent people's vehicles, hijack limousines to send their not-so-innocent occupants hurtling off the local bridge, and generally cause mass amounts of destruction, all in the name of freedom (i think).

You're given an enormous open world to mess around in, all KINDS of different weapons and vehicles to play with, and plenty of enemies to kill with your new toys. There isn't much variety among basic infantry units, which usually either shoot you, throw grenades at you, or call in more reinforcements, but this is balanced out by their array of [i] scary [/i] vehicles to chase you down in. They might try to ram you off the road in a boxy jeep, shoot you from afar in a weaponized speedboat, rain the fires of Hell upon ye with an attack helicopter, or just straight up kill you with a [b] [u] VERY FAST[/u] [/b] tank. Seriously, do not misconstrue the power of enemy tanks. You will die.

I haven't finished the game yet (a testament to how fun just playing around is), but so far the story is pretty nice. Nothing award-winning, a little corny at times, but it's still neat. Not much else to say about it.

The game unfortunately doesn't take much time to explain the controls in detail, so a lot of the tricks you have up your sleeves must be pulled out through trial and error. I'm only recently discovering how to properly use several of the game's major tools. A few YouTube videos might steer you in the right direction, but it's still a shame most of the cool game mechanics are only briefly clarified in their respective tutorials.

All in all, I think this is a really fun turn-your-brain-off game. It encourages creating and employing unique methods of killing everything you see while generally offering very few puzzles or serious neuron-activating moments. Shoot bang. Big fun.

This was my first Just Cause game and it won't be my last, I bought this game based off the trailer.. and I was not expecting the trailer to be pretty much exactly like the actual gameplay. Do you want to blow up a bridge? You can do that. Do you want to fly a jet into some massive fuel tanks and cause a huge chain reaction of explosions? You can also do that. Even if you're not into the game because of the chaos, there's much more to do than just blow stuff up. Race cars through the streets of Medici, glide through the mountains with your wingsuit, zoom through the rivers on a speedboat, I found it much more entertaining on my way to hundred percenting the game to do a bit of story, do some challenges, do some liberations, just mixing it up. Some challenges can be a bit difficult (looking at you wingsuit challenges), and some challenges are just straight up bugged (there are workarounds though), but all in all, this is a really solid game. Definitely should put this one on your "Play before you die" list.

If you're in the mood for a gaming experience that doesn't demand cerebral gymnastics or intricate storytelling, but instead invites you to unleash pure, unadulterated fun and chaos, then Just Cause 3 is your ultimate destination. This game isn't about delving into intricate narratives; it's about embracing the thrill of unrestricted mayhem. From skydiving onto speeding cars to orchestrating explosive chain reactions, every moment in Just Cause 3 is a playground of exhilarating possibilities. So, if you're looking for a title that's all about unbridled enjoyment and rampant mayhem, don't hesitate to jump into the explosive world of Just Cause 3.

This game is far from perfect. The dialogue isn't great, the story is average, the world is somewhat bland, but something kept me invested the whole way through. There's something uniquely enjoyable about systematically taking out bases using all the tools at your disposal. Wingsuiting around the landscapes feels great, and I had a lot of fun doing all the challenges, even if they made me angry at times. Get it on sale and enjoy the explosions.

[h1]16/20[/h2]

[b]Absolute destruction everywhere.[/b]
The game is so much fun and a massive step up from the 2nd game, in every aspects. Physics, stunning environments, a more engaging story (even though it's an excuse to blow everything up, it still hooks you more), a lot of weapons, vehicules, skills... Even in 2023 it still looks great with amazing destructions physics. The feeling of power & freedom is amazing. Dimah is a great character too, the acting on her is really good. And for once, a game that is not about driving stuff did a wonderful job at making the vehicules FUN to handle, without too many shitty mechanisms. It's simple & perfect.
I barely stopped playing once I started it. While I had a hard time really getting into Just Cause 2. Honestly Avalanche deserves a lot of credits for this game.
... You can also die from falling structures!

[b]Still not perfect[/b]
A lot of visual bugs in big explosions, randomly popping enemies that can become a pain in the ass when they're everywhere, 3 BIG crashes for no reasons (I had to reboot my PC), the online feature at the start of the game takes either forever or doesn't work at all, and a bit too many collectibles for my taste.

My first taste of the Just Cause series and it's great.

Huge map split into 3 main islands, You unlock more and more vehicles and weapons as you progress through the game.

There is a story and it's not bad (though the ending was unsatisfying) - but the main focus is just on causing chaos and liberating bases.

The physics are fun to toy with with Tethers, Grappling Hooks and Wing suits, creating an interesting mechanic I haven't seen in many games which gives you the ability to stand or attach yourself to enemy vehicles.

Overall great fun with a decent story, would recommend.

9/10, This game gives you tons of brain dopamine from allowing you to cause mindless destruction and explosions on enemy bases while feeling that you’re progressing something. The visuals of this game are amazing, and so are the mechanics.

Though this game has faults, the story was pursued poorly and made it hard to connect with anything going on. Additionally, you don’t get to use any of the cool end game content because there’s nothing left after you get it. 

The game is still great, and I highly recommend it.


ALTHOUGH, THE CHALLENGES RUIN ANY AND ALL FUN. If I add my 100% completion of this game into the mix, this game is a 4/10 because the challenges DRAIN ALL FUN.
What do I get for it? A few extra explosives and more tethers. The most helpful thing out of my pain was the boosting while parachuting and wing suiting. Not to mention the NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE bomb drive challenge. 


As for DLC content, I actually like this story more than the original line. I am able to follow with the story more easily, and connect with what’s happening. What’s even better is all of the awesome new weapons and toys I have to blow things up! I also really like how the Black Hand actually attempt to reclaim territory before you liberate a camp too. The DLC’s are not without fault however, as it crashes much more often then the normal gameplay.

This game is a great buy for a sale price. Its basically GTA but youre a spanish guy working for the CIA blowing shit up in a fictional Mediterranean country. You have a grappeling-hook, wingsuit, and are in general OP. Everything in this game is a little dumb and generic, EXCEPT for one thing. This game has amazing attention to detail with its explosions and destruction. Not only are the effects rich and detailed, but the objects have satisfyingly good physics and can often be destroyed in creative ways. You can use a minigun to dismantle a statue of a fictional dictator, blasting off specific body parts or just cutting the legs and watching the whole thing topple down. 

This game puts all its effort into being a rad as fuck destruction simulator, and when you play it you get a rad as fuck destruction simulator. GTA but more ridiculous and arguably shittier, in a good way. Very cerebral.

9/10

The controls for keyboard are a bit annoying and inconsistent, but once you get the hang of them the movement is great.

The gameplay loop is simple (i.e. find base, destroy base, repeat), but I almost never got bored throughout my playthrough. Especially since I've already played through this game for 65 hours on another platform.

The collectables and missions add something to do once you've finished the rest of the game, but they can get boring after grinding at them for hours for 100% completion.

The game isn't very skill based (with the exception of some of the challenges), so if you're looking for a difficult game this isn't for you.

Overall it's a fun game that I would recommend playing.

Just Cause 3 is an interesting game, but repetitive. Just Cause 3 is an action game with a very simple story, but the game never tried to change that, with this, this simple story was deliberate. The gameplay is very fun, explode, fly, and blast again is very good, but even with many varieties of weapons, vehicles, and explosions, Just Cause can become repetitive (the missions are often simple and similar). Visually the game is beautiful, but what is most striking are the explosions, they are extremely well made, and can even say that they are innovative; the soundtrack does not have anything special. The major problem of this game are the bugs, are many and are annoying (but some are funny). Overall, Just Cause 3 is a very fun and beautiful game visually for its time when it came out, however, has a simple story, it is repetitive and possesses many bugs

It's pure action with a barely serviceable plot line. You can't forgot the story due to how simple the writing is. Cruising around in a helicopter or jet and taking out bases are definitely the best part of this game, solid 7/10.

What this game does very well is wanton destruction and the freedom to go anywhere using any means of transportation. Almost right from the start you can grapple and glide/fly your way to your destination. Gets even more convenient with the rocket pack. Shooting is fun, the weapons sounds are satisfying and stuff blows up also in a satisfying manner. Lots of choices of weapons. The whole "destroy all this and liberate this place" mechanic is fun but a little repetitive. Vehicle handling is somewhat lackluster however. I dislike using most vehicles in this game, especially in time trials. Usually, in sandbox games like this, I love motorcycles, but in this game they are as clumsy as a 10-ton truck. So, yeah, vehicles are not as nice as I would want them to be, but they are still serviceable. 

So, yeah, just enjoy the ridiculous carnage and destruction and you'll be fine. The humour is another thing that stands out in this game. It doesn't take itself too seriously. All in all, it is a fun game and deserves a recommendation.

Just Cause 3 is a fantastic game, despite it's bugs and glitches. I'd say that Just Cause 3 is the best game in the series. There's too much to go over with this game, so I'll give you some likes and dislikes.

I like the missions, the game isn't totally narrative driven, you can always do the missions later, but when clearing the central command for the regions you need to do the missions in order to effectively clear it. 

I don't like the difficulty of the wing suit courses, they feel a bit too buggy, the physics are a bit off with the rings, but most of all, it's the difficulty. Just Cause 3 doesn't scale, meaning everyone has to hit the same goals, regardless of if they're a veteran to the series, or a person who's first introduction into Just Cause was this game.

I like the explosions, they are certainly worse than that of Just Cause 4, but with newer games usually comes better graphics.

I don't like the explosion physics, when the Falco Maxime FOW fires, the nuke is devastating, almost nearly killing you if your too close. The version of it that you get feels dramatically under-powered despite being the same projectile, a direct hit doesn't kill you.

I love the variety, most vehicles and weapons bring something new to the table, weather it be a powerful rifle or a new shotgun. A new sport car or a new vintage vehicle, there's almost always something new.

I like the collectibles, they aren't hidden so bad that you cannot possibly find them, but they don't stick out, again, I like the variety of the collectibles, there's several different collectibles, there's tapes, tombs, and various vintage parts. Collecting all of them grants an achievement, and collecting all of one type grants a weapon/vehicle.

I like the soundtrack, it's easily one that fades into the background, but when it's not there, something just feels off about the game.

Overall, I love this game and I would recommend anyone who wants a good challenge but also an open world experience to get this game. I should note that I am not an experienced critic, and this is one of the first times I have ever reviewed a game. You should look at other reviews from more experienced critics before making your choice.

No windowed fullscreen mode.  Fullscreen mode toggles automatically between windowed & fullscreen if you alt-tab or try to click anywhere outside of the game.  Then, the game automatically minimizes, resizes itself without being told to, and when you try to fullscreen it again, it becomes stuck in windowed mode until you once again go back into settings and change it. 

Why does it take effort for the end user to have a fullscreen mode, and yet the game itself will disable the fullscreen mode whenever you are not on that screen?
this game is all like *kaboom* *Blap* *kerblam* *BOOM* *Pow* *ratatatatat* *REAHHHHH* *KOW* *BKRRRRRRR*

I'm not entirely sure how to summarize the game without sounding like an 8-year-old: "yoU gET tO bLOW StUFF uP ANd ShOOt SOmE GuYs". In truth, that's pretty much what the game is, but sometimes that's all a game needs.

With many weapons and vehicles and weaponized vehicles, and a huge open world full of stuff to bLoW Up, you can lose a lot of hours in this. The story is a good mix of seriousness and humor, and broken up into missions so you can screw around instead if you'd like.

Overall, I'd highly recommend Just Cause 3. It controls well, the physics are well-designed (save for being able to wingsuit into a cliff head-on, and just walk it off. But hey, it gets crazier.) and if you have the hardware, it's got some pretty graphics.

I'm so glad I never removed this game from my library, hopped back into this after a while only having like a few hours into it and decided to dig deeper into the game then I previously did and it was extremely fun doing so. This game is the opposite of something like Elden Ring, this game is just about going in and having fun blowing shit up and doing whatever you want in this extremely big sandbox full of goodies. Your character you play as "Rico" is practically invincible, he can be killed but you don't have to try extremely hard not to die since his skull is made out of titanium. I know this game is decently well known but I feel like it should have more notoriety in today's lists of games. In my opinion this game still holds up extremely well in today's games that you can put your time into. With this game you will have a blast if you like fast past (or slow if you take it slow) sandbox game to hop in fly around and blow stuff up. Overall one of my favorites at the moment,   8.8/10

If the movie Commando was a game, this would be that game. It is a thoroughly fun and ridiculous game, where normal rules of physics don't apply. If you're falling through the sky and about to hit the ground at lethal speeds, you can grapple to the ground and land unharmed. Your parachute has weird antigravity properties at times. 
Get the version with the DLC, you will not regret it. Turning the wingsuit into a mini-jet is wonderfully useful for navigating the map, especially when leaving the oil rigs. And speaking of oil rigs... the Loochador boat is amazing for taking them and any seaside installations out. Then you have the mechs, which allow you to lift up walls from enemy bases and then throw the walls at them. The Eden Spark is an insanely powerful device that allows you to lay waste to bases and armored vehicles very quickly, and recharges itself so you have effectively infinite ammo (but it only works outside). 
Well worth it, especially during sale events.

The main selling point of J(esus) C(hrist) 3, is its vast open world with no loading times, like in the Witcher 3. However, it also actually is its biggest issue: to minimize requirements and maximize depth of field, many crucial assets regularly fail to load up. 
This translates into invisible enemies:
- That helicopter firing at you? Make a 360° and clearly LOOK for it please, to signify I need to draw it now on your... aww, you're dead. 
- Wait! There are 8 soldiers, not 4, because I loaded them two-by-two on top of each other to save space and... you're dead. 
- Same thing with that tank. I didn't load it up while you were scouting that base and... you're dead. 
- You don't mind if I spawn another soldier with the one you just killed? It saves RAM. Yes, that means the room you just cleared isn't... you're dead. 
And also:
- Reload your gun! No, I have to prioritize enemy actions to manage the huge open world. Re-mash that reload key! I purged the order from... you're dead.
- I told you already! I can't prioritize your actions over the enemies'! The world's too huge! Re-mash the 'draw weapon' key and.... you're dead.
- You've thrown a grenade on that squad??? No, I only computed it killing you. But if you insist, since you've just respawned, here it is, on your ass. Boom gift! You're dead. Again. (true story, I swear)
And my favourite:
- You pressed 'turn left'? Twice already? Aw, shit, I have to catch up. Here it is, your three commands, all at once! You hit an incoming truck? ... You're dead!

And still the punching-bag boasts and self-congratulates, as if he was some big, badass action hero... *sigh*

Well, at least, everything is simulated: the wind, the texture of the sand, the sea waves... Okay, since it's only virtuality on a screen, you won't actually feel any of it... But they WILL impact your vehicles. Ah! The joy of playing dodge-ball when you're blind.

Also, since the game came from console, the number of usable keys is limited to that of a controller, not the number of keys actually used in the game. So, the key to 'jump' with your car and 'use nitro' is the same, for some interesting accidents... Same thing with 'accelerate' and 'use nitro' with planes; except, the plane decelerates and falls if you release the key, and nitro doesn't recharge if you don't release the key. Very handy. (But you'll love planes if you're the kind that likes being trampled by stilettos)
And the 'F' key is permanently bound to 'trigger explosives', no matter what you do - which makes remapping kind of useless. Very handy too. 
 
Time for the frosting! Since we're already in the mood... Enemies can bob and weave around your bullets. Yes, like in a boxing ring! And it takes three headshots to kill them. Unless they get back up. You're dead. And helicopters can fire right underneath themselves. You're dead. And vehicles don't have health bars, they progressively smoke and catch fire, which you can't see since there's always fire and smoke everywhere from all the explosions and... you're dead. And your allies don't care if you're in their line of fire. You're dead. And the rebels will send rescue in dire situations, if you can rescue the rescue first. You're dead. And now the baddies have armour-plated 'Terminators' with gateling guns. You're... rage quit???

Still, if the game is on sale (like 90-95% off) AND you're a Mass Effect fan, take JC3. Play Ricco a while. Then play Sheppard. *grin*

[b]TLDR: Fun gameplay and movement, but an uninspired narrative, lacklustre gameplay progression, and disappointing difficulty. [/b]

Pros:
- Good Traversal: It's entertaining to experiment with the traversal using the wing-suit and the graphing hook.
- Destruction and Explosions: The following is quite enjoyable to see.
- Tethers and Ragdolls: This game contains a feature that allows you to connect numerous hooks to one another. You could, for instance, strap an NPC to the tail of a car or a helicopter. With this, there are lots of hilarious possibilities.
- The Main Menu: It was a nice touch that the gameplay seamlessly transitions from the interface to the gameplay.

Cons: 
- The Story: This is a tedious, forgettable slog of a story. Without it, the game would have been better because it contributes nothing except bloat and boredom. 
- Lack of Weapons: This game is lacking in weapons. You won't ever use all of the weapons because some are objectively superior than others, and many of them feel out of balance. Additionally, some of the funnier weapons are DLC-locked.
- The Progression: With the exception of the wing-suit mods, the "Gear Mods" that act as this game upgrades are under-baked and can be dismissed. You must complete the same monotonous side tasks in order to unlock gears. The game linearly unlocks the mods, so you cannot choose which ones you want.
- Usless Collectibles: The game contains the following: 71 Audio Tapes, 49 Rebel Shrines, 54 Vintage Parts, 30 Stunt Jumps, and 23 Ancient Tombs. The tapes unlock a skin for a helicopter, the shrines unlocks free fast travels(which is completely useless as you can easily get fast travel flares by dying as it restocks all of your ammo for free), vintage parts unlock 2 weapons and 1 plane(the actual useful collectible), stunt jumps only unlocks an achievement, and ancient tombs unlocks 1 weapon.
- Difficulty: There are no settings for difficulty. The only option to make the game more challenging other than by self-handicapping yourself. So the game is quite an easy one. The game is particularly forgiving when you die since it gives you free ammo refills, turning death into a way to gain more ammo.
– Poor AI. The AI is your typical terrible AI that makes no effort to behave intelligently at all.
Bullet Sponge Enemies. Enemies simply have greater health in the late game, allowing you to mag dump an enemy's head with a lot of lead shots.
- Strange Keyboard Mapping. The default mappings are somewhat unusual. Thankfully, excluding menu controls, you can remap them. So have fun using the CTRL key to back out of menus.
- Long Intro Opening. Every time you start the game, an initial cutscene plays without letting you skip it. Thankfully, a steam guide may be used to get around this.
- Terrible DLC Policy There should of have been only 1 DLC. But money-hungry developers divided it up into many DLCS. 
- Cutscenes in DLC. In order to save money, they substituted a slideshow for the in-game cutscenes for the DLC missions. Every time you play a mission that isn't part of the DLC followed by one that is, it is very apparent and off-putting. This stinks of a lack of consistency and effort.
- Bugs and Glitches: This game features the typical, small problems that you get in all games, but some of them are actually rather game-breaking. I was taken to a city when I initially started playing, however there was a problem because the city wasn't correctly loaded. As a result, I had to restart the mission in order for it to load properly. Speaking of things that don't load, the enemy vehicles frequently have problems with loading and being invisible. The firearms occasionally not making any sounds is another common problem. A softlocke on the task "Rico and the Rose" was the worst problem I ever encountered. You are given the task of shielding an ally's plane from enemy planes while flying a jet in this game. The issue is that your missiles' lock on capabilities aren't applied to the planes. This leads to the destruction of your ally and the mission's failure. You must employ a speed-run technique to get around, which involves continuously spamming your missiles to stop the enemy jets from shooting. Despite this softlocke being a problem for many other players, the developers never fixed it.

A game that is great fun, but drags on a bit too much towards the end.

Pros:
- over the top destruction is lots of fun. Seeing all the pretty explosions happen as you rampage through a base never gets old.
- wide variety of vehicles - cars, helicopters, boats, planes, tanks, and more!
- voice acting and cutscenes are good
- some genuinely funny bits
- huge and varied map, with forests, mountains, caves, mines, cities, oil rigs, etc.
- cute italian/spanish/french style villages dotted around
- easy to get around even without vehicles, with the grapple, parachute and wingsuit - with some upgrades...

Cons:
- the plot is your bog-standard fare: overthrow island dictator, clear the areas, blah blah, you've played it before
- the bad guy is portrayed as a wily and clever man in the tapes illustrating his rise to power, but is portrayed as a blithering idiot in the (very few, sadly) cutscenes we get. More screen time for the bad guy would have been better.
- not that many missions: the meat of the game is in its destruction/liberation of enemy outposts
- poor car/motorbike driving physics
- annoying console port issues, like negative mouse acceleration in tank turrets
- a few annoying gamebreaking bugs, like precision aiming breaking missile lockons (mandatory for a campaign mission)
- absolutely ridiculous spawning AI. Whenever they need to produce more enemies for you, they simply spawn them in a few metres away from you out of your line of sight, so you will often find enemies in places you knew were clear just two seconds ago. Most obnoxious when clearing oil rigs in a helicopter - by the time the radio tells you that helicopters have been called in, it is 100% guaranteed that they are right behind you and about 2 seconds away from shoving rockets up your behind.
- the game drags on way too much. There is simply too much to do - too many settlements and guard posts, too many collectibles of various kinds, [b]way[/b] too many challenges, etc. There isn't enough variety or incentive to do all this either - you'll be freeing tons of guard posts by blowing up the same ol' fuel tanks, radar dishes, transformers, etc., and most of the time you'll be getting some weapon or vehicle that you already have something else better of. Once you realise this, maybe 1/3 or 1/2 way through the game, you'll just start wanting to get it over with.

In summary, the bugs and annoyances don't detract too much from the tons of fun for the time it remains novel, and it remains a great sandbox for destruction and mayhem. Given the shockingly low prices to which it goes on sale, it's well worth it, but perhaps a bit too boring at full price.

just cause 3 is a open-world action-adventure game developed by avalanche studios and published by square enix. it released worldwide on december 1st, 2015 on pc, xbox one, and ps4. it is the third game in the just cause series, following 2006's just cause and 2010's just cause 2. it's set six years after JC2 and you're still playing as series protagonist rico rodriguez. this game however, you play in the mediterranean republic of medici, which is where rico grew up. it's an interesting premise for the third game, as it was at risk of becoming stale and that alone was enough (for me at least) to spice things up. of the three just cause games i've played so far, they always have some cliché-filled story that is usually an afterthought, but the gameplay and action is usually fun enough to keep me playing until 100% completion. the first JC game was so boring and repetitive i gave up after less than two hours, as i couldn't bring myself to spend 30 or so hours doing the same things over and over again. JC2 was bloated with way too much filler side content, and while the gameplay was refined enough to keep me playing for 90 hours as i was completing the game, it definitely should've been a 60-ish hour experience instead. JC3 was a perfect step forward in that regard, as i took 55 hours, but i could see it taking as low as 45 hours for some, and at most, i could see it taking like 75 hours.

development began in 2012, handled by avalanche studios' side studio while the main studio focused on the development of mad max (2015). they ended up with a map that was similar in size to JC2, but they expanded it vertically, and the amount of actual playable area was very dense comparatively. they also focused more on making things dynamically destructible, adding a lot of mechanics to the game. they also wanted to keep the humor and wackiness that was seen in JC2, but they also wanted to explore rico's backstory more. JC3 was first teased by the CEO of avalanche studios in february 2013, and a official announcement came in november 2014, with the first gameplay trailer coming at square enix's 2015 E3 conference. 

gameplay wise, they took everything that kept you playing JC2 and expanded on it, giving rico more gadgets and more ways to traverse around the map. there's a lot of refinement throughout the game, and the developer has steadily improved over the course of the JC franchise. i am definitely excited to eventually buy and play JC4, because i feel as if they will go even bigger and even better for the fourth game. while this game released at $60 full price, and it's been marked down several times (to $50, then $30, and now full price is only $20) but the cherry on top is that you can routinely find JC3 for 85% off on sale, making it only $3 instead, which is an insane value, even if you're just playing through the main story only, which will still take most players around 20 hours or so. to me, the original JC game is a 1 out of 10, and JC2 is a like 4 or 5 out of 10, and then JC3 would be like a 6 or 7 out of 10.

I don't know why, but ever since San Andreas released 20 years ago I've been a sucker for games featuring a mechanic where you take territory from an enemy faction. Just Cause scratches that itch better than any other title I've come across. The open world freedom, the color coded map which lets you track the progression of your turf war, the way areas change once they are liberated, the freedom to choose where you're going to take the fight next. I'm almost 100 hours in and haven't done a single story mission past the one to unlock fast travel. Simply put, this game is a blast (pun intended), engaging, visually stunning and well worth the purchase.

Just Cause 3 is an absolute blast of adrenaline, offering an exhilarating open-world experience that leaves players craving more. Avalanche Studios has truly outdone themselves with this action-packed sequel, delivering an explosive playground of destruction, freedom, and pure unadulterated fun. Brace yourself for a high-octane adventure that will have you grinning from ear to ear.

First and foremost, the open-world environment of Just Cause 3 is nothing short of spectacular. The fictional Mediterranean island of Medici is vast, diverse, and brimming with life. From lush forests to shimmering coastlines and towering mountain ranges, each region offers breathtaking views and a wealth of opportunities for exploration. The attention to detail is outstanding, making every corner of the map feel immersive and alive.

But what truly sets Just Cause 3 apart is its unrivaled freedom and sandbox gameplay. As protagonist Rico Rodriguez, you have access to an impressive arsenal of weapons and gadgets, including the iconic grappling hook and parachute combination. These tools allow for seamless traversal across the sprawling landscapes, letting you soar through the air, scale buildings, and hijack vehicles with unmatched ease. The sheer freedom to approach missions and objectives in any way you desire is liberating and adds an unparalleled level of creativity to the gameplay.

The heart of Just Cause 3 lies in its chaotic and explosive combat. Engaging in epic battles against dictator General Di Ravello's forces is an absolute thrill. Whether you're raining down destruction from a fighter jet, attaching explosives to enemy infrastructure, or engaging in intense gunfights, the action never disappoints. The destructible environments take the mayhem to another level, as bridges crumble, buildings collapse, and explosions reverberate throughout the world. It's a visually stunning spectacle that will leave you in awe.

Furthermore, the game's missions are varied, exciting, and always offer room for experimentation. You'll find yourself liberating towns, causing chaos, and taking down key targets in a series of exhilarating set pieces. The pacing is well-executed, providing a perfect balance between high-stakes missions and the freedom to explore and wreak havoc at your own leisure.

Just Cause 3 also delivers a captivating storyline that keeps you invested throughout your adventure. Rico's quest to liberate Medici and uncover the truth behind his past is engaging, supported by memorable characters and solid voice acting. While the narrative takes a backseat to the explosive gameplay, it still manages to provide a satisfying backdrop for your actions.

In terms of technical aspects, Just Cause 3 impresses with its stunning visuals and smooth performance. The graphics are vibrant and rich in detail, enhancing the already immersive experience. The vast draw distances and seamless transitions between different regions of the island are seamless, creating a truly seamless open-world environment.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 is an absolute triumph that takes open-world action to new heights. It embraces the chaos, offering players an adrenaline-fueled playground where they can unleash their wildest fantasies. With its breathtaking world, explosive combat, and boundless freedom, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking an unforgettable and relentlessly fun gaming experience. Brace yourself for an adventure that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

Just Cause series is mostly known for its bombastic gameplay, vast open world or lack of compelling narrative, and it shows. The third entry in the franchise is pretty to look at and run smoothly too. The world map is big with varied environments spread across 3 main regions/ islands. There are a lot of activities or objectives to complete. From the very start you can approach and complete objectives in any way you like. Rico (player) is equipped with tools, vehicles, and weapons that you can access from beginning. There isn’t a mandatory character progression or upgrade system which you often expected in games like this. It’s great for people who wants to feel overpowered from the get-go. But, there is a demerit to this approach.
As a replacement for upgrades, there’s a “mod” system that you can unlock by completing challenges/side objectives. Mod is used to increase your inventories, upgrade your tools and effectiveness, etc. Sadly, you can’t unlock mod by progressing organically trough the main campaign. It doesn’t help that the gameplay loop start becoming stale pretty fast. Players are tasked to liberate outposts and strongholds spread across the map. These tasks are often similar with minimal variations to keep players engaged.
The main campaign itself is lackluster and forgettable like in previous entries. Avalanche devs tried to tie the setting and characters with Rico’s backstory to increase his personal stakes in the story. At the end of the day tough, players isn’t invested in the story. Mostly due to lack of connectivity between the tone of the story, gameplay structure, and characters’ goofy attitude.
Another issue I had with this game is the “always online/connected” policy. Avalanche & Square Enix tried to mitigate this requirement as a part of mandatory online ranking/leaderboard for challenges, side activities and co-op. The problem I had was that my internet connection was spotty and unreliable most of the time. So, it buggered me a lot when suddenly a message popped up that said the game is trying to re-connect while I tried to play or even opened the map.
The internet connection problem didn’t hindered my progression, tough. I could finished the main campaign. In the end, it is still a fun game if you can look past all the problems. And it’s super cheap too for AAA open world games if you buy it during steam sale.

Que puedo decir. Me pasé el juego la primera vez y me encantó allí por el 2017 u 2018 cuando me lo compré en oferta.

Ahora, en 2022, me lo pasé de nuevo, pero al 100% y con todos los logros. Es una bomba de diversión, horas y horas sin parar (a veces más de 700 minutos de una sola sentada hice).

Mucho contenido, explosiones y pueblos que liberar. Es un Just Cause, debes esperar que sea un poquitito repetitivo, pero la acción sandbox y las múltiples y diferentes maneras de jugar es lo que hace una experiencia distinta cada vez que lo juegas.

Totalmente recomendado, pillatelo con todos los DLC's (al menos los que no son cosmeticos), en especial de Sky Fortress, dado que te da un Wingsuit con propulsor, cohetes y ametralladora los cuales son muy útiles.

Corre muy bien en computadores de bajo-medio recursos. Muy buenos graficos para la época, solamente que tiene muuuy poquitos bugs o glitches, pero nada como Cyberpunk jajaja.

PD: Para la misión de salvar un avión con "X" personaje importante que está llegando a la isla (evito spoilers), desactiven el Gear MOD de una mira especial con el mouse (Ayuda de apuntado creo que se llama), luego de ello, reinicien el juego. Esto solucionará el glitch de que los Jets no tengan el autoapuntado hacia objetivos. 
Dicho MOD no es necesario la verdad, el juego tiene una buen FOV, nunca me fue necesario tal MOD para acercar el FOV con la ayuda de un botón.

While i haven't finished the game yet, i'll say this.
This game is [i]really[/i] fun. The freedom you get in exploring the world after unlocking the wingsuit in the beginning is insane. And the beautiful visuals make exploring that much more appealing. Using them in combat is also quite appealing, being able to zip through the skies and shoot rockets like a mosquito is extremely fun, so in that regard this game is a hug W.

Storywise, this game is eh... It's not the greatest writing i've ever seen and it does get a bit cliche at times. Thankfully the game doesn't take itself too seriously in regards to story, rather focusing more on the action and explosions... like any Michael Bay movie. It reminds me alot of the movie "Hardcore" where you can just turn your brain off and focus on the action and explosions. Eye candy essentially. 

What i really have i problem is with the enemies. With any game, the difficulty will increase the more you get into it, and so it makes sense to make the enemies shoot more accurately the farther in you go. However, it's so broken that the enemies rival the accuracy of TF2 aimbotters. You can literally be flying at 300 km/h and some group of soldiers with a combined iq of -2 will somehow snipe you out of the air in an instant.
But it's not just that, enemies that arrive after calling reinforcements will appear out of thin air if they're not in your line of sight. I swear, you can find a small enemy boat in the middle of the ocean and shooting it will somehow cause 2 boats with aimbot miniguns to appear out of Narnia. You can be attacking a base in a heli and suddenly get shot in the back by a heli which spawned like 10 meters behind you. You can fight people from one side of a tunnel and suddenly have a bunch of soldiers coming from both sides. It's like the cyberpunk police force, hit one and suddenly 20 appear out of nowhere with godlike accuracy. It is by far the most annoying mechanic i've ever seen in any game. And i hate how they didn't at least make it seamless

Aside from that though 7.8/10 Good exploration. Fuck the enemies.

The movement is one of the crispest in any game I've ever played; the grapple, parachute, and wingsuit all meld perfectly together to give you an absurd amount of options in any situation to go fast and pull off flashy stunts.

The physics are set such that if you exit the car while it is in motion, it WILL explode the second that it hits anything, making you feel like you got a last-second escape; there are tons of design decisions like this.

In the DLC, you get a MECHA-SUIT with TELEKINETIC POWERS that can PICK UP TANKS AND THROW THEM AT HELICOPTERS.

If none of these things interest you, don't buy Just Cause 3. 

If they do, buy it. Now. You owe it to yourself.

With over 1000 km2, there is honestly too much space. Honestly I love my open world games, but I like them to full of shit to do like in Far Cry 3 and 4, plenty of space to run around while also having plenty of things to keep the player occupied. Unfortunately Square Enix and Avalanche missed the mark with how open the world should be but still made it fun and enjoyable, hijacking tanks to turn it against hostiles, flying bombers that allow you to run a fade on some of the bases and outposts, an arsenal of weapons that would make the American military blush, memorable characters like Mario, Dimah, Theo, and Anika, with the two faced Sheldon returning once more to stir the pot, it feels and plays like a JC entry, sure it's buggy but the bugs I've found have allowed me to, surprisingly enough, become more immersed. An example I'll use is when assaulting Griphon, a plane that tried to take off crashed into a fuel tank simply because I was running along the runway and the pathfinding essentially panicked, another example was when taking Tridente, I had reprogrammed the SAM sites to take care of enemy air support which happened to be interceptors/fighters. the SAM's constant volley of missiles forced the pathfinding to once again panic. Two of the 5 jets crashed into each other, another slammed into a corvette, and the remaining 2 got shot down by the SAM's making it feel like an actual breakdown on the battlefield where the sole objective of the ai in those jets was to survive.

This game may have it's downs, but it also has its many ups, whether on purpose or not.

JC3 - first impressions

The title may be misleading because at this point I've played 7-8 hours or something, but here is my review!

This game is amazing. Eight years old, and I bought it on a wim for $3. Let me tell you, this is worth more than full price. The main draw is the destruction and gunplay, but the movement is one of my favorites ever (fr!). The vehicles are good (although turn sensitivity is way down?) and complaints about them just show that the player isn't used to them. 

The weapons are great, but my favorite pastime is planting bombs on bridges, waiting for the enemies to chase me over,  and sending them plummeting to their doom. Or that without enemies. 

The story is a big draw, and all the characters are well made and funny. The game will run well on a system from the last five years, but it is automatically set to 720p. The environments can seem tedious (similar scenery) but it's action packed. 

If you are wrestling with JC3 or JC4, go with 3. It's a more solid game

Good game, but the "specs" you need to play this without it crashing or running poorly are very misleading.

Performance is very bad. See "PERFORMANCE"

That said it is a fun game [i] when it works [/i] and I have more hours than Steam has logged. Yes, you know what to expect when someone says there is a discrepancy between the hours Steam is logging and how long they play the game: the game has some serious software flaws and you may be unlucky enough to encounter them!

But the upside is that I can play the game with my brother, and I can't be too hard on games that support co-op or multiplayer. Especially not when you can have a lot of fun! It's a shame that fun can get interrupted by a litany of bugs.

-- PERFORMANCE SECTION --

First off, I'd like to say I play this game at 2560x1080 (2560x1440 [1440P] is the reference resolution I use).

I can tell you this game runs mysteriously bad on better hardware like a GTX 1650, RX 480, 2060, etc. -- fact is that on max this game ain't play well with those cards that have less than 8GB VRAM and maybe ones that aren't recent.

 On all the GPUs mentioned above the framerate was inconsistent, there was terrible stuttering, and other issues that plagued the game. The performance is very, very bad if you have a lower-end GPU. I thought maybe it was just me, but if I am testing 6 different configs with GPUs under 6GB of VRAM and they all suck hard at playing the game, I think it's safe to conclude the performance and specs are misleading.

It's not until you get a GPU around the power of a RX 6600 that you can get a stutter-free experience with minimal frame drops (virtually none) suggesting it may be extremely poor VRAM handling. This game also needs a patch to fix some bugs, but it doesn't seem like the devs care or will ever update it so we gonna handle these issues without them.

There are several problems with this game, which is a real shame.  Just Cause 2 was incredibly fun.  But the only word I have to describe this game is "janky".  It's a terrible port.  Some of the controls simply refuse to rebind, no matter what you do.  Even trying to manually rebind them using a keybind.txt file that they have in the system files doesn't work.  For example, if you rebind anything to Mouse2, you can't set remote explosives anymore.  
Not to mention, I felt like I was wrestling with the game every second.  Like on the wingsuit - you press left adjust your position.  Nothing happens.  You press it a little more.  It starts BARELY turning you to the left.  Then you suddenly lurch to the left, nearly rolling over, and you more or less fall out of the sky.  I'm fine with there being some nuance to the control, but this is insane.  The vehicles aren't much better.  I've tried playing this with a controller, but it doesn't help much.

Just Cause 3 is a chaotic and action-packed open-world game that thrives on over-the-top stunts and explosive gameplay. With its vast open-world environment, grappling hook mechanics, and arsenal of destructive weapons, it offers a thrilling and exhilarating experience. Here's a concise review highlighting its pros, cons, gameplay, and overall quality.

Pros:

Massive open-world: Just Cause 3 presents players with a vast and beautiful open-world environment filled with diverse landscapes, cities, and military bases to explore and wreak havoc in.
Grappling hook mechanics: The grappling hook is a central gameplay mechanic, allowing players to traverse the environment with ease, perform impressive stunts, and create chaotic and explosive scenarios.
Destructive weaponry and vehicles: Just Cause 3 provides a wide variety of weapons and vehicles, ranging from assault rifles and rocket launchers to helicopters and fighter jets, enabling players to unleash mayhem in creative ways.
Cons:

Repetitive missions: While the game offers numerous missions and objectives, some players may find that the missions can become repetitive in structure and objectives, lacking depth and variety.
Technical issues: Just Cause 3 has been criticized for occasional technical issues, including frame rate drops, long loading times, and minor glitches, which can affect the overall immersion and enjoyment of the game.
Gameplay:
In Just Cause 3, players take on the role of Rico Rodriguez, a skilled operative on a mission to liberate his homeland from a ruthless dictator. The game encourages players to embrace chaos and destruction by combining the use of the grappling hook, parachute, and various weapons to engage in high-octane action, complete missions, and free territories from enemy control.

Quality:
Just Cause 3 boasts impressive visuals, vibrant environments, and satisfying explosions that contribute to the game's overall quality. While the technical issues can be a drawback, the game still delivers a fun and entertaining experience with its explosive gameplay and vast open-world playground.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 offers an adrenaline-fueled and explosive open-world adventure with its massive environment, grappling hook mechanics, and destructive weaponry. While the repetitive missions and technical issues may dampen the experience, the game's overall quality, chaotic gameplay, and freedom to create chaos make it a worthwhile choice for fans of action-packed open-world games.

Overall Rating: 8/10

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Playing JC3 right after finishing Far Cry 6 made it clear just how many similarities the two titles have. This is like a faster-paced arcade version of Far Cry with broken physics and a forkload of big explosions.

Halfway through, I was a happy camper and would have rated the game 80%, and planned to liberate all the regions. Then a couple of broken game mechanics came into focus and changed my mind.

As you get better at controlling the crazy movements you can accomplish with the grappling hook combined with the wingsuit, you become a target that's very hard to corner and hit for your enemies. As you progress through the game, the difficulty is obviously supposed to escalate. The devs apparently didn't have the brains to come up with anything better than giving your enemies 100% aimbot aim from any distance, regardless of what weapon they wield, along with an absolutely ridiculous spawn algorithm.

For instance, the split second you enter their awareness sphere, they can hit you from miles away with anti-aircraft guns, even though you're whizzing through the air in your wingsuit. You can run through a town fighting enemies on foot, but the instant there's a line of sight to an enemy warship a mile out at sea, it WILL hit you with a cannon.

But the overshadowing problem for me is the super-aggressive enemy spawn algorithm. Enemy soldiers and vehicles will spawn as close as 10 meters from you anywhere outside of your field of view where there is no obstructing object. You can be all alone, with nothing in your proximity apart from one soldier. As soon as he becomes aware of your presence, you'll get five aimbot soldiers right behind you, filling you with lead. You can look up to spot a chopper, and as you look back down to the ground, there are suddenly two jeeps and a tank full of soldiers right in front of you. I mean... COME. ON.!

One of the key elements for me in an FPS is having situational awareness - knowing where your enemies are and responding accordingly. That's absolutely worthless here! You end up hardly bothering to engage in gunfights and instead solely focus on quickly grappling yourself around the enemy bases and destroying the target buildings to accomplish the liberation objective. The gameplay loop became frustrating and unsatisfying for me.

Having lost enjoyment of the base liberation objectives, I took the straight route to finish the story campaign. What an underwhelming boss fight.

My overall verdict is 65% - I did get something like 10-15 very enjoyable hours of gaming here, but the second half of the playthrough was a chore.

I love this game
It's simply an amazing and super satisfying sandbox game, where the more you destroy, the more you enjoy

-Destroy a whole military base
-Fly away

I fucking love this game. So endlessly satisfying.

But sometimes it is a royal annoyance to play. When it works, you feel like a god of destruction, perfectly coordinated and able to take on any obstacle with infinite fun toys at your disposal. However, there are a lot of little frustrations that make this game unplayable sometimes.

-Slow controls. There is often a lot of lag in responding to input. Land in water with enemies firing at you? Well, you'll have to wait a moment and press for a second before you dive. Transitioning from a jump to firing to grappling just takes a little too long, so Rico feels less agile than in previous games.
-No controls: no crouching, sprinting, etc. Despite breaking out controls into categories (on foot, in plane, in helicopter) setting changes are global (I.E. you're stuck with the same weapons controls on plane, helicopter, and vehicle). Rico has less movement at his disposal, despite new features such as the wingsuit.
-Broken features. You can't use the large transport plane because it can't take off or land at most runways. Blow up said transport plane trying to use it? Prepare to wait 30 minutes to drop another. Some weapons with single-shot mags don't reload automatically.
-Grapple errors. Why does Rico get stuck on intermediate objects? Why can't you unstick yourself from a wall without taking 2 seconds to jump UP (I.E. just hop onto the ground if you're right above it)? Why does going straight to a grapple from parachute sometimes fail? Why is grappling on vehicles like the train so prone to error?
-Enemy AI. Enemies spawn endlessly, and without a good way to protect yourself and with awkward 3rd person combat mechanics, taking a base on foot often means suffering multiple deaths.

The only way to enjoy this game is by disabling network access via Windows Firewall. Otherwise, your play session is constantly interrupted with leader board popups like "GnarlyGenitals55 beat your head shot high score".

How to disable network access for JC3:
- On Windows 10, open start menu and search "firewall", launch on "Windows Defender Firewall".
- From the right side panel, click on "Allow an app or feature through Windows Defender Firewall"
- Click the button labeled "Change settings" with the Shield icon.
- Scroll thru the "Allowed apps and features" frame until you find "JustCause3.exe"
- If you don't see "JustCause3.exe", click the button labeled "Allow another app...", and navigate to the exe (find it in folder "$steam-install-dir/steamapps/common/Just Cause 3"
- Uncheck the left-most checkbox in the "Allowed apps and features" frame to disable network access.

That should disable leaderboard popups; otherwise, disabling your network adapter should work too.

I love this game so god damn much. I first played it years ago when I still was a kid and I had a lot of nostalgia when I decided to replay this masterpiece. Tho, unlike when I was a kid, I actually had some skills and completed the entire game and all of its achievements.

So let's first talk about the challenges. I have mixed feelings about some of the challenges. Some of them are very fun, while others are a huge pain in the ass (Laguna Blast). And like I said earlier, I got all the achievements, so I had to get five gears in all the challenges of the game.

Now let's talk about the gameplay. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. Fun. No, but seriously, this game is the most fun game that I've ever played. You can do anything in this game. It's even better if you play with friends with the multiplayer mod.

Now the story. I'll be honest, it kinda sucks.

Oh yeah, this game also has a great soundtrack that is very nostalgic to me.

Pros: 
-Beautiful and smooth open world
-Many various weapons, vehicles, and secrets/collectibles
-Decent if not cliche story
-Parachute
-Grappling hook
-Wingsuit
-Jetpack (w/ DLC)
-Pilotable mechs with punching arms (w/ DLC)
-The ability to tether things together at ever increasing velocity
-Grappling onto a moving jet and then skydiving off it as it explodes
-Explosions are really satisfying
-50+ hours in and i'm barely done

Cons: 
-Enemies are ridiculously accurate. It's broken to the point where not even gliding in a wingsuit/grappling to and fro is enough to dodge most enemy fire, and there is no cover/running/dodge/crouch mechanic to speak of, though why would you need that when you are basically a super hero, right? ...Eh. It gets really punishing, especially mid-late game where there are only enemies on roads and any mook that you can't kill fast enough will keep calling in reinforcements until the 5 star threat level is reached and all you wanna do is tether two baddies together at mach 3 for the laughs. It's a balance thing to compensate for the fact that you almost always have the advantage with the chaos you can cause, but sometimes it doesn't feel like it when you can barely stick a pinkie finger out from a corner before getting aimbotted to death no matter what you are doing.

-Half the vehicles in the game are inherently useless and a chore to even drive, such as motorcycles that slide all over the place and the awkward camera that leans with you when you turn, and this is perpetuated when the game forces you to use the crappy vehicles in the race challenges that rely solely on SPEED.

-Dead multiplayer

It's probably worth $20 despite those cons, still. I was late to the party, but I don't regret anything. It will keep you occupied for a good while if you're waiting for games like Cyperpunk 2077 or Baldur's Gate 3 to finally become playable, and even then, it's a solid game in it's own right; the best of the franchise. Don't get Just Cause 4. Just... don't. Buy this and be entertained by a big budget action movie-style game.
