An Explosive Open-World Playground
MEDICIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIII

Rating: ★★★★☆

Review:

Just Cause 3 is a thrilling and action-packed open-world adventure that embraces chaos and offers players a sandbox of destruction and mayhem. With its expansive map, versatile gameplay mechanics, and explosive set pieces, it delivers an exhilarating experience that fans of the series have come to love.

One of the standout features of Just Cause 3 is the massive and beautifully realized world of Medici. The Mediterranean-inspired setting is a joy to explore, with diverse landscapes ranging from sun-soaked beaches to towering mountains. The sheer scale of the map, combined with a wide variety of vehicles and traversal options, ensures that players always have new adventures waiting around every corner.

The gameplay mechanics in Just Cause 3 are a true highlight. The protagonist Rico Rodriguez's signature grappling hook and wingsuit combo provide an unmatched sense of freedom and mobility. The ability to seamlessly traverse the environment, combine grappling hook tethers for creative stunts, and unleash chaos with an impressive arsenal of weapons and explosives is immensely satisfying.

The destructible environments in Just Cause 3 take the action to new heights. Blowing up bridges, toppling statues, and bringing down entire military bases offer a visceral and explosive experience. The game embraces the spirit of wanton destruction, allowing players to approach missions and challenges with a wide range of creative and destructive strategies.

The visual design of Just Cause 3 is vibrant and captivating, with lush environments and stunning vistas. The attention to detail in the world's architecture, foliage, and weather effects adds to the immersive experience. It's a visual treat to witness the chaos unfold amidst the picturesque landscapes of Medici.

While Just Cause 3 shines in terms of gameplay and visuals, the story and character development take a backseat. The narrative serves as a backdrop for the action rather than a driving force, and the characters often feel underdeveloped. However, this does not detract significantly from the enjoyment of the game, as the focus primarily lies on the explosive gameplay and open-world exploration.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 delivers an adrenaline-fueled experience that thrives on chaos and destruction. The vast open world, versatile gameplay mechanics, and explosive set pieces provide countless hours of thrilling entertainment. If you're looking for an action-packed adventure that encourages creative mayhem and offers a visually stunning playground, Just Cause 3 is the game for you. Prepare to unleash chaos and embark on an unforgettable journey through the explosive world of Medici.

Title: Explosive Fun and a Compelling Story - Just Cause 3 Review

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Just Cause 3 is a thrilling open-world action-adventure game that brings together a captivating story and an absolute blast of gameplay. From its explosive action sequences to its vast and beautiful landscapes, the game offers an exhilarating experience that will keep players hooked from start to finish.

One of the standout aspects of Just Cause 3 is the sheer amount of fun it delivers. The game places players in the shoes of Rico Rodriguez, a charismatic protagonist known for his audacious stunts and mastery of all things explosive. The freedom to wreak havoc and create chaos in the fictional Mediterranean island of Medici is unparalleled. Whether it's soaring through the air with the aid of Rico's iconic grappling hook and parachute combo or causing mayhem with a vast arsenal of weapons and vehicles, Just Cause 3 offers an abundance of creative and explosive possibilities.

The game's open-world environment is a playground for destruction, allowing players to engage in breathtaking stunts, daring vehicle chases, and intense gunfights. The mechanics of tethering objects together with the grappling hook provide endless opportunities for inventive and explosive action, making every encounter a unique and thrilling experience. The level of destruction and chaos players can unleash is simply awe-inspiring and contributes to the sheer joy and satisfaction derived from playing Just Cause 3.

While the gameplay alone would be enough to make this game stand out, Just Cause 3 also manages to weave an engaging and surprisingly compelling story into the experience. The narrative revolves around Rico's mission to liberate Medici from the oppressive rule of General Di Ravello. The story unfolds through a series of missions and cinematic sequences, and while it may not be the deepest or most profound narrative, it successfully keeps players invested in Rico's journey and provides enough motivation to keep pushing forward.

Furthermore, the voice acting and character development are commendable, adding depth to the world and creating a sense of attachment to the cast of characters Rico encounters throughout his adventure. The interactions and banter between characters inject moments of humor and humanity into the game, enhancing the overall experience and making it more memorable.

Visually, Just Cause 3 is stunning. The sprawling Mediterranean landscapes, picturesque coastal towns, and lush forests are beautifully rendered, creating a visually appealing backdrop for the chaos and destruction that unfolds. The attention to detail, combined with the game's vibrant color palette, contributes to an immersive and visually satisfying experience.

Just Cause 3 is an outstanding game that excels in both its gameplay and storytelling. Its ability to deliver exhilarating and explosive action is unmatched, providing players with endless hours of fun and excitement. The compelling story, combined with memorable characters and breathtaking visuals, further enhances the overall experience. With its perfect balance of chaos, freedom, and an engaging narrative, Just Cause 3 is an absolute must-play for fans of open-world games and action enthusiasts alike.

This game is fantastic. They fixed every issue I had with just cause 2 and improved the game in every conceivable way.
You no longer have to choose between an explosive and a primary weapon.
No ammo? - Now theres an ammo dump at every settlement
Slow map navigation? -  wingsuit. Still too slow?  Rocket wingsuit
Tedious settlement clearing? -  fewer but larger and more complex settlements with clearing objectives marked on the map.
grungy boring looking environments?  Not any more, welcome to the Mediterranean
Boring small explosions? - Giant explosions, with lighting bloom
Pointless zipline attachment function? Now it can reel in and you can attach engine mines to stuff. Its wild.

Its all action with no restrictions. 

Its not perfect though. There are some..... I wouldnt call them bugs exactly, but certain objectives require you to cause mayhem within the borders of a police station and multiple times I ran out of things to shoot, so I ended up having to go raise my heat level elsewhere and aggro the enemies over to objective. The game also crashed on me a couple of times, and I had an odd issue where it never wanted to save my fullscreen setting, so any time I would aim down I'd end up clicking my start bar. But those issues are minor. 

That being said the game is excellent.

Having played every installment of the Just Cause series, I can confidently say that Just Cause 3 is a high-octane masterpiece. With its unparalleled freedom, explosive action, and visually stunning open world, it takes the franchise to new heights. Whether you're wreaking havoc with creative stunts or engaging in adrenaline-fueled missions, Just Cause 3 delivers an exhilarating experience that is unmatched. Prepare to unleash epic chaos in a thrilling sandbox adventure!
Good

Just Cause 3 is an exhilarating action game that not only satisfies your thirst for high-octane gameplay but also grants you the freedom to soar through the skies with unparalleled joy. As an avid gamer who appreciates both intense action sequences and the thrill of flight, Just Cause 3 was an absolute delight.

One of the standout features of this game is the seamless integration of action-packed gameplay with an open-world environment. The vast Mediterranean-inspired island of Medici serves as the backdrop for your daring escapades, and it's an absolute playground for mayhem. With a wide range of explosive weapons and gadgets at your disposal, you'll find countless opportunities to wreak havoc on military outposts, blow up bridges, and engage in thrilling vehicle chases.

However, it's the ability to take to the skies that truly sets Just Cause 3 apart from other action games. The introduction of the wing suit adds a whole new dimension to the gameplay, allowing you to effortlessly glide through the air, perform death-defying stunts, and execute precision attacks from above. The feeling of freedom as you navigate the stunning landscapes while performing incredible aerial acrobatics is simply unmatched.

The graphics in Just Cause 3 are nothing short of breathtaking. The lush, vibrant environments are filled with intricate details, from dense forests and shimmering lakes to sprawling cities and towering mountains. The attention to detail in both the landscapes and the character models is commendable, further immersing you in this explosive world.

While Just Cause 3 shines in terms of gameplay and visuals, it does have a few minor drawbacks. Occasionally, the frame rate can drop during intense moments with a lot of explosions and chaotic action, which can momentarily disrupt the otherwise smooth experience. Additionally, the story, while serviceable, may not be as engaging or memorable as some other aspects of the game.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 is a must-play for anyone who craves action and a thrilling flying experience. It successfully combines a vast open-world environment, explosive gameplay mechanics, and the exhilaration of flying, creating a truly immersive and unforgettable adventure. Despite a few minor technical hiccups and a somewhat forgettable story, the game's strengths easily outweigh its weaknesses. Strap on your wing suit, buckle up, and get ready to unleash chaos like never before in Just Cause 3.

Just Cause 3 is a game that provides an exhilarating open-world experience filled with explosive action and moments of sheer freedom. As a player who craves adrenaline-pumping adventures, I have had a mixed experience with the game. While it delivers on its promise of chaotic fun and breathtaking stunts, it also suffers from some notable flaws that can detract from the overall enjoyment.

Let's start with the positive aspects of Just Cause 3. The game's vast open world is a playground for destruction and exploration. The sheer scale and variety of environments, from sprawling cities to breathtaking landscapes, create a sense of wonder and encourage exploration. The grapple hook and parachute mechanics provide a unique and enjoyable way to traverse the terrain, allowing for seamless transitions between soaring through the air and engaging in high-octane gunfights on the ground.

Additionally, Just Cause 3 offers a wide array of tools and vehicles to wreak havoc with, ranging from tanks and helicopters to boats and fighter jets. The freedom to approach missions and challenges in multiple ways gives players a sense of agency and encourages experimentation. The explosions, destruction, and over-the-top action set pieces create thrilling and memorable moments that can leave you on the edge of your seat.

However, it's important to address the game's shortcomings. Just Cause 3 suffers from notable performance issues and technical glitches, especially on lower-end systems. Framerate drops, occasional crashes, and long loading times can disrupt the immersion and hinder the overall experience. While these issues may not detract from the core gameplay, they are noticeable and can be frustrating.

Furthermore, the game's story and mission structure fall flat compared to its gameplay mechanics. The narrative feels generic and fails to engage on a deeper level. Missions often boil down to repetitive tasks that lack variety and fail to offer meaningful challenges. This lack of depth in the storytelling and mission design can leave players wanting more substance and purpose behind their actions.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 delivers on its promise of explosive chaos and moments of thrilling freedom. The open world, versatile mechanics, and breathtaking stunts create an exhilarating experience that can be immensely enjoyable. However, the game's technical issues and lackluster story and mission design are notable drawbacks that may diminish the overall experience. If you're seeking a wild and action-packed adventure, Just Cause 3 has plenty to offer, but be prepared for its shortcomings along the way.

Have you ever noticed how those games with severe gameplay issues are the ones that somehow end up with a significant price reduction?  Duh.  I paid $30, half price for this game and feel I should have waited for a better sale. Better yet, I should have paid attention to the many negative reviews from my fellow gamers. What’s really sad is that somewhere hiding within is a great game. 

The gameplay mechanics are typical of console ports; they’re like threading a needle with a pair of plyers and a vise.  It's probably just me but I don’t recall JC2 being anywhere near this difficult to play.  For example, it’s too easy to end up in grappling hook h311 during those heavy action sequences.  During one of the missions, “Abandon Ship” the absurdly poor AI has the character “Mario,” whom the object is to protect, is out walking in the middle of the firefight waiting to get whacked. During this time you’re evading airstrikes, shooting down helicopters, etc.  You’re half a second from mission completion and wham, Mario dies …or worse the game’s well-documented memory leak takes hold and crashes the game completely.  Once that happens, the player is forced to replay the mission from the beginning since there is no built-in resume checkpoint feature.  Didn’t any of the developers test their product?  

The game's map is a couple steps up from useless.  The map should give the player all they need in terms of status, potential targets and so on.  Nope, the player is forced to turd hunt in order to "discover" said targets.  

I'll say it again, I should have paid attention to this game's less than stellar reviews.

My rig: built PC, Windows 10 Pro, i5-4690K, 16Gig Ram, GTX970, Gaming 7 MSI board.

Update: May 28, 2023.  

Here it is almost 7 years later and I just finished playing this game and everything I said above still holds.  I’m now up-voting the game since it cost $20 and it seems a decent price even with the well-documented runtime issues, i.e., he game still crashes randomly.  I ran the game with a 64 Gig, 8700K PC and had MSI Afterburner running.  I’m still running the same ole GTX 970.  I really didn’t see much evidence of a memory leak during a crash.  The event viewer of course says very little.  Usually the game would crash once and sometimes twice a session. 

I downloaded a buggy grapple hook mod that created as many problems as it solved.  I suggest buying this game, better on sale, but know ahead of time it can be frustrating and challenging due to crashes.

I've been playing Just Cause 3 for 36 hours now, and I have to say that I'm really enjoying it. The game is a lot of fun, and it's very easy to get lost in the world. The graphics are also very good, and the game runs smoothly on my PC.

Here are some of the things that I've enjoyed about Just Cause 3:

The open-world is massive and beautiful. There's so much to explore, and I've found myself getting lost in the world for hours on end.
The game-play is fun and varied. There's a lot of different things to do in the game, and I've never gotten bored.
The weapons and vehicles are awesome. There's a huge variety of weapons and vehicles to choose from, and they're all a lot of fun to use.
The destruction is satisfying. I love blowing things up in Just Cause 3, and the destruction is always satisfying.
The story is cheesy but enjoyable. The story is a bit cheesy, but it's still enjoyable. I've found myself laughing out loud at some of the dialogue.
Overall, I would highly recommend Just Cause 3 to anyone who enjoys open-world action-adventure games. It's a lot of fun to play, and it's sure to keep you entertained for hours on end.

Here are some additional thoughts that I have about the game:

The grappling hook is one of the best features in the game. It allows you to do all sorts of crazy things, like grapple onto a helicopter and then swing it into a building.
The wing-suit is also a lot of fun to use. It allows you to fly through the air and perform all sorts of stunts.
The game is very forgiving. If you make a mistake, you can usually just try again. This makes it a lot of fun to experiment with different things.
If you're looking for a game that will let you blow stuff up and have fun, then Just Cause 3 is definitely worth checking out.

I don't know what's changed since I last played this but I remember having a good time. Was it just the novelty of my first playthrough? Maybe...

As the game is now, though, it is buggy in the extreme, with frequent graphical hitches. That's a shame, because otherwise it is a very beautiful game with beautiful explosions, but that doesn't mean a thing if the game will freeze up every few seconds.

Likewise, I remember the game being fun but now I'm asking myself why I ever thought that. Every base is the same, in essence. The only real differences being how many red themed volatile objects you need to obliterate before the game goes "you win!" The brief couple of hours I played recently were just...dull...which is an odd thing to say about a game where you fly around in a wingsuit attaching bombs to stuff.

Also, for gameplay issues, the pop in is disgusting. I've literally turned around and seen enemies manifest out of the ether, so I felt no shame whenever the game would surprise me with a sudden Tank/Helo/Gunboat assassination.

Finally, in the vein of gameplay...your character moves like garbage. You slow to a crawl on boats. You can drop from orbit and survive if you grapple to the ground but god forbid you hit a branch in your wingsuit. Most importantly, the grapple was problematic. It was as if I'd select where I want to grapple, but the game would decide that what I wanted  was whatever was in the way instead, which is kind of annoying, ramming feet first into gas cans in the middle of a firefight.

Glitches, inconsistent physics, offensive amounts of enemy pop-in and, most vitally, a lack of simple enjoyment. Like I said, I remember my first playthrough being enjoyable but, now? No. I was not having fun.

Anyway, great game, solid 8.9/10. The amount of bases are just enough I believe, comparing to JC2 that had like 50 repetitive locations, the story missions offers a great range of challenges and minigames that makes the game very diverse, but it appears only in mission, so that's a bummer.

 The other challenges, like the wingsuit, destruction and race are a good addition too, contributing to the unique mechanic of getting perks for the reward.

The DLC adds more story, and more things to play with, such as mechs, jetwings, an OP boat. If you do pick up those DLC, I suggest you do it later, as it really makes the game (and its missions) easier to beat, unless you really want to speedrun this game, which I did lol

Overall, solid game and probably the best in this series (never played JC4, but judging by reviews, its not better). Pick up the XXL edition during a sale as it's very cheap for a quality 5 year+ game.

Overall a good game, probably one of my favourites.

The port to PC was clearly not given enough care, though, as there are still references to console features such as aim assist. There is also a bug that prevents homing missiles from actually homing when you have Precision Aim enabled.

The story is decent for what it's worth, about what you'd expect – it's not a major component of what makes the game interesting.

The gameplay manages to remain fun for entirety of the game. I thought it would have been fun for a bit and then become boring, but no.

The game looks great in my opinion, and I never saw an area that looked like it lacked detail.

I would definitely recommend giving it a try, especially if you can get it on sale.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

Title: A Thrilling and Explosive Masterpiece: Just Cause 3 Delivers Unforgettable Fun!

Rating: ★★★★★

Just Cause 3 is an absolute triumph of open-world gaming that manages to raise the bar for the entire genre. From the moment I stepped foot into the sprawling island paradise of Medici, I was completely blown away by the sheer scale, freedom, and exhilaration that this game offers. It is an adrenaline-fueled adventure that kept me hooked from start to finish, leaving me with an insatiable hunger for more.

Let's start with the breathtaking visuals. The stunning landscapes of Medici are a sight to behold, ranging from sun-soaked beaches to towering snow-capped mountains. The attention to detail is exceptional, and the vibrant colors make every corner of the map come alive. Whether you're skydiving from an aircraft or speeding through the lush forests in a high-powered sports car, the visuals never fail to impress.

But Just Cause 3 isn't just about eye candy; it's about delivering pure, unadulterated fun. The gameplay mechanics are a pure joy to experience. The grappling hook and parachute combination is a stroke of genius, allowing you to effortlessly traverse the vast open world with an unmatched sense of freedom. The fluidity of movement and the ability to seamlessly switch between different gadgets and weapons make every encounter a sandbox of destruction and creativity.

Speaking of destruction, the chaos and mayhem that Just Cause 3 offers are nothing short of mind-blowing. The game grants you access to an awe-inspiring arsenal of explosive weaponry and vehicles, each designed to wreak havoc in its own unique way. Whether you're sending enemy bases crumbling to the ground with a well-placed rocket launcher or tethering objects together to create absurdly satisfying chain reactions, the possibilities for destruction are endless. Just Cause 3 rewards creativity and experimentation, and I found myself constantly discovering new and entertaining ways to obliterate everything in sight.

The missions and challenges are both varied and engaging. The main story missions strike a perfect balance between high-octane action and compelling storytelling, filled with memorable characters and plot twists that kept me invested in Rico Rodriguez's quest to liberate Medici from the oppressive regime. Side missions and challenges offer a fantastic distraction from the main storyline, providing a wealth of activities to partake in, from daring wingsuit races to liberating outposts with your own unique flair.

The audio design in Just Cause 3 is also worth applauding. The soundtrack perfectly complements the game's exhilarating gameplay, delivering an adrenaline-pumping experience that immerses you deeper into the chaos. From the rumble of explosions to the satisfying thump of gunfire, every sound effect feels satisfying and impactful, adding an extra layer of immersion to the overall experience.

Furthermore, the game offers exceptional replay value. Even after completing the main campaign and side missions, I found myself constantly revisiting Medici to experiment with new strategies, unlock hidden secrets, and engage in spontaneous bouts of destruction for the sheer thrill of it. The world of Just Cause 3 is so vast and rich with content that there is always something new to discover and enjoy.

In conclusion, Just Cause 3 is an extraordinary game that sets a new standard for open-world action and adventure. Its explosive gameplay, stunning visuals, and unmatched sense of freedom make for an unforgettable experience that will keep you entertained for hours on end. Whether you're a fan of the series or a newcomer to the franchise, Just Cause 3 is an absolute must-play. Strap on your wingsuit, buckle up in your favorite vehicle, and get ready for an adventure that will leave you exhilarated and begging for more.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Kind of incredible. A beautiful open world with loads of structures to destroy, endless soldiers to engage in firefights with, and some of the best mobility I've felt in an open world game. Forget GTA, Just Cause is where it's at.

The grapple hook, parachute, and new wingsuit are AMAZING. You feel like a mix of Spiderman, Batman, and a flying squirrel. Once you learn to cancel your grapplehook mid-pull to stay midair and readjust, and master the wingsuit's realistic weight and momentum, you feel amazing. The wingsuit is genuinely one of the best mobility options I've ever had the pleasure of controlling in a videogame.

There's many cars, scooters, helicopters, planes, and water vehicles to drive around (and eventually crash.) They handle MUCH better than GTA. 

The story isn't the main draw of the game, it's a bit ridiculous and cheesy, but I was actually kind of surprised by some of the characters and more serious scenes they managed pulled off. Rico is less cut-throat and more chill, love his new look. The dictator is a genuinely captivating presence with blunt and brutal tactics. Even the scientist lady, while your typical awkward bustling scientist, starts to grow on you and has a surprising conclusion. I was shocked to hear David Tennant as the compelled government propaganda radio host lol.

Only major criticism is we're missing some tactical options from Just Cause 2. There's no run, roll, or hanging onto cars, now you can only stand on top of them. It kinda sucks and makes combat feel less deep, but we now have better grappling and the wingsuit, so maybe that makes up for it. Not a deal breaker, but I do miss those options.

As well, the map isn't quite as good as Just Cause 2. JC2's map was a massive tropical continent with snowy mountains in the middle, a great city to the east, and a great desert to the south. JC3 has 2 island regions in the south, and a larger continent in the north, with small desert regions and snowy mountains within it. It's not as interconnected or varied as JC2's world was. Not saying JC3's is outright bad, but it's not "as" good. Just a small thing to be aware of. It's still plenty of space to rampage and fly around in.

If you have the chance to get JC3, the wingsuit and grapple are great!

First of all, this is my opinion so no need to cancel me.
I think that Just Cause 3 is the best game yet in the franchise,
Many reasons like:
-Very interactive world.
-Gear mods
-Story was good, wouldn't say it was better than Just Cause 2's story, but good nonetheless.
-Rebel drop was a great feature as well.
-Best graphics in the series arguably.
-Many things to do after you complete the game.
-Loved the fact that you could fight and free regions as you went.
And many other things.
Cons:
-Fast travel was a nuisance, unlike Just Cause 2 where you could fast travel at anytime to any discovered locations, you had to have flares. You needed to unlock gear mods to get the number of flares up to 5, otherwise you could light up all rebel shrines to unlock infinite fast travel, which while a great feature is still a pretty big nuisance.
-Car handling was worse than GTA 4's car handling.

When i bought this i expected to play maybe 40 or 50h, and after 240 hours, on my fifth playthrough I beat the game to 100% completion. If you're on the fence about action games, this is IMO the best game to start with. The story is quite engaging and the charachters are well written, and for a game this old the graphics are stunning and even on my sub par PC can run the game at a smooth 60fps. The main point of the game is blowing stuff up and boy does it feel great. There is also a lot of vareity to destruction, you can shoot, grapple, Drive into things, Blow up with rocket launchers, grenade launchers, helicopters, tanks, bombs, mounted explosives and grenades. You can even call in an air strike* or shoot a god damn nukes at things*. The combat in this game is also really dynamic, and don't even get me started on the movement because that is the stuff. Of course as with everything there are flaws, some chalanges are unreasonably difficult requiring either extreme percition or luck (or both) to get the perfect score, but unless you are a masochist like me and you are trying to get the legendary 100% completion those challanges can just be skipped. The biggest issue IMO are the glitches, because this game is really bug infested for some reason, and likes to crash, although crashes are relatively rare (once every 10-20h on average for me). Most glithes don't affect the game but some straight up prevent you from doing certain missions. But in general despite it's flaws it's a great game. 9/10

* the weapons that allow you to do that are unclocked through missions

I come back to it from time to time only to be reminded why I stopped playing it the first time. It gets boring after a few hours of game-play; the story gets boring, the same enemy structures get boring, no fun in driving vehicles because the driving mechanics are terrible, even the scenic beauty of Medici gets boring after a while. Still, the game gets the explosive action bit right, so I try to squeeze some fun out of the game but then BAM! The game starts crashing randomly (apparently because of a memory leak they haven't fixed for at least 8 years). I'm still giving it a thumbs up and recommending it, because you can still get some money's worth of game-play if you buy it on sale.
fun

Gameplay:
+ mechanics of the parachute, wingsuit and grappling hook are great
- normal vehicles not as useful (apart from just messing around)
- control of the cars is finicky (especially bikes)
+ when it comes to guns and explosions, the game excels - lots to blow up along
+ difficulty from various kinds of enemies, ramps up well
+ plenty of challenges and collectibles to improve your skills in wingsuit flying, racing, etc.  in a natural way to train you to get better instead of just progressively adding features
? I beat the main story and most collectibles first time in 23 hours or so, not 100%. Granted, I am not one to free roam, and there is plenty of easter eggs and fun ways to mess around - giving plenty of extra hours of fun.

Story:
- at a surface level and at the beginning, it's hard to find depth to the story.
- comical, ridiculous style of the game makes you not expect much
+ lore building and themes come as you collect the dictator's audio tapes
- the final boss felt somewhat anticlimactic
+ good game progression

Graphics and Sound:
+ gorgeous game - one of the few games that not only impressed me technically but also aesthetically
+ pretty explosions
+ your character animations are especially smooth
- other characters' animations fall into average.
- LOD mesh and texture popping (there are good mods online that fix this)
+ sounds and music are great, fit the environment and tone well
- loading screens take a bit sometimes, playing with a solid-state drive is recommended

Saving: I added this section because it's one of the few things I legitimately got mad about in this game. It's an autosave that works in the background as you navigate and progress.  That aspect of it works great - unnoticeable. However, despite having great Internet, the game will PAUSE ITSELF to try to reattempt to sign in if it couldn't earlier (signing in to keep track of leaderboards, DRM, etc.).  It does give an option to try being offline for a while, but the next time you pause the game, it'll reattempt to sign in.  I think this wouldn't be as big of an issue if it was fast, but it can take 10-15s to attempt to sign in and save (and this happens every time you open the game). I ended up adding a firewall so it wouldn't attempt to save online, but of course that disables social leaderboards (I personally don't care with that, but some may).

Overall: very fun game with a gorgeous world to play around in.  It's one of the best sandbox games I've played.  Apart from a few graphics and saving issues, it's very satisfying to play.

Just Cause 3, unlike most shooters, has a degree of realism to it, ignoring the fact that Rodriguez can withstand eleven or twelve bullet before he even gets close to death. In certain situations, you can't stand there tanking bullets, you have to be smart and do things you would do in real life gunfights, such as take cover behind objects and occasionally throw grenades at a cluster of enemies or explosive things, or maybe even run away.
Besides this, there are certain gear upgrades in the game that greatly improve your abilities, but you can only acquire them by performing well in Challenges, proving by your performance that you are actually worthy of them. In these ways, this game is a shooter that forces you to not only shoot at enemy, but to do it strategically, from behind cover, from the safety of an armoured tank, or with lots of rebel buddies. It forces you to think before you shoot, while you're shooting, and sometimes even after you finish shooting.

Just Cause 3 is an open-world action-adventure game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Square Enix. The game is the third installment in the Just Cause series and was released in 2015 for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One. In this review, I will share my thoughts on the game based on my experience playing it.

First and foremost, the game's world is vast and beautiful. The Mediterranean island of Medici, where the game is set, is full of breathtaking landscapes, from sandy beaches to snowy mountains. The game's graphics are stunning, and the attention to detail is impressive. The world feels alive, and there is always something to discover, whether it's a hidden cave or a military base to liberate.

The gameplay is where Just Cause 3 truly shines. The player takes on the role of Rico Rodriguez, a skilled agent tasked with overthrowing the oppressive dictatorship of General Di Ravello. The game is all about causing chaos, and there are countless ways to do so. Rico is armed with a grappling hook and a wingsuit, which allow for incredible mobility and acrobatics. The player can attach the grappling hook to nearly any surface and use it to propel themselves forward or tether objects together, creating hilarious and explosive results.

Pretty fun entry into the Just Cause franchise, though not worth it at full price. Wait for it on sale.

Do note, if you decide to pick up this game, it is VERY repetitive. Every Outpost, Base, Town; they all blend in together and rarely have distinguishing features between each other. Save for a few notable ones. Story is lackluster and predictable, trite even. Collectibles are extremely tedious as well, and I recommend you liberate an entire area before looking for them, or follow a guide. Rewards for most completions are lackluster as well. 

Where this game does shine is in the sandbox mechanics. You may be liberating tons of bases, but you can always do things a different way each time or playthrough. There's plenty of different paths you could go for each time you do liberate one. Helis, Jets, Tanks, ground vehicles; ect.. Destruction effects are satisfying as well. 

I'd recommend it if you've never played a Just Cause game as the entry game. JC1/JC2 are a bit outdated and janky. Pick this up first and play it to see if you're really into it, or watch the plethora of review videos first.

- Planting rocket powered explosives on an animal's rear end
And/or do whatever else your imagination comes up with.

Now, YES, there are more than a few "clunky" gameplay elements. But no, they definitely should NOT ruin the entire experience for you. 

Ultimately, Just Cause 3 is a LOAD of fun. And, IF you can get it on sale for a few bucks, it's totally worth it. I truly believe that you'll have as much fun as I did, if not more. Just remember not to take this game too seriously though.

Sincerely, Vulcan.

Just Cause 3 is a game that promises a lot but ultimately falls short in many areas. One of the biggest issues with the game is its repetitive gameplay. While the destruction mechanics and the open world environment initially seem exciting, it quickly becomes apparent that the missions and objectives are all very similar, offering little in the way of variety or challenge.

Another issue is its poor optimization for PC, causing frequent crashes, stuttering, and other technical issues. This can be extremely frustrating for players, especially when combined with the repetitive gameplay and lack of variety.

The story and characters are also lackluster, failing to engage the player and ultimately feeling forgettable. The dialogue is often cheesy and clichéd, and the voice acting can be grating at times.

Additionally, the game's AI is often buggy and unreliable, with enemies frequently behaving in illogical ways and making the game feel more frustrating than fun. The lack of any real difficulty curve also means that the game quickly becomes too easy and predictable.

Overall, while Just Cause 3 has some fun elements, such as the ability to create chaos and destruction in the game world, these are ultimately not enough to overcome the game's many flaws. The repetitive gameplay, technical issues, poor optimization, and lackluster story and characters all make for a frustrating and underwhelming gaming experience.

This game is 100% Party-In-A-Box.
Fast food has more substance. Porn has more depth. It's not a game that requires any special skill or presents you with any real role-playing elements. 

What this game is:
Beautiful, constant explosions, more over-the-top action than a 90's action movie, plenty of guns, lots of ammo, lots of wild means to create chaos, wild unearthly items, and lots of vehicular mayhem. 

Do you want to launch a tank through the air to attack an oil refinery? Check
Do you want to summon lightning from the sky to blow up a power plant? Check
Are you getting bored with fighting your enemies and just want to attach them to a nuclear missile instead? Check

While it is kind of lackluster without the expansions, if you get the expansions with it, it becomes what it was meant to be. It's not a game you walk away from reflecting on the story or characters. It is a game you walk away from looking out while civilization burns behind you saying "That was fun."

Just Cause 3 is an absolute blast to play! From the moment you start the game, you're thrown into an open world filled with beautiful landscapes, bustling cities, and plenty of things to blow up. The game's mechanics are incredibly smooth and intuitive, making it easy to zip around the map with your grappling hook and parachute.

The story is entertaining, with plenty of over-the-top action sequences and memorable characters. But where Just Cause 3 really shines is in its sandbox gameplay. Whether you're hijacking enemy vehicles, liberating towns from oppressive regimes, or just causing chaos for the fun of it, there's always something new and exciting to discover.

The graphics are stunning, with bright colors and gorgeous vistas that make every moment of gameplay feel like a cinematic experience. And with a huge arsenal of weapons and gadgets at your disposal, you can approach every situation in a different way.

Overall, Just Cause 3 is an incredibly fun and satisfying game that's perfect for anyone who loves action, adventure, and explosions. Highly recommended!

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him in the online mode. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and I cant wait to make future memories with my son.

Ah yes, the sweet air of Medici. Where one could cripple a government with a brand new grapple hook and a dream. Yes, this is that kind of game.
Before we start, I've already sank at least 100 hours in this game on PS4 (playing the main story twice without DLC) and I've still had a blast.

However, warning to those who are easily irritated at the smallest programme error or feature then think its the worst game in the world. (Yes that person over there in the back. Get out. Now.) This game features many bugs. Not just that but also annoying features which may annoy some depending on your opinion.

(Listed below are features that the community has agreed to be annoying. Bugs will be listed as of my discovery)

Bad Features:
- Online Leaderboards. No you can't turn this off as far as i can tell, despite an offline mode existing when it randomly disconnects.
- Limited Rebel Drops (5 max). I don't understand what the issue is when there is plenty of resupply points all over the map. Especially at outposts.
- "Tough" driving. In contrast to JC2's driving, JC3's is very limiting as most cars have weight and cannot turn when driving at high speeds.

Bugs:
- Small dirt mounds on roads
- *Some* small cliffs in Insula Striate do not load in correctly
- Lock-on system for any weapons that use it does not lock-on half the time. Causing one mission in particular to be softlocked.

Now, for DLC.
As of playing this on the PC, this is my first time playing (and using) all of the DLC within JC3.
For simplicity, the 3 campaign DLCs (Air, Land and Sea) will be reviewed.

Sky Fortress -
The best out of the three. This includes a Bavarium Wingsuit which acts as a jetpack with built-in machine guns and rockets for Rico to wreak havoc on anyone he comes across. New drones, a whole new airship between Insula Fonte and Dracon which is INCREDIBLE to fly through and liberate. And a decent storyline to boot. Plus the now permanent (and fair) balance that SAM sites will lock onto you whenever the player uses the wingsuit. Its a shame the only negative in the DLC is that all of the bases (2 for airship and 2 mining outposts) cannot be Re-oppressed if you have completed the main story.

Bavarium Sea Heist -
The middle man of the DLCs, one that ticks all of the boxes for your stereotypical heist movie. A new OP boat with near-infinite boost, a set of sea platforms to the east of Insula Dracon to liberate and...
Well let's just say you wield the power of Thor by the end of the campaign.

Mech Land Assault -
The worst of the DLCs despite its introduction of OP mechs. A mediocre campaign with little to no tension that never hooks the viewer and annoying ass eDEN outposts to takeover (I'm not lying, you'll be ripping your hair out by the time you liberate ONE). Ironically, this (and the lore of the DLCs) hints directly at the 2018 sequel; Just Cause 4

In conclusion. Is Just Cause 3 a perfect game? No. But is it the best in the series and lets the player create their own dumb fun? Absolutely.

Whilst in some ways Just Cause 2 is better, I have been finding Just Cause 3 to be just as good in it's own ways. There is plenty of fun to be had. Whilst the environment is rather bare in many ways and offers nothing of interest, it's fun to liberate bases, towns and think of creative ways to go about it. This is the heart of the gameplay beyond the fun of relaxing traversal with the wingsuit etc. 

I've found that when it comes to Just Cause, the way you have fun is by experimenting with new ways to go about the same task. Think outside the box and you'll have a lot of fun. For example, instead of shooting a weapon at one of the red tanks, drive a jet into it, or use the grappling hook tethers and smash something into it and so on. 

Whilst it's also fun and such to rain hell from above in the air, I've found that ground combat adds an additional challenge factor particularly if you use less powerful weapons against the enemy. So there is plenty of ways to enjoy the game and also add replayablility as well.

I do highly recommend the DLC content as it completes the game and really provides you with all you need to really make the most of what the game has to offer. You can still enjoy the game without it. But if you can get it all, I can say it's a wonderful addition and provides you with more ways to go about playing.

I played Just Cause 2 religiously in High School for a short period of time, and when I finally had the hardware to upgrade to 3, I was not disappointed. All told, this is exactly what I expected to find going in. This game is something of a guilty pleasure for me-- guilty not because I think it's bad to enjoy this kind of game, but because of the strange design and writing choices that give this game the energy of an old late 70s D-tier action movie. I find it perennially funny that you're "saving" the island with indiscriminate destruction of the military and infrastructure and the (all-too) occasional innocent bystander.

I recommend anyone interested in the Just Cause series start here! There's not much I can say, other than what you see is what you get. I had a lot of fun messing around, and I highly recommend taking on optional challenges you make for yourself, or approaching each location with a new strategy. My only real beef with this game is that the more cool stuff you unlock, the less you have to use it on. Overall a fun time, 7.5/10.

PC:
One of my favorite open world action games I've ever played

Steam Deck(some of these apply to the pc version):

Pros:
-Portable JC3
-if you have played this game on controller in the past its a very familiar feel.
-Your getting the full game experience
-The PC port is the definitive way to play this game and the steam deck version is the second most definitive way
Cons: 
-Performance is shaky(20-30 fps) in certain conditions on Low graphics especially on the games large island and in big military bases but can keep a solid 40 fps in most areas.
-The map is a little finicky and needs a patch
-Do not play this game with motion blur on, Especially on Steam Deck
-You need to be connected to the games online servers(DRM) once before entering the map

Conclusion: The game is really good but is in need of a steam deck patch/Definitive edition, also if you have a shakey/no  internet connection I recommend buying the game and its DLC on steam and then playing a pirated version of the game with DLC's as it skirts past the online functionality(do actually buy it as its a really good game and Embracier will hopefully fund more Just Cause games or a patch to this game in the future,)

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Just Cause 3. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

You could take the story seriously and be bored out of your mind or you could do the objectively better thing and steal helicopters with infinite missiles then blow up military bases for giggles.

Just Cause 3 is an adrenaline-fueled action game that puts you in the shoes of Rico Rodriguez, a legendary mercenary on a mission to liberate his homeland from a ruthless dictator. With a massive open world to explore, a wide variety of vehicles and weapons to utilize, and an explosive story campaign to play through, Just Cause 3 is an absolute blast from start to finish.

The game's highlight is its incredible sense of freedom and chaos. You can grapple onto any surface, parachute through the sky, and hijack any vehicle in your path, leading to endless opportunities for creative destruction and mayhem. And with a variety of challenges and missions to complete, the game always feels fresh and exciting.

The graphics and sound design are also top-notch, with a beautiful and detailed world that truly feels alive and immersive. The music and voice acting are excellent as well, helping to bring the story and characters to life.

The game also has a variety of modes and challenges to keep you coming back for more, including a new multiplayer mode that lets you team up with friends to take on challenges and wreak havoc together.

Overall, Just Cause 3 is an incredible game that delivers on all fronts. It's thrilling, explosive, and endlessly entertaining, with a great story, memorable characters, and plenty of exciting gameplay to keep you hooked for hours on end. If you're a fan of action games or open-world games, you owe it to yourself to give this one a try.

Just Cause 3 is a fantastic game that offers thrilling gameplay and an expansive open world to explore. The game's mechanics are great, with a grappling hook and wing suit that allow for unique and creative ways to traverse the environment and take down enemies. The game's story is also engaging, with a colorful cast of characters and over-the-top action set pieces that keep players on the edge of their seat.

Compared to the Far Cry franchise, Just Cause 3 offers a different kind of experience that is more focused on explosive action and destruction. The game's open world is massive and varied, with countless towns, bases, and landmarks to discover and liberate. Overall, Just Cause 3 is a must-play for fans of open-world action games, and it's a great challenger to the Far Cry franchise.

While the explosions and wing suit start the game off with a bang, it quickly becomes soulless.

The enemies never develop into anything other than a generic dictator and his army.  There's no sense of impending doom from them, no sense of a personal vendetta (the game tries for about 30 seconds to create one), there's no sense of anything, really.

Even with the plot, or lack of, the core gameplay has issues as well.  Movement and aiming is overly loose and you never truly feel like you have complete control over your character.  Everything simply feels off from grappling to aiming to driving.

So, yes, the explosions and wing suit will hold your interest at first, but soon you'll realize that you're basically doing the exact same things over and over to help characters you don't care about crush an evil leader you don't care about.  There's nothing here besides gliding and shooting things until they blow up and then you move on to the next location to do the same thing there.  This game is guilty of trying both too hard with its action and not hard enough with everything else.  It's not horrible, but there are certainly better games you can spend your time with.

A game that has had alot of issues many of them have over time been finally pressed down and dealt with. Still pretty rough around the edges at times and if you have AMD hardware or certain Nvidia cards you'll need to do some tinkering to get textures and even terrain to function right.

If you are lucky enough to NOT have those problems the game works pretty well most of the time.

Just Cause 3 is like many 3rd entries into series full of technical wonders and very fun toys. The devs over time have found what works and cut away what doesn't (for the most part). Rico usually feels responsive and easy to control if sometimes a little slow or stilted.
Namely you'll find yourself wishing he would move faster during some of his animations such as deploying the chute or when he decides to take a 5 minute nap after tripping on a rock.

on the topic of controls key board and mouse works fine but i've always liked 3rd person with a controller and while they did manage to map everything to the controller some of the choices feel...odd like using X and B (or Circle and square) to steer the rudder on planes. Sounds ok on paper but in practice takes a great deal of getting used to.

Vehicle physics in general feel a little silly, land vehicles seem to lose mass when they get airborne which makes for some funny visuals. Flying vehicles and watercraft feel fine though on the topic of transportation vehicles feel almost like a afterthought in this entry due to the tether winch, wingsuit, parachute and (if you got the DLC) jet pack giving you more options for getting around on foot than you can shake a stick at. Its not uncommon for you to end up traveling 10 clicks without stepping foot inside a vehicle and when you get a nice wingsuit run going its really fun.

Shooting feels as lackluster as it always has in the franchise. a small handful of weapons feel tight and powerful but the rest feel like clutter that you'll rarely ever use. Shotguns seem to only exist to help the enemy as when you use them they only work inside the torso of another enemy but when a guy from 2 miles away hits you with a single pellet you'll stagger.

The biggest problem you'll encounter in this title is when in the heat of combat some random piece of debris will hit you and make you slowly ragdoll to the ground, flail and then slowly get back up all the while you are most certainly being shot from a dozen sources, its obnoxious sometimes but once you've got some options of heavy duty vehicles to call in itll become just a minor annoyance.

There's a bunch of DLC for this game some of which is pretty cool but the Devs seemed WAY more interested in getting said DLC out rather than fixing and optimizing the game. Several years later with the game patched and in a good working state its a non-issue now but those of us who played shortly after release will remember the pain.

The story is blah, but this series isn't known for its spectacular story and writing (our hero says "FUCK YOU MISSILE" at one point.) Its serviceable sure but is mostly just a excuse to set up situations like jumping from a jet to a prop plane or riding a ICBM to defuse it as it enters the lower atmosphere.

If you want some fun action and lots of explosions this is probably the most interesting entry into the series, its fixed, it works and is fun to play. Grab it and all its DLC in a bundle when its on sale sometime.

I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw it - a man grinding aggressively out of a toilet and proceeding to bottle flip a tank. It all started when I was taking a break at a rest stop during a long road trip.

As I walked towards the restroom, I heard a strange noise coming from one of the stalls. It sounded like someone was struggling to break free. Curious, I pushed open the door to find a man grinding furiously out of the toilet. Without missing a beat, he stood up and walked out of the stall.

To my shock, the man then approached a nearby military tank and began to bottle flip with impressive accuracy. The tank's crew was so surprised that they exited the vehicle to watch the man's feat.

But the man's incredible display of bottle flipping was not just for entertainment. Suddenly, a group of terrorists attacked the rest stop, firing shots and throwing explosives. Without hesitation, the man used his bottle flipping skills to knock out the terrorists and save the day.

I watched in awe as the man calmly walked away from the scene, as if it was just another day in his life. I knew I had just witnessed something truly extraordinary, and I couldn't wait to share the story with my friends and family.

This game could have been a great game. But vehicle control is horrible for motorcycles, cars start to smoke on 3rd impact, explode on 5th, which is especially stupid for armored ones. No option to repair them, so fast driving is not fun - your car will explode in a couple of minutes and you will be left in the middle of nowhere. All but maybe 2-3 cars are boring to ride (either too slow or ridiculous steering). 

Combat is meh due to your and enemies auto-aiming. Weapon choice is limited, so you get used to them within a couple of hours.

Taking bases is unfortunately also gets boring quickly. It's always the same strategy - grenades for machine gunners (or you're dead), assault rifle for everyone else (not to run out of ammo). Helis and planes are mostly useless, as they always lose to SAMs (anti-air rocket launchers). And there is a ton of them on each,  so by the time you disabled all of them - you also cleared the base. Some bugs like rebels not boarding vehicle which says "accommodates up to 12 rebels" means you cannot bring a small army with you.

It looks like the (only) focus of the game is explosions, but again, after several hours you've seen them all. Then game becomes a slog

Just Cause 3 is an action-packed, open-world game that delivers a thrilling and explosive gameplay experience. The game puts you in the shoes of Rico Rodriguez, a charismatic and skilled agent on a mission to liberate the Mediterranean island of Medici from a tyrannical dictator.

One of the standout features of Just Cause 3 is its massive open world, which is filled with stunning landscapes, diverse environments, and countless opportunities for exploration and destruction. The game's mechanics allow you to use a wide range of weapons, vehicles, and gadgets to wreak havoc on the island, from skydiving and parachuting to driving fast cars and flying planes.

The game's graphics and sound design are also impressive, with stunning visuals and explosive sound effects that bring the game's world to life. The game's storyline is simple, but effective, providing a good backdrop for the game's fast-paced and action-packed gameplay.

One of the only downsides of Just Cause 3 is its lack of variety in missions, which can feel repetitive after a while. However, this is offset by the game's huge open world, which provides endless opportunities for experimentation and creativity.

Overall, Just Cause 3 is a thrilling and enjoyable game that offers a fun and immersive open-world experience. With its explosive gameplay, impressive graphics and sound design, and huge open world, it is definitely worth checking out for fans of action and open-world games.

[h1][b]Introduction[/b][/h1]
Just Cause 3 is a fantastic open-world action game that is the pinnacle of the Just Cause series. Developed by Avalanche Studios, the game takes place on the fictional Mediterranean island of Medici, where the player takes on the role of Rico Rodriguez, a skilled agent of chaos on a mission to liberate his homeland from the tyrannical rule of General Di Ravello.


[h1][b]Gameplay review - 9/10[/b][/h1]
The gameplay in Just Cause 3 is a blast. The game offers a massive open-world environment filled with a plethora of vehicles, weapons, and gadgets to cause destruction with. The core gameplay loop of liberating towns and bases is engaging, with a variety of approaches to each scenario. The standout mechanics of the game are the grappling hook and wingsuit, which provide an unparalleled level of freedom and mobility. Players can use the grappling hook to tether objects and enemies together or use it to attach themselves to buildings and launch themselves into the air. The wingsuit allows for seamless transitions between the grappling hook and gliding, allowing for endless creativity in traversing the game world.


[h1][b]Graphics review - 9/10[/b][/h1]
The graphics in Just Cause 3 are stunning. The game's tropical setting and the vibrant color palette make the game world come to life. Explosions and destruction effects look fantastic, and the attention to detail in the environment is impressive. However, the game does suffer from some performance issues on consoles, with occasional drops in frame rates and long load times.


[h1][b]Final review - 9/10[/b][/h1]
Just Cause 3 is an excellent game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys open-world action games. The gameplay is engaging and provides endless opportunities for destruction and creativity. The graphics are stunning and immersive, but the game does have some performance issues on consoles. Despite its flaws, Just Cause 3 is a must-play for anyone who wants to experience the ultimate sandbox of destruction.

So first of all, I love JC games. Third part was awesome, it had some nice details, gameplay, but it also had lots of problems, even today and when I googled it, it was years old, they just dont care to fix. Nothing major, but some stuff was pretty annoying.
Random mission around the world to unlock sanctuary etc, not working. Audio in some story missions doesnt work, also had problems with features like auto-aim on rockets or reloading a weapon. It happened after few hours of playing, I guess too much memory, simple restart fixed that.
Motorcycle driving, worst there is.
When you complete side mission, get gears, oh my god, the time you have to wait till you can press continue is extremely long.
Some challenges are broken, like driving a rigged car. When you jump out, the car will explode before hitting anything, it will hit an invisible war and its almost impossible to finish. On the other hand, some challenges were extremely easy, no challenge at all.
Too many cutscenes .. long loading, the game cant properly use all the hardware. My PC is pretty good, can run anything there is, it still took kinda long for my taste. Which reminds me, draw distance, too low. All the trees, buildings, cars, loading like 100 meters ahead of you, extremely annoying in oper world game where you can fly. When clear the whole map, destroy everything, you can still see those objects from afar, but when you come close, it will disappear because you already destroyed it, lazy.
And what I hated most in cutscenes, after every scene, Rico turns and shows you his back and just standing there. It gets annyoing after 2nd time.
Some missing option, you have car auto camera adjustment, but no wingsuiting, just lazy.
When you finish game, you cant skip credits, almost 10 minutes wasted lifetime, grrr.
Other than that, awesome game and you are not gonna find anything similar out there.

My brother told me I would like this game and I didn't believe him.

Then I played it and WOW was I surprised.  The world is so OPEN that if you're skilled, you'll start taking land from the enemy long before you're supposed to.

Instead of glitch tho, it turns out the developers actually EXPECTED you to do this.  SURPRISE!  The story line goes right along with you regardless of how fast or slow you're achieving objectives or even if you're taking areas you're not supposed to be able to take yet. 

You can tell they play tested the he|| out of this game, it's fun, and the variability of the terrain really PULLS you into the game.

When you're standing on the top of a building with the sun in your face, you almost forget that you're playing a game.

When VR comes out, I can imagine people just hanging out in games like this.

This game is packed to the brim with action, and it's absolutely great! Some challenges are annoying, but the overall experience is one akin to 80's action movies, with constant explosions on the screen making you feel like an unstoppable force of chaos. [h1][Review #1] 
Just Cause 3[/h1]
Pros:
1. Explosions
2. Incredible destruction (many things including bridges are destructible)
3. Huge open world
4. Tethering things to buildings and flinging them off is fun fun as hell
5. Traversal is exhilarating
6. Colourful graphics
7. Allows for many fun and creative gameplay. You have mechs, nuclear launchers and all. You can pull off stunts
8. Large variety of vehicles to have fun with

Cons:
1. Can get repetitive
2. Mediocre performance
3. The world is huge but looks almost the same from start to finish
4. Dumbass car driving mechanics
5. The cars just blows up the moment you leave the car, which is freaking frustrating in Crash Bombs challenges
6. The aftermath of destruction is underwhelming (Many debris just disappears after hitting the ground)
7. No Steam Cloud (if you delete your save file you are basically fucked)
8. Collectibles? Why?
9. Weapons are limited
10. Laguna Blast can go to hell

Although there are many shortcomings, I enjoyed this game a lot. You can tell by me spending 165 hours on this game. With the recent reveal of JC4 (my most anticipated game of the year), I hope that most of these issues are fixed.

There's some fun to be had here, but I have two big issues with this game.

Firstly, it clearly suffers from being designed for consoles. You can't edit the FOV or edit controls at all. Things that I would absolutely expect in any PC game.

Secondly, the plot sucks so bad. You are "liberating" a chain of islands. How are you liberating it? By destroying pretty much everything. Literally the more you destroy, the better. If the game could at least acknowledge how ridiculous this is, I might be more willing to give it a pass... but it presents you as a "heroic savior" narrative. Every NPC you talk to can't stop talking about how great and heroic you are. But you aren't. You're just some dumb idiot with big guns. A game like this should go one of two ways, pick either:
- Lean hard into the dumbness of it all and don't even pretend to have a plot. If you must have a plot make it as unobtrusive as possible.
- Actually engage with the topic with some seriousness. Make the player thoughtful about their destruction by recognizing that some things shouldn't be destroyed. Maybe penalize the player for carpet bombing civilian settlements. Maybe present at least one NPC which is sincerely critical of mass destruction. Otherwise the whole thing comes off like "Terrorist Simulator".

If you really do just want to switch off and blow up a lot of things, sure, maybe you'll have some fun with this. But it's all terribly superficial and senseless.

It's like going for a walk on a sunny day blowing shit up.
But towards the end it becomes annoying to have to do bases to unlock the next story mission.

I just want to preface this by saying, roughly 6-7 hours of my playtime was from my original playthrough in 2019 that I never finished. And frankly, I wish I never finished it - here's why:

1. Square Enix requires you to log into their servers for a singleplayer only game. There's no multiplayer, no being in the same "lobby" with other people like some of the Need For Speed games, you are just in singleplayer the ENTIRE time. It is absolutely redundant when the game can just be played without wifi. It even wastes a whole 60-90 seconds each time going into the game, so you just have to sit there. It also means when Square Enix inevitably shuts down the servers for JC3, this game will likely be DOA. 

2. Using the grappler half the time is just a straight up mess, especially when trying to climb up a mountain. Half the time when you reach your destination, you slip off and have to grapple again (and sometimes also jump depending on what you're trying to grapple to), which just makes for a mess when traversing through places and you don't have one of the Rebel Drop flares. Grappling onto other things above you have a similar experience depending on what you are grappling towards, so grappling all around is mid at best.

3. Precision Aim can only be acquired if you get enough mini-challenge gears to unlock it, which I find incredibly dumb. Games like Saints Row, which are also third person shooters, have precision aim straight out of the box. It should've been the same way here. In addition, they don't even bind it to LT - which has nothing mapped to it - and instead makes you push down the right stick for some reason. I guess you could maybe re-map that to LT (I didn't try) if the game allows, but I still find it incredibly bizarre considering LT was just not used in shooting controls. 

4. Load times are kinda bad, even today on modern SSDs. I did all of my playthrough on my Steam Deck (512 GB model, didn't change the SSD). The load times were about 60-90 seconds, and it didn't even look like they started in the cutscenes. I can understand not getting it fully loaded in time since the cutscenes are kinda short most of the time, but it doesn't seem like they load during the cutscenes, which just adds way more time to waste in between missions. Maybe you can boil it down to poor SSD optimization, but honestly I wouldn't be surprised if it's more of Square Enix's time wasting. 

5. The final boss battle against Di Ravello was kind of overpowered. Going into it I would say that I had most if not all of my original ammo, and when I got his helicopter down to about 30% health, I was starting to run out of all of my ammo, including my RPG. On my first attempt, I ran out of ammo and died because I had zero clue what I was supposed to do after I ran out, because it's not like I could grapple under Di Ravello's helicopter the entire time since he had the Bavarium Shield (Which, by the way, felt like it only went down for like 3 seconds and went back up for that first 2/3rds of the boss fight. It got better as the fight went on). Thankfully I realized that I had a rebel drop and I was able to use it, however, if the boss fight lasted for 5-10 more minutes, I would've run out of all the ammo I had gotten from the Rebel Drop, and then I would be utterly screwed. It also didn't help that there didn't seem to be any mini-challenges to upgrade your ammo capacity, or else it wouldn't be as much if at all an issue.


Frankly, the only pro of this game was the story. It was bearable enough for me to keep playing through this.


P.S. This isn't part of the reason why I gave the game a downvote, but HLTB (How Long To Beat, a website that lists how long it takes to beat games) via a Deckyloader plugin said that the game takes 18 hours for the main story. It took me approximately 44 hours, which I'd imagine 3-5 of those could equate to how much time it took for me to keep going after dying or doing very few of the mini-challenges to unlock some tether and precision aim upgrades. Essentially it took me roughly 38 hours give or take to beat the game, so do with that information what you will.

One of the roughest starts to any game I've ever played. The first 30 mins are basically do one thing, loading screen, cut scene, loading screen, walk 10 feet, loading screen, cut scene, loading screen, do one thing, etc.

You unlock all the core moveset items immediately (parachute, wingsuit, grapple hook). But you have to play for 20 hours before you get some basic quality of life upgrades like being able to chain grapple hooks before the full pull is complete, or grappling from the wingsuit. Because the core mechanics are unlocked right at the start, it makes the upgrades a lot less exciting. Not to mention the upgrades are really just things that should be in from the start. Like fast traveling - it works on a consumable. But you can get more of them after a lot of gameplay. Though the fastest way to restock them is usually to just close the game and re-open. The stupidest upgrade is the ability to slow and roll out of the wingsuit, because before that you have to open the parachute then close the parachute to land. Just terrible decisions to lock basic QoL upgrades behind tons of hours of gameplay.

Few things that really bother me about movement is that you can't return to an aerial free-fall after using the parachute, wingsuit, or grapple. I would love to fling myself through the air ragdoll style and take advantage of physics, but once you deploy a movement mechanic you can no longer free-fall. Another serious issue is that you cannot turn off camera auto-centering for the wingsuit. You can do it for all vehicles but not the wingsuit. So if you're using the jetpack wingsuit, flying over a town, looking for an objective, your camera will constantly keep pulling upwards.

The game is a destruction focused open world. But there are only like 20 weapons in the whole game. There are more non-combat vehicles than there are weapons. Moreso, the vehicles handle really poorly. Every base has automatic surface-to-air missle sites that will automatically target you in an aerial vehicle, even if there is no combat engagement. They will also target you immediately in the wingsuit, but they cannot target you in the parachute?

The DLCs are really weird. Usually a game's DLCs come with gameplay content, but here they are really just giving you a single gimmick that should be in the base game. One DLC has a jetpack that works with the wingsuit, the other an infinite ammo heavy weapon that calls down lightning strikes, the other gets you mechsuits. Each of the DLCs can be completed in under an hour, the cutscenes are animated still images with voice overlaid, have interesting locations but are over so quick.

There are so many bugs in the game. In fact I couldn't even play the entire 3rd act of the campaign because you are supposed to follow/protect an ally plane. When it breaks out of the cutscene, I am 2km away and can only go 350khp, enemy jets are flying past me at twice the speed to kill the ally. They take him down before I even get to 1km away. I tried exiting the plane and grappling to a faster enemy jet, but it fails the mission because I left my jet.

All in all, the game has some really interesting ideas, a well crafted open world, but poorly executed movement systems, progression, vehicles, and gameplay loop. You will not experience anything new after the first hour.
