Just Cause 3 is a videogame about destroying things and freeing a country from the evil dictator. Your grappling hook, parachute and wingsuit help you move around the island so you can destroy things quicker with your expansive arsenal of weapons and vehicles. If that got you interested, get this game on a big fat sale.
I really wish I could give this game the most neutral score possible. Not because it is bad, but because what I described is what you do in the previous games, and at least the second one does them much better.

[i]TL;DR at the bottom, lots of complaining incoming.[/i]

The core loop is there and it's even improved. Going around the island is much quicker thanks to new and improved movement options, between the wingsuit adding a method to go faster horizontally and the slingshot ability to add further specialized movement. Destructive elements are more sturdy but can be quickly destroyed by hitting a specific weakpoint that you have to find yourself, sometimes behind a gate or by destroying a specific part. Activities like races, going through rings or destroying things now have a reason to be completed, being what unlocks new powerful abilities.

And I think that's where I run out of positive things to say about the game.

Locking character progression behind doing races and stuff is boring, especially because cars in this game SUCK. I cannot believe they were almost boasting about getting "Criterion Games" developers (from Need for Speed fame) to do vehicles, and they end up feeling the worst in the franchise. They have a weird "weight", like if Rico was actually handling the steering wheel inside the car, and like he needs to fully turn it to neutral before turning to the other side quickly. Cars are also made of paper mache, both because they lift into the air at the smallest bump and also because of how quick they explode over the smallest crash. Bikes are no different and this problem is visible, turning to one side physically rotates the bike and the character leans to that side, and so to be able to quickly turn to the other side they first need to lean back to neutral position, and then lean to the other side, making the action have a weird delay and like you're lacking control over what you're driving. This game didn't need realistic driving. I can't believe the most shared tip to complete a specific difficult bike race in the game is "Spawn a car before starting the race, then ride the car instead of the bike".

Storywise it starts somewhat interesting, Rico coming back to his home country and fighting over freeing his old friends, and hearing his origin story, and having conflicting decisions over who to trust. And it very quickly drops the ball, introducing reoccurring characters with no influence in the story, making conflicts be quickly resolved with no afterthought, making super weird plot decisions that no sane human being would actually do... they said they wanted to make the story more serious compared to JC2, and I don't think it worked out for them. The villain felt actually threatening, sure, more cunning and smart, but he didn't have the power or weaponry like Baby Panay in JC2 to back it up. [i]I literally two shot the dude in the final fight.[/i]

And for a quickfire round for random problems I have with the game:
[list]
[*]WHY DO YOU BLOCK SUCH A BASIC THING LIKE [u]AIMING[/u] BEHIND PROGRESSION?!?!?!
[*]Why is the best handling, heaviest, most durable car in the game an F1 car.
[*]I understand that for explosive challenges I am driving an explosive car, but could it not blow up at the smallest bump in the road? People are calling these missions [i]bugged[/i] everywhere else when searching how to complete them.
[*]Why is turning with a plane bound to Z and C, and I'm unable to rebind it to something sane like Q or E because E ejects me from the plane with no way to rebind that. At least I got to use my controller I guess.
[*]Why do homing missiles on my fighter jet stop working for the entirety of the play session if I decided to AIM DOWNSIGHTS with my weapon ON FOOT at any point before?
[*]Why is my camera so far up my ass, and no FOV slider? I need a third party program to be able to edit it every single time I ran the game, it's honestly uncomfortable, and while it was close to the player in JC2 it was still at a more comfortable distance than now.
[*]The minimalist HUD, probably intended to have less things on screen while you fly around, really plays against you. No way to track health, no way to track oxygen for the 3 times in the entire game that you need to go on water, randomly getting two shot because I didn't hear that the only indication of my health, a heartbeat sound which was drowned by gunfire, hadn't completely faded out, which meant I was still regenerating health.
[*]Was my soundtrack bugged? I see the game has over 20 songs, but it felt like the same 3 played all the time, and it forced me to just mute the music about 30 hours in. I'm honestly playing some of these songs on Youtube and I have never heard them ingame.
[*]Why is Denuvo still in this game 7 years after being released. Why do I need to confirm I still own the game every week. Please Square Enix.
[*]After about 2-3 hours the game starts to break down on me. Particle effects stretch across my screen, models start stretching weirdly, low poly models don't unload; my GPU isn't running hot enough to cause this and the problems have persisted through driver updates.

Also to note, I almost immediately blocked this game from my firewall, and installed a "Skip Intros" mod. Doing both massively speeds up the game boot up time from over 3 minutes down to like 20 seconds at worst. The only multiplayer element in the game is Leaderboards so I really see no reason to have online activated. And disabling it [b]improved my game performance[/b].... what?

The only thing I'm missing to complete is the DLC, and I will update this review when I finish them.

I'm very critical over this game because I like the franchise. I like having this big fat "Ubisoft open world" map that I can quickly traverse across and cause chaos just because xd. Having them regress so much after a successful attempt, with no one catching it or recommending changes is baffling to me. I understand it was a "team B" developing this game while the "A team" developed Mad Max, but were they so far up theirs thinking that they were able to create a better game than the other team and just completely ignored all feedback, or even worse, thought that the game was fine? Did Squeenix force them to just launch the game as it was, but they weren't able to release bugfixes or changes to make the game feel better? I honestly need a post-mortem of this game, hell even the franchise in general, where did it go wrong?.

[u]TL;DR:[/u] If you like shooting things that explode and cool fast movement systems and don't care for story, get this game on a big sale. It's a great experience for those factors  I myself wouldn't recommend it to people coming from Just Cause 2 because it's honestly so rough seeing these changes. But it's not a bad, unfinished game, it just has weird changes, and maybe you can live with them. If so, hope you have fun. I certainly tried to.

The game is smooth, packed with ridiculous action and stunning visuals even after 5 years or how long has it been. Downside is repetitiveness - not much of a story to speak of and god-like ability of the main character makes the game-play feel like chore very soon as you go through enormous map and "liberate" one settlement after another again and again and again restroying the same objects scattered around similar bases, strike from heaven, nothing can harm you nothing can stop you. I'd appreciate a bit more challenge. A reason to cover a little in the fight or be forced to think about how to approach the base, because now you can just drop in the base packed with tanks, choppers, soldiers, sentries and just break it all without even minding the soldiers.
The mini-games (skydiving, racing) pose a nice challenge and there's a lot of things to be collected and various records to be set (although I feel like all of those have been broken by modders - it shows you who was better and no matter how you try every record is set several magnitudes higher than the game realistically allows)

BIG downside is poor PC optimization. All the controls are clearly meant for game-pad which results in motorbikes and cars having really strange turn gradient making especially the bikes nearly unusable. Key layout is the weirdest I ever encountered and if you change it for one type of vehicle, it changes for other too. Like you want to change plane controlls to wasd and arrows (instead of wasd zc shift ctrl (!)) but then you jump in the mech and cannot go straight. So you change it for the mech and then the helicopter shoots boosts with the same button etc etc... so you either 
a) change key settings every time you get in a vehicle
b) accept the game settings and grow an extra pair of fingers from your palm
c) connect game-pad (which would be great if I was able to aim with it)
Also every time you minimaze the game it goes to window view

[b] Achievements. Open world at its finest [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
Bring chaos in this open world action game where weapons, vehicles and gadgets at your disposal. 

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
The achievements are everything that a open world "should" have: challenges, collectibles and missions. Only a few where you have to beat a friends score but can be done fairly easily enough. DLC required, completion depends on skill and can be done in 60-70 hours. Guide is available.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
A truly open world experience where you can go wherever you want and complete whatever you want (after progression of course). Even with the DLC requirement the game is great for a more explorative open world game. A good recommendation.

----original review starts here----

This game has a LOT of issues. Seeing as it's in the sale and there will be a lot of people considering buying it, I feel like I should outline the issues. TL;DR and specs at the bottom.

- Performance, it varies from person to person but personally I have a medium/high-end gaming rig and still get stuttering and frame drops. I get smoother framerates on games with more graphic fedelity. On consoles it's the same story, constant frame rate drops.

- There's a memory leak issue that is yet to be fixed. Instead of fixing the issue, the devs just raised the minimum RAM requirement from 8GB to 16GB and added a message for every time you boot up the game telling you that you have insufficient memory. Apparently getting more RAM actually fixes a lot of performance issues with the game, go figure.

- The car handling in this game is so, so, bad. People says that Just Cause 2's handling was bad, but that game is a shining light of glory compared to JC3's habdling. And then just wait until you try a motorbike. The turning is horrid, it feels like you have no control sometimes. You hold down the button or move the stick to turn and there's a delay of about 1 second until your bike actually starts turning.  It's so easy to make them spin out and / or flip. Again, when the devs were questioned about this, they literally said "We think it's fine!" (can't find the link to the tweet but I'm sure it's out there).

- There's no native way to change the FOV. There's mods that let you do so but then when you do change it a whole bunch of glitches appear, like terrain not rendering, animations ending, etc. I usually wouldn't mind, but the default FOV is so low to begin with, try driving a car, it's right up in your face and you can barely see past it. 

- Missions are creative until you realise that a lot of them are the same being repeated multiple times. Story is boring, I ended up ignoring it and just fucking around. Plus, at least for me, destroying bases got boring after a while because there's so god damn many. Just Cause 2 did the whole "Chaos" thing better. When you destroyed military vehicles, killed personnel, destroyed bases, etc. you would gain Chaos and once you reached a certain point you would unlock new items and missions. This worked great because you would end up unlocking things just by fucking around. Just Cause 3 however makes you liberate towns and bases, which are mostly just the same thing over and over again. Destroy these buildings, shut down this surveillance system, open this door, free these prisoners, kill there people. Over and over. It's very repetitive. As for Chaos? It's just a meanless stat. 

- The rebel drop system is stupid. In JC3 you have to collect flares from rebel bases, and then use those to call in a rebel drop. You have limited flares, but that's ok because you can just get whatever you want for free whenever you want. Right? Wrong, because there's fucking WAIT TIMERS. You sometimes have to wait up to 20 minutes before you can drop in a plane again. It's one of the most anti-fun things a developer can do and is often paired with micro transactions that let you reduce the wait, but JC3 doesn't even HAVE microtransactions so the decision makes no sense.

Those are my main issues, but while I'm at it:

- There's no minimap. Why is there no minimap. You can pause the game and look at the map from there to find things buy that's no reason not to have a mini map.

- There's no sprint button. It makes Rico feel really slow in combat because you can't make him run any faster. The devs said that they want you to "use Rico's other movement skills" or whatever but JC2's sprint button was super useful.

- Devs said they wanted to support modders but every patch completely broke most mod. I think there's still some mods that haven't been updated to the latest versions of the game.

- Speaking of patches, there hasn't been one in months. You know what the latest patch was? DLC release. No big fixes. These devs charged us heaps of money for lackluster DLC and the worst part is I was idiotic enough to buy the first one. I'll give them the fact that have a booster on my wingsuit is cool but maybe they could use the extra time spent on DLC fixing the huge bugs in the game? Wait, that doesn't earn them money. Whoops, lol

- WHY DID THEY RE-INVENT THE WHEEL AND BIND LEFT CTRL TO BACK. WHY NOT JUST USE ESC. YOU KNOW, LIKE EVERY OTHER PROGRAM AND GAME EVER PROGRAMMED LIKE EVER. WHY. 

TL;DR: Is this game fun? Hell yeah, I have like 70 hours on it. Is it worth full price? Fuck no. Buy Just Cause 2 in the next sale for like $3 and then play it for three years until Just Cause 3 is a similar price. Just Cause 3 could have been great given another year of development. But it's just gonna forever be that game that could have been fucking awesome but instead blowed and probably killed the entire franchise. Good job, Avalanche. Next time give the game to a competent development team.

Rant over. Can you tell I'm still salty about a nearly 1 year old release?

The wingsuit is a good addition to the series, and the addition of upgrades you can get over time for your vehicles and equipment and such is nice, but the core gameplay is 90% spent either doing generic challenges to blow things up or parachuting around military bases and towns to just place explosives down while trivially avoiding all challenge. 

The parachute and wingsuit are a lot of fun to use - until you realize that they basically are the only way to get around, and there's absolutely zero reason to care about any of the vehicles in the game. You could use a helicopter - only to get it shot out of the sky by SAM sites, so you might as well just parachute or wingsuit dive around at the same speed (as long as you're above land you can grapple for speed) or faster while avoiding all danger. You can use cars of various types, but that just makes you a bigger target and again is pointless compared to just grappling around. I know some people will say "it's a sandbox, play how you want," but I and many other people do not enjoy actively handicapping ourselves and making things take far longer in games just so we get "variety."

There are pointless collectibles you can find around to waste your time, but for the most part the map is extremely empty - without interesting things to find or dynamic events or anything really worthwhile. So you'll spend most of your time between towns and such just quickly flying at mach 3 with your wingsuit, observing pretty but pointless scenery so you can actually get gameplay. Doing occasional timed challenges to destroy things or do wingsuit races or such so you can unlock what are effectively skill points for obligatory upgrades you have little agency over.

I really enjoyed Just Cause 2, and might still get through more of this game. The movement and grappling hook mechanics are great and have been refined very well. What disappoints me is that the world itself feels very boring to explore, and lacks the scale and "realism" (I say half in jest, you could grapple to the ground while falling in that game too) of Just Cause 2 that kept me immersed long enough to want to keep playing. The villain in this game is charismatic enough to keep me interested when you get the occasional audio log from him or see him in a cutscene, but otherwise there's not much to the characters or world that I care about.

In summary: Just Cause 3 is a generic open world collect-a-thon with above average movement mechanics and destruction, but unfortunately has all of the downsides of other generic open world collect-a-thons which I despise in the first place. If you enjoy games like every Assasin's Creed game ever released, or Ghost Recon Wildlands, or that kind of thing - you might like this. If you want something more substantial though, which values your time and doesn't have an open world solely to fill it with pointless nonsense - you won't get that here.

Edit: Another minor annoyance I just thought of is that when you finish the last objective in a zone, enemies in the area magically teleport out and resistance forces appear. I know that the game isn't very grounded in the first place, but it takes the tension out of things completely that destroying a random sign-post causes the two attack helicopters and dozens of soldiers currently shooting at me to just leave in disappointment.
A good open world game, specially if you like big explosions

I like blowing stuff up, but I don't like blowing up with them. I really don't like the objective structure of this game, because it simply encourages you to blow up an object, die, and then blow up an another object, or maybe blow a few in a row and then die. the game puts you in an enemy base with everything attacking you, and you just need to move around and avoid as many hits as possible while destroying structures. the thing is, at times because of the incredible amounts of enemy forces in the base, you find yourself looking at a black and white screen, waiting for a rocket to kill you or for you to be able to properly see again, while also hoping you won't crash into a wall. This simply isn't fun. I'd recommend you to play it only if you're not gonna try to finish it (weird thing to say, right?) and just roam around this massive open world using the incredible moveset (which is also poorly built for tighter spaces, like bases and tight cities for example) and maybe conquer some small bases and knock down some bridges.

First time I've ever posted a rant less than an hour into a game.  

And yes, this is a rant.  I fully admit that.  I have a free day today.  Downloaded the game last night and was excited to get up early this morning and play a new game.   

The start stinks.  Timed missions with poor guidance.  BS.  

Had to do the opening missions 4 or 5 times each because I'm expected to learn the  controls in the first 5 minutes while I'm defending against 20 enemies or have 1 minute to figure out and memorize the button sequence to get to my goal.  When it's that busy, it's too easy to miss the prompts.  Then, very often when I do catch it, it gives keyboard help instead of the controller.

10 seconds left...push [SPACE] to...huh?  GRRRRRRR!

Horrible way of trying to learn the game.  Ever hear of tutorials? 

I've played a lot of games that are frustrating at the start, but I had to shut it down after I tried over and over getting to the top of a mountain on a timed mission (like the 2nd or 3rd mission).  Everywhere I tried to use the grappling hook, it wanted to tether instead of reeling me up the cliff.  Frustrating.  

I can see it being a cool game.  I just wish I could play and not spend the whole morning doing the first missions over and over while I learn the controls.  That's not fun for me.  

Maybe if I can muster a little more patience, I'll try again.  I'll update if that happens.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. One of my favorite games is Just Cause 3. This game has amazing explosions, explosives are everywhere big and small. This is a very open world game with a huge map containing 3 main islands and a volcano that i believe is hidden off the map. Your character, Rico, has a grappler, redeployable parachute, and wingsuit to move around the air and fly like a bird. The main point of this game is to support a rebellion in this place Medici and blow up as many things as possible on your way so you can look and feel cool. Love the story, love Rico, and the game has so many cool things to do and check out.

I WILL ONLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME if you haven't played Just Cause 2. If you have, don't bother; this game is basically the same.

Just Cause 2 was pretty nice because there was no game like it that offered an open world to destroy. Just Cause 3 does the same and adds wingsuits and better tether hook possibilities, but it didn't make a change for me and playing the game felt the same. The only enjoyable way I found playing the game was by getting a bomber jet and bombing every place on the map like I was a NATO pilot bombing Yugoslavia in 1999.

Good points in the game was the aforementioned bomber jet, but also the beautiful graphics and the fact you can unlock vehicles to call in by 'liberating' (in other words bombing the hell out of) villages or military bases. But the game is basically a sea that is 20 centimeter deep. The gameplay is super simple and the map is too large for that. Perk unlocks are too many as well, I modded the game to unlock all of it because I'm not bothered wasting time on that. The controls in the game are super weird on PC as well, the vehicles feel super slow. 
The story just like JC2, is basically irrelevant and the gameplay doesn't make up for it.

As a fan of open-world games, Just Cause 3 definitely delivered on all the action and chaos I was looking for. The graphics are stunning and the ability to make chaos with all the different gadgets and weapons at my disposal was a blast. I also really appreciated the freedom to explore the beautiful Mediterranean setting and take on a variety of missions.

One of the highlights for me was definitely the range of vehicles available, from cars and motorcycles to planes and helicopters. The controls took a bit of getting used to, but once I had the hang of it, soaring through the skies and causing destruction on the ground was an absolute thrill.

I also had played the expansion DLCs for Just Cause 3, and I must say that I was thoroughly impressed by the additional content. The new stories added by the DLCs were engaging and added a lot of value to my overall experience with the game. The expanded map also allowed for even more freedom to explore and cause chaos, which was a joy to experience.

There were a few frustrating moments, such as the occasional glitch or bug, but overall the gameplay was smooth and the storyline kept me engaged to the end! :)

[b]Just Cause 3[/b] is a really fun and chaotic game which you should consider trying out.

[i]"What you gonna do when I come for you?"[/i] - Rico Rodriguez

My review on the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TheBeggarSoldier/recommended/401850/]Air, Sea & Land Expansion Pass[/url], which you should totally get for your playthrough.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
- Huge map
- Great storyline with fun comedic characters
- Great voice acting [i](Especially the propaganda spokesman)[/i]
- Steam content [i](Achievements, wallpapers, emoticons etc.)[/i]
- Really good animations
- Well done cutscenes
- Soundtrack is pretty good
- Awesome destruction physics
- Lot of Abilities/skills which the game calls "Gear Mods", these mods can be obtained by completing challenges around the islands.
- Lot of challenges
- Great variety of weapons
- Great variety of vehicles
- Grappling hook, wingsuit and parachute
- Lots of bases to be liberated

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- If you don't have at least 16GB of RAM, then the game will crash AFAIK
- Default FOV is really bad
- Game sometimes crashes for no reason
- Some performance issues
- Lot of bugs, sometimes game breaking
- Sniper rifles are considered "special" weapons and they take away your rocket/grenade launcher.
- Aiming is a seperate skill [i](Gear mod)[/i]
- Driving some vehicles are clunky

[b][u]Tips and Advices:[/u][/b]
- For the FOV issue, I used the [b]JustFOV mod[/b] which you can download easily, also be sure if you are about to use this mod to [b]have a fov toggle between 35 and your desired FOV[/b], otherwise cutscenes will be broken in some way
- Spoiler alert: [spoiler]There will be a very game breaking bug at the mission [b]"Rico and the Rose"[/b] where your jet won't lock onto the jets that are attacking Rosa's plane. All you have to do is [b]turn off the precision aiming mod[/b] then restart the game.[/spoiler]

[b]8/10[/b] You can have a lot of fun playing this game and I highly recommend it, especially on a sale, even with all the game's flaws.

My Just Cause 3 review

The positives

+The graphics are pretty good
+Flying around with the rope launcher and jet pack is a great deal of fun
+There are many different and varied vehicles to choose from
+The over-the-top action which consists of blowing stuff up is very fun for the first few hours
+One the three major DLCs is good
+The wanted system is pretty good

The negatives

-The main story is brainless and uninteresting
-The characters aren't memorable
-The voice acting isn't AAA level
-Although the gameplay loop is fun at first, it gets very stale once you realize the entire game is only that
-The open world doesn't really have any proper side missions, just repetitive liberation activities
-The driving is pretty bad
-The entire world looks unvaried with basically every location looking almost identical. This holds especially true for the countryside
-The flying mechanics for planes are abhorrent for keyboard & mouse
-There isn't much in the way of customization
-The other two major DLCs are boring and/or annoying
-The movement while simply walking is subpar

Score: 6.0/10

This game has a LOT of issues.
Instead of fixing the issue, the devs just raised the minimum RAM requirement from 8GB to 16GB and added a message for every time you boot up the game telling you that you have insufficient memory.
Apparently getting more RAM actually fixes a lot of performance issues with the game, go figure.- The car handling in this game is so, so, bad.
Just Cause 2 did the whole "Chaos" thing better.
In JC3 you have to collect flares from rebel bases, and then use those to call in a rebel drop.

- There's a memory leak issue that is yet to be fixed. Instead of fixing the issue, the devs just raised the minimum RAM requirement from 8GB to 16GB and added a message for every time you boot up the game telling you that you have insufficient memory. Apparently getting more RAM actually fixes a lot of performance issues with the game, go figure.

This game has a LOT of issues. Seeing as it's in the sale and there will be a lot of people considering buying it, I feel like I should outline the issues. TL;DR and specs at the bottom.

- Performance, it varies from person to person but personally I have a medium/high-end gaming rig and still get stuttering and frame drops. I get smoother framerates on games with more graphic fedelity. On consoles it's the same story, constant frame rate drops.
Very Fun game, I recommend it!

Some people seem to think that this is a realistic game, and it's not. You ride missiles, its not realistic. The lack of realism is quite nice, meaning that you get some really good thrills and some awesome moments ass you play the game.

If you have friends, there are leaderboards that you can challenge them on, but I found it was full of random tryhards with the highest possible scores, and so I couldn't see my friends' scores. In challenges, you can race the ghost of your friend, but it's a bit weird and I feel that the system for this was half completed. It's too buggy and my friend's ghost would disappear, crash into a wall or suddenly teleport throughout a race. It's also annoying that a lot of end game content (like mods and abilities) are locked behind these challenges, and its really hard to unlock them all with 5 gears to get the mod.

On the other hand, JC3 still looks great, and it's honestly one of the prettiest games I've played this year. The cars handle (mostly) fairly well. Big cars feel heavy and small cars feel light. The open world is truly open. Nowhere is off limits and you can go anywhere and do anything, it's great! There's a lot to do, collect, unlock, find, so you will be busy and it keeps completionists happy, but once again, there's too much. It took me another 70 hours after finishing the main story to unlock everything else, and it feels too grindy.

So, do I recommend Just Cause 3? NO. It's too buggy for me, and I find that it's too big, with too much to do with no incentive for it to be fun at all. Once you've beaten the story and the DLC, either you're too overpowered and combat isn't fun, or it's just go somewhere, blow it up, collect and repeat. You can't configure the keyboard to how you like it, which is annoying, and the AI is awful. People just drive into you and it doesn't feel like a normal city. Rico can't sprint, so in combat you're slow or forced to use your grapple. (If you get motion sick like me, its really not fun. I threw up at least 3 times while playing as I got motion sick from being upside down all the time). The rebel characters are also weird. I can kill about 30 and the ones that are alive still go "Yay Rico, you're the best!". Enemy spawning is also bad. I have had enemies spawn behind me and it kills the immersion. 

Overall, a great game spoiled by lazy developing and bugs that never got fixed. A poor 4/10. I'd recommend getting on sale if at all.

The Just Cause franchise is the pinacle of open world action adventure gaming. No other similar game series has this much content and freedom of movement in such a beautiful singleplayer game world. Everything you wished that was there in games like Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, is there in Just Cause. And what it lacks in terms of storyline progression, it more than makes up for in terms of pretty much all the other gameplay elements.

Pros:
+ The Just Cause 3 XXL Edition, has an insane amount of quality playtime to offer for the price. Especially when it is on sale, for less than ten euros.
+ A 1000 km² open game world with a Mediterranean paradise theme. It looks and feels like you are on holiday in, for example, the province of Istria in Croatia. You will see a lot of similarities with cities/towns like Fažana, Labin, Motovun, Pazin, Rabac, Rovinj and Vrsar. And of course little islands like the surroundings of Brijuni National Park.
+ Just exploring the island is an enjoyable activity in itself. There are also a striking number of details: fully decked out towns/villages and farms, underwater landscapes, cave systems, forests with animals, and a lot of audiovisual propaganda about the policy on the island.
+ Talking about the game world propaganda and the mischievous dictatorial behaviour: it is quite absurdistic and funny, but still realistic enough that some organizations would actually be spreading this kind of stuff in real life. For example, you will notice some behaviour patterns that can be applied to your direct surroundings... The developers really did their homework here!
+ An unprecedented number of vehicles. Including speedboats, jets, helicopters, turbo-fuelled sports cars and super bikes, MechWarrior-like robots, military ships and planes with heavy weaponry.
+ A very large and diverse arsenal of firearms. Everything from remote mines to absurdly overpowered rocket launchers.
+ Introduction of the Wingsuit with jet engine, minigun and missiles.
+ Massive destruction and explosions while annihalating military bases, harbours, prisons, police stations and communications facilities. You can even carry out bombing missions with a military fighter jet. Just Cause has that wow-factor in this regard.
+ Tethering multiple objects together with the grapling hook, sometimes with hilarious results.
+ You can just spend many hours of "stunting" with all the game mechanics and vehicles.
+ The overall visual performance is very good. Nice graphics for a game from 2015, without absurd system requirements. And above all: no loading times and few pop-ups while exploring the game world.
+ Day and night cycle looks beautiful.
+ Remarkably few bugs for a game engine of this size and complexity.

Cons:
- Loading time during game startup. Just Cause 4 improved this quite a bit.
- The storyline is a bit mediocre and slow. But that is pretty much the cause with all the games in the series.
- The main villain (a Tropico-like dictator) is not getting enough attention. There are a lot of good character details hidden in the collectibles, which are underexposed during the course of the story missions. But overall he is still a more detailed villain than the main one in Just Cause 4.
- The missions are repetitive in design and execution. But not as bad as in Just Cause 4.
- While there is a diverse set of fun side activities, they will also become a tedious time sink to complete the game on 100%.
- Getting to 100% game completion territory, requires an insane amount of time.
- The music is OK-ish and does the job, but it's nothing special and not very memorable. I will not be listening to this stuff outside of the game. Overall, the music in Just Cause 4 is a lot better.
- AI of the enemies and NPCs doesn't always make sense.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Apex Legends and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The only thing I found enjoyable about jc3 was the on foot movement/gameplay. Being able to be spiderman with a gun is just as fun as it was in jc2 and the wing-suit makes aerial movement engaging. In fact whenever I had to liberate a location, I would hardly use my guns, I would favor swinging/flying around and attaching bombs to everything and then detonating elsewhere because it was that fun.

However, everything else about the game is a massive drag. For a 2016 game, the graphics aren't very good (like the default resolution being like 1280x720 and being stretched so much that the menu options are located off the bottom of the screen is a massive WTF). The cars and boats all handle like trash, as they are either one of two extremes: Incredibly slippery or they move slower than a tank. This (un)intentionally compels the use of either fighter jets or using the wing-suit to get around quickly. Speaking of which, moving around the map is an absolute chore as the map is way to big for how limited the travel options are. Jc3 may as well not have a fast travel system because the only way you can use it is that you can only fast travel to places you have liberated from a liberated location. This is meant to force you to liberate locations to expand this option, but it's not fun. It just feels like a way to force a bootleg far cry experience.

The biggest sin that this game commits is the main story and its missions. They didn't even attempt with this game's main story. It feels rushed and every cutscene lasts for about 2 minutes with all these """characters""" spewing out garbage one liners while moving along with an extremely generic action plot. Then you're left to deal with the main missions which boil down to 4 types: Wing-suit shilling, set pieces, battlefields and escort missions. The wing-suit missions are only there to force you to try the new mechanic, it's not fun following glowing pipes in the valley for 5 minutes straight, the set pieces are the only interesting content like the train sabotage but are hardly present and the battlefields are generic "rush to point a and save the ai then go to point b and do the same, etc." 

But the worse missions are the escort missions which are probably 50-60% of the main story missions. These are all terrible missions that drag on for far too long and are incredibly frustrating due to how fragile the escorts are. The worst example has to be towards the middle section of the game where you have to defend mario (he's easily the worst character in the game and his death here would actually have improved jc3). However the idiot decides to stand in the middle of the beach and face tank all of the missiles and rounds from the tanks, ships and soldiers that bum rush him. "Well why not use the emp like the game wants you to?" BECAUSE MARIO IS STANDING IN THE MIDST OF ALL THE STUFF THAT EXPLODES FROM THE EMP BLAST AND HE'LL DIE EVERY TIME. This just forces you to use the care package system to call in a tank/hind/rocket launcher to ignore the game's suggestions and kill everything before mario dies. And this is not an isolated issue.

There are also times where you have to use weapons that do explosive or large damage (like a helicopter) but then the geniuses who designed this game thought it would be a great idea to have friendly fire on, which not only means you can accidentally kill escorts, BUT THE """FRIENDLY""" NPC'S CAN ALSO KILL YOU RANDOMLY EVEN THOUGH YOU'RE ON THE SAME SIDE.

Terrible game, downgrade from jc2 in every way save for the grapple and wing-suit and ultimately a massive waste of time. I only suffered through this game because I made the mistake of buying this on sale not long after release and I only just now got to it.

It's really interesting how only a few small changes in its basic mechanics clearly elevate [i][b]Just Cause 3™[/b][/i] from the previous outing.

In its core, it's basically the same game, with a similar story as the previous ones (serving basically as the new excuse to play around in the sandbox), offering only the added bonus of the new wingsuit to facilitate the traversal.
And yet, the simplicity in changing between transportation methods (grappling hook, parachute and wingsuit) leads the way to some great combinations to get around the map quickly and stylishly. 
Even the simple action of scaling up a building or grappling to a vehicle is made so much easier with the tweeks made to the snapping point that, maybe not that evident, put this one ahead of [i][b]Just Cause 2™[/b][/i]. Fun as it was previously, the grappling hook could be frustrating to use sometimes, especially when in motion.

Despite this, I felt pretty disappointed after completed the main story, as the final mission was very easy and unoriginal, putting us against another helicopter and cutting immediately to credits after the general's death. After the fun and more challenging ending mission of [i][b]Just Cause 2™[/b][/i], jumping between high-rises and having to exploit different attack strategies, this one looks way too lazy and anti-climactic. 
And Sheldon's final witty remarks were sorely missed —even with the pretended more personal story.

It may not shake the formula as much as it should, but all the small improvements allow for a more polished (and, subsequently, fun!) Rico Rodriguez experience.

It's a great game! ...as long as you don't expect it to be like Just Cause 2. It's a different game with the same but improved Rico. I'd say it's more like Red Faction: Guerrilla with frikin' Rico, the way the missions and challenges are and how your friendlies gradually take over and the bad guys disappear. The controls are different in this one, for example, grapple is on the mouse instead of F, which is annoying at first but I STRONGLY RECOMMEND you get used to it, rather than change the mapping, because it turns out to be better once you stop forgetting and wasting your grenades trying to grapple. You kind of get forced into the challenges, unlike JC2, in order to up your gear, but that's not bad, it makes you get good at things you might normally not. I think the missions are better in this one. There is more to feel compassion for the citizens in this one, you have little connection with them in JC2. The wing suit is a great enhancement, especially if you get the Sky Fortress DLC and do the missions to get the wing suit thrusters, which is AWESOME! The map can be completed in less time than JC2, as JC3 has fewer locations (which I think is a good thing because I feel you can spend years to complete the map in JC2, might never finish, I like to finish). It looks like they improved the steering with driving and flying since I had it on PS4, or so I hear. It could also be that I am horrible with a controller (I'm a KB&M or die kind of guy, never could beat games with a controller).

Honestly, this game has a few issues, but I would overall recommend the game. 

In this game, you mainly follow the Far Cry gameplay loop of liberating settlements from the big baddie of the region and progressing throughout the area. This game excels in one main thing: enjoyable gameplay.

The gameplay loop in this game is quite fun. The main thing that makes the gameplay fun has to be the grappling hook, the parachute, and wingsuit. Being able to grapple to almost any surface and also have the option to instantly start gliding is amazing. Not to mention the wide variety of environments that this game has to offer, from archipelagos to snowy mountaintops. If you don't find the enjoyment in this, then I don't know how else I could explain it, but I guarantee you that it is a fun experience for most people!

Unfortunately, this game has issues with glitches and being forced online. I never found any issue with the game being forced online but I could see how that would be annoying. However, the glitches were quite annoying, especially with achievement hunting. Some side missions are glitches, some locations of the game show noticeable drops in FPS for no reason, sometimes things just explode for no reason, and more. 

Overall, despite the issues present with Just Cause 3, I would say the enjoyment far outweighs the negatives. You can brush off the negatives present in the game if you truly enjoy the gameplay loop. It is a shame AAA games are just expected to come with issues these days, but it is what it is.

The game is not bad, but definitely has it's issues.  I could definitely see how someone might find it worth the money, especially with the sales at $3.  But I personally don't see myself playing it much for the reasons I'll explain.  For context I only have less than an hour in the game before I figured I'd give up on it in favor of playing something else, a fair part of that time is loading / trying to log in for a single player game for some reason.

The graphics are good, they hold up 7 years later.  Not amazing graphics by today's standards, but nothing I'll complain about.

The controls weren't natural to me. Some of the tutorials weren't as clear as they could have been.  The big thing in this area that was a big miss for me was the fact there is no sight usage.  You can only hip fire (Except for apparently sniper rifles).  To me that felt like it didn't reward skill (which I don't have but it's more fun).  The sprint speed felt slow.  First mission I parachuted to the ground slightly too soon and it took forever to reach what felt like a few seconds worth of space to cover.

The game play seemed pretty good with the exception of the related things I'll cover elsewhere.  It was pretty fun to grapple from one object to the next and parachute between them quickly.  It wasn't realistic at all but for sake of game play, that was a worthwhile trade.  In my time playing I never got used to the slow steering when driving cars.  It felt too long to respond to directions. Realistic, but hurt the game play in my opinion.  I probably would have gotten over this though.  Some of the movement felt goofy.  The game felt somewhat unrefined and could have used some tweaking to make it feel better.

As for story, I got major vibes that the main character is a 'Gary Stu'.  Firing only from the hip definitely made that feel that way more.  You literally start off firing an rpg while standing on top of an airplane.  There very well might be some good character development later on in the story, but I got the vibes of "bad ass for sake of being a bad ass" type character.

The final straw for me to desire a refund on the game was a bug in the map system where I had a rather large tutorial notification to push tab and select a spot to way point.  I couldn't get that off the screen after several minutes of trying and following the tutorial.

You might think I didn't give it enough time to thrive.  The trailers look cool, the map looked very expansive.  It just didn't quite hit the mark for me enough to feel like it was something I wanted to keep in my library and play long enough to disqualify myself from a refund.
Still good in 2022, although I would add more explosions.

I absolutely love the movement in this game. Mastering using the grappling hook, parachute, and the new wingsuit simultaneously makes this game so much more fun. And it's already a pretty fun third-person shooter. Combat feels pretty great, and the difficulty is fairly good (if a bit too easy. But with how much Rico can do it's to be expected.)
The story is fairly bland, though. It's also kind of hard to follow if you haven't played at least JC1. Also, some of the challenges are glitched/untested and are way too hard to complete (cough cough Laguna Bomb Blast). But they're not impossible at the very least.
A very fun game for 100% achievements. Would recommend for anyone that enjoys third-person shooters, and perhaps even some who don't.
